On behalf of caregivers everywhere. Thank you for your support!

story:
♻️ WE DID IT!!! ♻️ 

We came, we saw, we built a giant butt in the middle of the desert! And the reception was AMAZING. We handed out hundreds of anti-litter ashtrays AND got to connect one-on-one with individuals to have empowering and enlightening conversations on how we can be better guardians of the earth. 

It was a HUGE SUCCESS and while my bones are tired and I can’t seem to get enough sleep, I’m deeply grateful for how everything came together, and everyone who supported, including YOU. 

The future is promising, as we are currently in talks with music festivals about taking THE BUTT on the road. How cool?!

SO, it was a huge success AND... it also cost A LOT more than we expected. From increased transportations costs, to custom metal fabrication so our structure held up, to LED lighting that illuminated the piece at night, to all the random nuts bolts and foam that served as the “ash”, this puppy’s expenses really added up. It’s been a dream come true and a burden I’ve been willing to take on BUTT I now have some hefty bills to pay and would REALLY APPRECIATE your support. 

If you can donate some to help reach the goal, GREAT. 

If you want to further the cause and get a reusable pocket ashtray for yourself or a friend GREAT, we will ship to anywhere in the US. 

There are only 7 days left to contribute, thank you for your support in keeping this green planet green :) 

Thanks for making this happen and I can’t wait to share with you what’s next.

Much Love,
Princess 

 

 

THE PROBLEM

  • 4.5 TRILLION, yes, TRILLION, cigarette butts are littered throughout the world each and every year.  That’s OVER 8 MILLION a minute. AND, cigarette butts take up to 10 YEARS to degrade.  SO. NOT. SUSTAINABLE.
  • Made of non-biodegradable cellulose acetate—a type of plastic—cigarette BUTTs are the MOST LITTERED PLASTIC ITEM IN THE WORLD (and arguably the smelliest).
  • Cigarette butts start countless forest fires, leach toxins into the ground and waterways, and to top that off that kids eat them, fish eat them, birds eat them. AND cigarette butts make their way back into our food supply. Worst of all, it's 2019 and it's still socially acceptable to flick them on the street.
  • Sadly, cigarette butts are one of most commonly MOOPed items on the Playa as well.

 

 
 

THE SOLUTION

We are raising funds to do SOMETHING POSITIVE about toxic litter.

Your contribution will directly support us to:

  1. BUILD the art piece: 'THE BUTT' Its construction will raise awareness of the issue and also serve as a recycling station for cigarette butts
  2. DISTRIBUTE OVER 1,000 REUSABLE  POCKET ASHTRAYS to burners to leep
  3. the playa clean and recycle ♻️ their waste. Individuals can use their pocket ashtrays for years to come, potentially saving our streets from tons of toxic waste.
  4. RECYCLE all the butts collected from the art piece. Part of our long term goal is to build benches and structures on the Playa with the recycled material.

Turning waste into useful materials

 

Custom, one-off reusable pocket ashtray (limited to 1,000)

 

Why This? Why Burning Man?

 

 

LEAVE NO TRACE is one of Burning Man's Ten Principles to which all burners abide. Burning Man is also a ripe field for change, allowing individuals to reexamine their behaviors, and change old patterns that no longer serve them. We believe that by inviting individuals into a new way of thinking about MOOP (Matter Out Of Place) on the playa, they will be encouraged to do so off the playa as well. 

 

How You Can Get Involved

We need funds to make this dream come true. We have already been approved by Burning Man to construct our art project and make this all happen. Now, we are asking for your love and support in achieving our goals and keeping the planet clean.

Every dollar contributed will go directly to the BUILD of our ART PIECE and the PRODUCTION of the REUSABLE POCKET ASHTRAYS, which, of course, are made of recyclable materials!

  • For $5, we will give you or gift an ashtray in your honor during the Burn.
  • For $10, we will give you or gift TWO ashtrays in your honor.
  • For $20, we will give you or gift FIVE ashtrays in your honor. 
  • For every donation over $20, your name will be written on the ladder up to the art piece.  

Our dream to build this art piece, and produce reusable pocket ashtrays will come to fruition with the support of our family, friends, and community.  Thank you <3

 

What Will You Do With My Money?

(Good Question!)

  • We will use your funds to make and distribute the pocket ashtrays, build the art piece, and transport it to and from the burn.
  • EVERY DOLLAR above our goal will be used with appreciation and care to REDUCE litter, RAISE AWARENESS, and EMPOWER individuals to better take care of our planet.

Who Are You, Anyway?

We are some unique individuals (just like you!) who want to DO SOMETHING POSITIVE instead of just getting angry and farting in public (not the best way to vent FYI—you get lots of weird looks and not much sympathy).

  • I (Roman, the lead artist) am a creative currently residing in New York City, where I handout an abundance of high fives, host volunteer street cleanups, DJ rooftop sunset sessions with friends, and hang out with cats as much as I can.  
  • I AM PASSIONATE about innovative solutions to big problems (aka situations). I feel the state of our environment, this awesome blue dot we call home, SHOULD BE OUR BIGGEST COLLECTIVE PRIORITY. I also believe we can get this place looking nice again, and functioning in a healthy way, in a FUN and POSITIVE way that doesn't involve yelling, chastising, or demonizing people that are doing their best, or just simply don't know any better.
  • This campaign MEANS THE WORLD TO ME. The fact that you are reading this literally brings tears to my eyes. At my first burn (this will be my third) I dreamed that one day I would contribute to the most amazing art in the world (which I feel lives for one week in the middle of the desert). I just didn't know that it would come so fast ("T.W.H.S.").
  • Our camp (Camp Waylate) is a group of directionally challenged people from all over the world, yet all call Burning Man home. Our camp is relatively small, about 12-20 individuals, so this will be an all-hands on deck build. We believe strongly in the importance of family, coming together to support each other, and that the best experiences and projects are truly enjoyed when shared. 
  • REGARDLESS OF YOUR CONTRIBUTION, you are ALWAYS more than welcome to come hang out with us at our camp if you make if to the burn this year!
    •   CAMP WAYLATE - 9:15 & G

Photos by Eric Starr

Other Ways You Can Help

Sometimes well-meaning people just can't contribute with the Benjamins, and that’s okay. BUTT, (see what I did there?)  that doesn't mean you can't support in other ways!

  • Regardless of whether or not you can contribute monetarily, please share this to your billionaire Uncle Jessie, on social media, or via carrier pigeon.
  • Also, please contact me if you'd like to help with the build in Los Angeles (August 8-22nd), I could use all the help I can get!

 

THANK YOU for your support and much, much, much, much love. <3
Roman "Princess Meow Meow" Rac

et al.
story_txt:
♻️ WE DID IT!!! ♻️ 

We came, we saw, we built a giant butt in the middle of the desert! And the reception was AMAZING. We handed out hundreds of anti-litter ashtrays AND got to connect one-on-one with individuals to have empowering and enlightening conversations on how we can be better guardians of the earth. 
It was a HUGE SUCCESS and while my bones are tired and I can’t seem to get enough sleep, I’m deeply grateful for how everything came together, and everyone who supported, including YOU. 
The future is promising, as we are currently in talks with music festivals about taking THE BUTT on the road. How cool?!
SO, it was a huge success AND... it also cost A LOT more than we expected. From increased transportations costs, to custom metal fabrication so our structure held up, to LED lighting that illuminated the piece at night, to all the random nuts bolts and foam that served as the “ash”, this puppy’s expenses really added up. It’s been a dream come true and a burden I’ve been willing to take on BUTT I now have some hefty bills to pay and would REALLY APPRECIATE your support. 
If you can donate some to help reach the goal, GREAT. 
If you want to further the cause and get a reusable pocket ashtray for yourself or a friend GREAT, we will ship to anywhere in the US. 
There are only 7 days left to contribute, thank you for your support in keeping this green planet green :) 
Thanks for making this happen and I can’t wait to share with you what’s next.
Much Love,Princess 
 
 
THE PROBLEM



4.5 TRILLION, yes, TRILLION, cigarette butts are littered throughout the world each and every year.  That’s OVER 8 MILLION a minute. AND, cigarette butts take up to 10 YEARS to degrade.  SO. NOT. SUSTAINABLE.
Made of non-biodegradable cellulose acetate—a type of plastic—cigarette BUTTs are the MOST LITTERED PLASTIC ITEM IN THE WORLD (and arguably the smelliest).
Cigarette butts start countless forest fires, leach toxins into the ground and waterways, and to top that off that kids eat them, fish eat them, birds eat them. AND cigarette butts make their way back into our food supply. Worst of all, it's 2019 and it's still socially acceptable to flick them on the street.
Sadly, cigarette butts are one of most commonly MOOPed items on the Playa as well.
   THE SOLUTIONWe are raising funds to do SOMETHING POSITIVE about toxic litter.Your contribution will directly support us to:

BUILD the art piece: 'THE BUTT' Its construction will raise awareness of the issue and also serve as a recycling station for cigarette butts

DISTRIBUTE OVER 1,000 REUSABLE  POCKET ASHTRAYS to burners to leep
the playa clean and recycle ♻️ their waste. Individuals can use their pocket ashtrays for years to come, potentially saving our streets from tons of toxic waste.


RECYCLE all the butts collected from the art piece. Part of our long term goal is to build benches and structures on the Playa with the recycled material.
Turning waste into useful materials Custom, one-off reusable pocket ashtray (limited to 1,000)
 
Why This? Why Burning Man?
 

 
LEAVE NO TRACE is one of Burning Man's Ten Principles to which all burners abide. Burning Man is also a ripe field for change, allowing individuals to reexamine their behaviors, and change old patterns that no longer serve them. We believe that by inviting individuals into a new way of thinking about MOOP (Matter Out Of Place) on the playa, they will be encouraged to do so off the playa as well. 
 
How You Can Get InvolvedWe need funds to make this dream come true. We have already been approved by Burning Man to construct our art project and make this all happen. Now, we are asking for your love and support in achieving our goals and keeping the planet clean.Every dollar contributed will go directly to the BUILD of our ART PIECE and the PRODUCTION of the REUSABLE POCKET ASHTRAYS, which, of course, are made of recyclable materials!
For $5, we will give you or gift an ashtray in your honor during the Burn.
For $10, we will give you or gift TWO ashtrays in your honor.
For $20, we will give you or gift FIVE ashtrays in your honor. 
For every donation over $20, your name will be written on the ladder up to the art piece.  
Our dream to build this art piece, and produce reusable pocket ashtrays will come to fruition with the support of our family, friends, and community.  Thank you <3 What Will You Do With My Money?(Good Question!)
We will use your funds to make and distribute the pocket ashtrays, build the art piece, and transport it to and from the burn.

EVERY DOLLAR above our goal will be used with appreciation and care to REDUCE litter, RAISE AWARENESS, and EMPOWER individuals to better take care of our planet.
Who Are You, Anyway?We are some unique individuals (just like you!) who want to DO SOMETHING POSITIVE instead of just getting angry and farting in public (not the best way to vent FYI—you get lots of weird looks and not much sympathy).
I (Roman, the lead artist) am a creative currently residing in New York City, where I handout an abundance of high fives, host volunteer street cleanups, DJ rooftop sunset sessions with friends, and hang out with cats as much as I can.  

I AM PASSIONATE about innovative solutions to big problems (aka situations). I feel the state of our environment, this awesome blue dot we call home, SHOULD BE OUR BIGGEST COLLECTIVE PRIORITY. I also believe we can get this place looking nice again, and functioning in a healthy way, in a FUN and POSITIVE way that doesn't involve yelling, chastising, or demonizing people that are doing their best, or just simply don't know any better.
This campaign MEANS THE WORLD TO ME. The fact that you are reading this literally brings tears to my eyes. At my first burn (this will be my third) I dreamed that one day I would contribute to the most amazing art in the world (which I feel lives for one week in the middle of the desert). I just didn't know that it would come so fast ("T.W.H.S.").
Our camp (Camp Waylate) is a group of directionally challenged people from all over the world, yet all call Burning Man home. Our camp is relatively small, about 12-20 individuals, so this will be an all-hands on deck build. We believe strongly in the importance of family, coming together to support each other, and that the best experiences and projects are truly enjoyed when shared. 

REGARDLESS OF YOUR CONTRIBUTION, you are ALWAYS more than welcome to come hang out with us at our camp if you make if to the burn this year!  CAMP WAYLATE - 9:15 & G


Photos by Eric Starr
Other Ways You Can Help
Sometimes well-meaning people just can't contribute with the Benjamins, and that’s okay. BUTT, (see what I did there?)  that doesn't mean you can't support in other ways!

Regardless of whether or not you can contribute monetarily, please share this to your billionaire Uncle Jessie, on social media, or via carrier pigeon.
Also, please contact me if you'd like to help with the build in Los Angeles (August 8-22nd), I could use all the help I can get!

 
THANK YOU for your support and much, much, much, much love. <3Roman "Princess Meow Meow" Rac
et al.

story:
Fired up to fire up!

It’s been an exciting year of planning and building for the newly founded River Song Pottery in Plano, IL! Approaching the first firing, we have a few necessary and important steps to take care of before we can start the kindling and build the fire up to a blaze. 

I’m stoked about how much we’ve accomplished so far! 

  • We purchased five acres of land in Plano. Plenty of space for pallets of wood, and for industrious potters to build more wood kilns!
  • It's wooded! Unlike most of Illinois! We have befriended a neighbor/landscaper who has already donated a year's worth of firewood at the property. We have split enough wood for the first two firings.
  • The property came with a sizeable barn. A two-story section will eventually be framed out to become studio space and a gallery. 
  • The kiln room was built in an addition, which will protect me from the harsh winters. I was diagnosed with Reynaud's syndrome last winter, so having walls and space heaters on days when we load the kiln will save me from some nerve pain. It will also prevent everyone involved from being overly cold. Bonus!
  • Ted Neal came out to oversee the kiln build.  Having him assess the barn before we started the build was a fantastic decision. The week we built the kiln was a joy—Ted answers questions and teaches new skills with a patience and thoroughness much appreciated by myself and the crew of volunteers who came out to help!
  • The kiln room has been torn down and rebuilt, taller and safer. Lots of barn doors to open the room up when the kiln gets toasty.
  • There's a river. Although that's not important for wood firing, my son is obsessed with fishing. So it sold him on purchasing the property.
  • There are a few, super friendly outdoor cats! Not particularly pertinent to firing kilns, no matter how you feel about cats, this was the selling point for my daughter. 

What we're building

A kiln this size will be an asset in the Chicagoland area. It's 70 minutes from downtown. Maybe a *little* longer at rush hour on a Friday. This makes the site available to a lot of potters interested in wood firing! It will be the main site for several full-time potters to fire their work. There will be plenty of room for artists dabbling in wood fire as well. I also plan to host visiting artist workshops once per year to hand over the reins of the kiln, learn from others' expertise, and see what variation comes from the firings!

The art scene is taking hold beautifully in Downtown Aurora. Just down the river from the property, Aurora hosts First Fridays as well as numerous art fairs and other events ready for ceramics to hold a larger presence. 

At the barn, a small gallery will welcome drop-in visitors, and we will hold kiln unloading parties outdoors. 

What we need

We are in the final push for expenses leading up to the first firing this October. Still to come before we start the kindling...

Approximately $8,000 more for metal siding. The barn where the kiln lives currently has rotted wood siding, which is a safety issue. 

The kiln room needs to be lined with cement board to protect the framing--$5500.

$400 for bricks-- we need a slightly taller chimney!

$1500 for kiln shelves. Pottery is loaded onto special shelves that can withstand the high temperatures and environment of the wood kiln. They are surprisingly pricey when you purchase 30 of them.

$20,000 to purchase a tiny house for a business partner. Just kidding. Kind of. This would be our (incredible) stretch goal!

Lofty goals, I realize! If we fall short of our fundraising goals, the next steps of hosting workshops and framing out a studio will be delayed. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Not everyone is in a position to contribute-- we totally get it! There are other ways to participate in bringing the communal joy of wood firing to fruition!

Share the campaign on social media. Indiegogo makes it easy!

Mention it at your next art-nerdz get together.

Send positive thoughts/vibes/prayers over my way! 

A little background

I have been working in clay since my freshman year of high school. At Hope College, I graduated with a BA in Studio Art with an emphasis in Ceramics. I moved to Virginia for a teaching job (well, also to follow my high school sweetheart and now husband) and taught ceramics casually at night at our church.

After we had our two children, I was a full-time mom in Illinois, without a studio. As they entered preschool, I had heard from my high school teacher that Waubonsee Community College had a fantastic ceramics program. Having classes and open studio available away from the house was such a blessing. My hours were very casual through the preschool and kindergarten years and expanded as the kids’ school days grew longer. Six months into my time there, I participated in a wood firing for the first time*.  For five years, I continually took classes at the college—it’s a fantastic environment for exploration and learning. 

One year ago, I decided it was time to leave the comfort of the college setting and seriously consider the next step and settle on where to live and what type of kiln to build. We explored the idea of moving to North Carolina--my husband was looking for a new job at the same time I was dreaming of starting a business. In the heart of pottery country, we fell in love with properties that have a home, studio, and wood kiln all in one spot. 

We decided to stay in Illinois and keep our kids in their schools, and my husband started a great new job. Lots of time on Zillow and lots of research on zoning** found us a great spot to build a kiln (right away), a studio (as time and finances allow), and eventually a home.

At the same time we were exploring properties, I enjoyed firing with friends and experiencing how a catenary arch kiln fires, teamed up with others at a clay center to fire a gas/soda kiln, and appreciated firing a wood/salt/soda kiln and unloading its lovely results.

I kept coming back to the train kiln at Waubonsee. I loved loading it, understood firing it, and appreciate the rich and earthy surfaces deposited on the work. Sixty cubic feet of loading space would allow me to fire just several times per year-- a reasonable trade of lost sleep (the firings can range from 36 to 48 hours) for a good amount of pottery!

I had the opportunity to help build a kiln of that type and size at Simon Levin's pottery*** over the winter. It is great fun laying brick. It's also humbling! Weighing my experience against the project ahead, I decided to contact Ted Neal about overseeing my kiln build to make sure it was built solid, and to last. The week of the kiln built was amazing. We cast custom bricks from refractory material, cut endless bricks using the wet saw, and lay bricks meticulously, avoiding seams. Add to that the volunteers who came out in force to build the kiln, and it was by far the easiest and most satisfying part of the project****. 

Everything has moved along quickly. We purchased the land this spring, the kiln was built in July, and we are in the midst of working with contractors on making the barn safe for firings.

Many thanks to my mentors in the field, the amazing crew of volunteers who came together for the kiln build, and the potters who have answered my endless questions throughout this process!

*For those who know Waubonsee and wood firing artists, my second batch of clay I mixed up at the college had reclaim in it, and the reclaim was tainted with chunks of feldspar. Totally something that would only happen in a wood firing program! Almost every piece of mine had one or two shiny blemishes. I decided to participate in the anagama firing to “hide” the imperfections. All four of those pieces came out beautifully (that beats the odds by more than a little,) and I was smitten with the results! I think the only work I ever gas fired after that was test tiles!

**shout out to our realtor, Jason Sunderland! 

***I have a sneaking suspicion Simon's family moved from Wisconsin to Illinois at this moment, just for my benefit

**** Getting the bricks unloaded from the truck was by far the most exciting part of the project. Roy and Chuck hold a special place in my heart. Their troubleshooting, when the truck driver was ready to give up on unloading 18,000 lbs of bricks, saved the day!

story:
Masks in the Aftermath

The Project

 

Background
Like all segments of Virgin Islands society, practicing artists, arts and cultural organizations were impacted greatly by the 2017 hurricane season. As a part of the Virgin Islands’ recovery, the St. John Arts and Culture Long-Term Recovery Group (STJACRC) was formed under the fiduciary sponsorship of the Community Foundation of St. John and the St. John Angels in March 2018. STJACRC, which includes arts organizations such as The St. John School of the Arts, St.JanCo and the Gri Gri Project, initiated several outreach projects geared towards helping the arts & cultural community on St. John. 

One of these began in May of 2018: a community wide project, Mask Making as a Tool for Community Expression and Healing in the Aftermath of the 2017 Hurricane Season.  The project mirrored a variety of community public art and art therapy projects that have been successful in supporting the emotional and social recovery process after disasters. Thanks to the National Endowment for the Arts for inspiring us to do this project and their ongoing support.

                             

The project targeted students, senior citizens and other community members, schools and organizations on St. John. The goal was to reach as many residents, youths and organizations as possible. Participants were encouraged to imagine new identities, new selves, new ways of being in the storms’ aftermath.

       

         


Over 500 people participated in making masks that were then publicly displayed and viewed by thousands of residents and visitors. This process helped to build community and introduce an aesthetic to the recovery that suggests both newness and is rooted in cultural heritage.

        

                                            


Although the mask-making itself came to an end, the masks and their stories continued to share our experiences and efforts to heal and move forward. For example, students at the St. John School of the Arts incorporated the masks as part of their St. John 2018 Festival Troupe.

                   

                               


Many masks were also displayed at the Department of Interior’s Library in Washington D.C.  in the fall of 2018.

       


The masks and their stories were then documented in a 12-minute film directed by project team member Dr. Crystal Fortwangler and produced by St. John’s Arts and Cultural Long-Term Recovery Group Co-Chairs, Kurt G. Marsh, Jr. and Priscilla Hintz Rivera Knight. William Stelzer joined as part of the film team, filming the documentary, assisted by Crystal and St. John high school student Ameir Sprauve. (See film inset directly below).

       

 

 

Research has shown that community art projects and art therapy have been effective in carrying out creative community-building, which is essential in the disaster recovery process. This has been our collective experience on St. John after the hurricanes. Our experience has shown us that art programs help communities heal and recover.


Current Project & Indiegogo Campaign
Post-storms we want the masks and their stories to continue circulating! To help in this way the Virgin Islands Council on the Arts (VICA) committed to partially funding a book project that highlights over 100 masks made in the project. VICA awarded us $5,000 and we are seeking an additional $5000 as part of this Indiegogo Campaign to bring this beautiful book to the public. Sales from the book will support a newly created St. John Arts & Cultural Emergency Fund. The fund is being established by the Arts & Culture Recovery Committee of St. John (ACRC) with the fiduciary support of the Community Foundation of St. John. Once established, the fund will help support arts & cultural practitioners and organizations during times of disaster or an unforeseeable economic need. Our goal is to provide meaningful and timely relief and recovery assistance.

We also found a way to link the mask-making art-therapy project to a broader goal. While making the short film about the mask-making project, we became additionally cognizant of the critical need for improved access to mental health. There is an extraordinary need for greater mental health support in our islands, and even more so in the aftermath of disasters. A few months ago, in March 2019, VI Gov. Albert Bryan Jr. declared a mental healthcare emergency in the U.S. Virgin Islands because of a  shortage of psychiatric physicians and behavioral health providers. We believe producing a feature length documentary film can help make the case for professional art-therapy programs in the USVI. Through the film we want to demonstrate the success of this project (plus another VI art-based therapeutic program) and additionally promote professional art-therapy and mental health programs in the USVI. We will interview mental health care providers in the USVI, art-therapy professionals with the American Art Therapy Association, and include more interviews with people involved in the mask-making project.

The film will also be valuable for communities across the Caribbean who also face the need to heal and recover post-hurricanes, but also communities around the world who face all types of disasters.

 

What We Need & What You Get

Your contribution is greatly appreciated! Monies received will be used in the ways listed below.

Book Funding
1. We will spend $5000 to print a bulk order of Masks in the Aftermath to ensure a great price. We will then sell these books and 100% of the sale price will go to the St. John Arts & Cultural Emergency Fund (described above). 

Documentary Film Funding
1. Filming more interviews! We need $3000 to conduct 5 more key interviews for the film. Three interviews are on St. John, one on St. Thomas or St. Croix, and one stateside. The interviews on St. John are with (1) a high school student who made the mask that appeared on the cover of the recent NEA Arts Magazine (National Endowment for the Arts, 2019),  (2) a teacher who gave workshop for children at Julius Sprauve School, and (3) a St. Johnian artist who has provided an art-therapy oriented program previously in the USVI. The interview on St. Thomas or St. Croix will be with a mental health care provider who can speak to the need for art-therapy oriented support programs in the USVI. The interview stateside will be with a leading scholar in the art-therapy profession. Money will also be spent on travel & accommodation expenses to St. Thomas/St. Croix and stateside, and paying our camera operator to work with our Director to film the interviews (in USVI).

2. Sponsoring and Filming an Art-Therapy Information Workshop in USVI! We need $2500 to sponsor this workshop open to the public, and conduct two additional interviews with the practicing art-therapists who travel to USVI to present a informational workshop about the practice of art-therapy. The interviews and material from the workshop will be included in the film. Money will be spent on travel & accommodations for the two art-therapists to get to USVI.

3. Making Music! $6000 is needed to hire musician and composer Victor Provost and a team working with him to create an original soundtrack for the film. A professional audio mix moves a film from good to amazing. This is one of the most expensive aspects of film (thankfully we have supportive musicians giving us a great price).

4. Editing & Graphics! Editing & graphic design is an expensive part of film production as it takes a considerable amount of time. We need $6500 to cover the final editing and graphics for the film. This rate is discounted as we are donating much of our time to finish the film.

General Funding
1. Rewards! It costs money to create the perks. We estimate we will need $1000 to cover these costs (any perks created and not sold as part of this campaign will be sold at Bajo El Sol Gallery and 100% of sales will be donated to the St. John Arts & Cultural Emergency Fund).

2. Paying Indiegogo! Without IndieGogo we wouldn't be able to run this campaign and connect with you! We need an additional $960 to cover these costs (that is 4% of our goal of $24,000).

Funding Goal
The total amount we need then is $24,960. Rounding up just a small amount for convenience - our funding goal is $25,000. Please help us reach the goal!
 

Our Team

Priscilla Hintz Rivera Knight
Film/Book Producer & Co-Chair St. John’s Arts and Cultural Long-Term Recovery Group 
Priscilla Hintz Rivera Knight is an independent curator and arts advocate. She recently co-founded the Gri Gri Project with writer and photographer David Knight Jr.

The Gri Gri Project’s mission is the creation of interpretive exhibitions, critical writing, events and archives related to the cultural patrimony of the U.S. Virgin Islands and the Caribbean region. The Gri Gri Project has been involved in arts-related projects and exhibitions in the Virgin Islands, Denmark, Puerto Rico, the United States, Aruba, Barbados and Cuba.

Priscilla holds a master’s Degree in arts administration from Goucher College  and a BA in Social Sciences with a concentration in Caribbean studies from the University of the Virgin Islands.

She has worked for and collaborated with such organizations as the Smithsonian Institution in Washington D.C., the Turabo University Art Museum and Center for Humanistic Studies in Puerto Rico, The St. Thomas Historical Trust, El Museo de Arte de Puerto Rico, Casa de las Américas, in Cuba and was co-founder of Artfusion Magazine.  She is currently the Director of the Bajo El Sol Gallery on St. John.
 

Kurt G. Marsh Jr.
Film/Book Producer & Co-Chair St. John’s Arts and Cultural Long-Term Recovery Group 
Kurt G. Marsh, Jr, is a professional woodworker, architectural designer, and social activist. He obtained his Bachelor of Fine arts, and Professional Masters in Architecture from the Savannah College of Art & Design. Kurt’s thesis, “So We Live: Within space, Without place”, sought to critique socio-cultural constructs regarding identity & culture in a ‘post-colonial’ St. John, US Virgin Islands. This exercise stimulates dialogue regarding cultural resistance and adaptation, through built form and place-making, whereas architecture becomes a catalyst for creative cultural reproduction. His design pursuits are now paralleled with ideas of political activism and outreach, and often challenges the ancestral natives’ ideas about positionality and notions of ownership & space as an American possession. Kurt maintains membership in the AIA, NOMAS, and ASHRAE, serves with several nonprofits, and is the Vice President of “St.JanCo: The St. John Heritage Collective”.


Dr. Crystal Fortwangler
Film Director & Editor                                                     
Crystal Fortwangler is a filmmaker and is director of the film program at LaRoche University. She dove into film after spending over a decade in the academic world of anthropology and environmental studies. She started a film company, Wider Angle Productions, in 2014 to transition from an academic world into an artistic one. She recently joined LaRoche University as a faculty member coordinating the film program. She has also been teaching film at Tzohar Seminary for five years, and this coming summer will teach documentary filmmaking at Pittsburgh Center for Arts and Media. She has spent over 20 years working on scholarly and artistic projects in the US Virgin Islands with VI-based colleagues. She taught summer film workshops twice at Gifft Hill School on St. John, working with a number of students to create short films about their hurricane experiences.

Crystal has produced two documentary films prior to directing  and editing Masks in the Aftermath. Her first documentary film, It Ain’t Easy Being Green (35 min.), is an exploration of human perspectives on green iguanas and agriculture in the US Virgin Islands. The film was accepted at 8 festivals and was awarded Best Documentary, at the Palm Bay Caribe Film Festival (2018) and Best Short, at the Caribbean Lens International Film Festival (2018). It is distributed by Green Planet Films and has been well-received at colleges and universities. She and her co-producer Jessica Bellas raised over $11,000 on kickstarter to help fund the film.

Her second film, Our Island, Our Home (33 min.), documents the activism and insights of a well-known historical figure in the US Virgin Islands, Senator Theovald Moorehead (1916-1995), to remind young Virgin Islanders to dream, be brave, and stay the course as they struggle today to manage the luxury tourism development of their home island, St. John. The structure of the documentary is oriented towards community education and engagement. Crystal collaborated with long-time friend and colleague, Ms. Theodora Moorehead (daughter of Senator Moorehead), who produced the film.

She directed and edited the short documentary about the mask-making art-therapy project, working closely with Bill Stelzer on camera and graphic design.

 

William (Bill) Stelzer
Film Cinematographer & Graphic Designer                                        
William Stelzer is a freelance artist, photographer and filmmaker who specializes in the arts, sciences, education and humanitarian causes. He has lived in St. John since 1992 and has worked with numerous organizations in the Virgin Islands and the US, including AT&T, USVI Department of Health, USVI Tourism, St. John Sun Times, St. John School of the Arts, Dancing Classrooms USVI, NOAA, NPS, Friends of Virgin Islands National Park and HaitiChildren. Prior to living in St. John he worked as Graphics Director for ABC-TV’s affiliate in Central Texas during the First Gulf War. He was also part of a research expedition into the Venezuelan Amazon to study burial cave artwork and has taught computer graphics in West Africa as part of an AIDS project. He helped set up pilot programs and shot a series of mini documentaries in Haiti, Nicaragua and St. John as part of the one laptop per child project. In addition, he has exhibited is artwork throughout the Virgin Islands, Puerto Rico and the USA. William has worked with Crystal to film the short doc film about the mask project (see link above), and contributed to this current project by creating the designs for the Masks in the Aftermath poster and notecards.


Kamaria Penn
Book Graphic Designer
Kamaria Penn is a freelance graphic designer and artist from St. John providing creative services and consultation to several local business, schools, and nonprofit organizations throughout the U.S. Virgin Islands and United States.

Kamaria is a graduate of the Ringling College of Art and Design with a B.F.A. in Graphic and Interactive Communication and a minor in the Business of Art and Design. She currently works as an office manager at Hybrid Services, LLC. Before starting freelance work, Kamaria worked two years as a part-time computer teacher at the Julius E. Sprauve School's 21st Century Program and full-time community liaison for the Office of Senator Tregenza A. Roach in the Legislature of the Virgin Islands.


Victor Provost
Musician & Composer for Film's Soundtrack
Victor Provost is widely regarded as one of the world’s leading voices on the unique, and often misunderstood, steel pan (or steel drum). Through appearances at concert halls, clubs, and stages throughout the world, he has been meticulously developing a reputation as a “dazzling” soloist, crafting an impressive improvisational voice and style. With a strong foundation in Bebop, a contemporary sensibility, and deep roots in Caribbean music, he seamlessly melds and mixes genres. The Washington D.C. City Paper’s “Jazz Percussionist of the Year” six years running, his new recording Bright Eyes debuted at #5 on the iTunes Top 40 Jazz Charts.

In addition to leading his own group, Victor tours with NEA Jazz Master, Paquito D’Rivera, is a member of the GRAMMY award-winning Afro Bop Alliance, and works with several of the Mid-Atlantic region’s most lauded musical collectives.  Already in his relatively young career, he has performed and recorded with Jazz luminaries such as Wynton Marsalis, Hugh Masakela, Joe Locke, Nicholas Payton, Terell Stafford, Dave Samuels, Steve Nelson, Ron Blake, and Wycliffe Gordon, among others.

Victor is an Adjunct Professor of Music at George Mason University and conducts residencies and master classes throughout the United States and the Caribbean. He is also an Arts Ambassador to his hometown of the U.S. Virgin Islands, which honored him with a Special Congressional Recognition in 2014, and to which returns frequently to perform and teach as part of Dion Parson’s community-based arts initiative, the United Jazz Foundation. Victor attended school on St. John  spent much of his time at the St. John School of the Arts where he was a member of the renowned Steel Unlimited II steel orchestra.

Lauryn Sinclaire Samuel
Sequential Artist
Lauryn Sinclaire Samuel is currently a student at Savannah College of Art and Design (SCAD) Atlanta. She studies sequential art and creates illustrations on the side. Lauryn is an emerging artist from St. John and will be spending this summer on island preparing five illustrations of island residents wearing masks to be used in the film's credits. The images are not of any specific person but generalized and representative images of those who participated in the workshops. The images will then made into notecards and sold at Bajo El Sol Gallery. All proceeds from the sale of these cards will be donated to the St. John Arts & Cultural Emergency Fund.


Fiduciary Organization:

The St. John Community Foundation/ The St. John Angels Network:
The St. John Community Foundation (SJCF) has successfully been carrying out the mission of providing services and supporting programs that positively engage people, build resources and strengthen the St. John community since 1989.  The St. John Angels Network is a SJCF initiative which is comprised of several Long-Term Recovery groups.  There mission is to unite disaster recovery resources with community needs to ensure that even the most vulnerable community members recover from the recent hurricanes while establishing systems for resiliency and preparedness for all-hazard events. 

St. John’s Arts and Cultural Long-Term Recovery Group’s mission is to create synergy and encourage activities among community, arts, and cultural groups and entities on St. John and connect them to resources and opportunities.
story_txt:
Masks in the Aftermath
The Project
 
BackgroundLike all segments of Virgin Islands society, practicing artists, arts and cultural organizations were impacted greatly by the 2017 hurricane season. As a part of the Virgin Islands’ recovery, the St. John Arts and Culture Long-Term Recovery Group (STJACRC) was formed under the fiduciary sponsorship of the Community Foundation of St. John and the St. John Angels in March 2018. STJACRC, which includes arts organizations such as The St. John School of the Arts, St.JanCo and the Gri Gri Project, initiated several outreach projects geared towards helping the arts & cultural community on St. John. 
One of these began in May of 2018: a community wide project, Mask Making as a Tool for Community Expression and Healing in the Aftermath of the 2017 Hurricane Season.  The project mirrored a variety of community public art and art therapy projects that have been successful in supporting the emotional and social recovery process after disasters. Thanks to the National Endowment for the Arts for inspiring us to do this project and their ongoing support.                              
The project targeted students, senior citizens and other community members, schools and organizations on St. John. The goal was to reach as many residents, youths and organizations as possible. Participants were encouraged to imagine new identities, new selves, new ways of being in the storms’ aftermath.
        
          
Over 500 people participated in making masks that were then publicly displayed and viewed by thousands of residents and visitors. This process helped to build community and introduce an aesthetic to the recovery that suggests both newness and is rooted in cultural heritage.
        
                                             
Although the mask-making itself came to an end, the masks and their stories continued to share our experiences and efforts to heal and move forward. For example, students at the St. John School of the Arts incorporated the masks as part of their St. John 2018 Festival Troupe.
                                                    
Many masks were also displayed at the Department of Interior’s Library in Washington D.C.  in the fall of 2018.
         
The masks and their stories were then documented in a 12-minute film directed by project team member Dr. Crystal Fortwangler and produced by St. John’s Arts and Cultural Long-Term Recovery Group Co-Chairs, Kurt G. Marsh, Jr. and Priscilla Hintz Rivera Knight. William Stelzer joined as part of the film team, filming the documentary, assisted by Crystal and St. John high school student Ameir Sprauve. (See film inset directly below).
        
 Research has shown that community art projects and art therapy have been effective in carrying out creative community-building, which is essential in the disaster recovery process. This has been our collective experience on St. John after the hurricanes. Our experience has shown us that art programs help communities heal and recover.Current Project & Indiegogo CampaignPost-storms we want the masks and their stories to continue circulating! To help in this way the Virgin Islands Council on the Arts (VICA) committed to partially funding a book project that highlights over 100 masks made in the project. VICA awarded us $5,000 and we are seeking an additional $5000 as part of this Indiegogo Campaign to bring this beautiful book to the public. Sales from the book will support a newly created St. John Arts & Cultural Emergency Fund. The fund is being established by the Arts & Culture Recovery Committee of St. John (ACRC) with the fiduciary support of the Community Foundation of St. John. Once established, the fund will help support arts & cultural practitioners and organizations during times of disaster or an unforeseeable economic need. Our goal is to provide meaningful and timely relief and recovery assistance.We also found a way to link the mask-making art-therapy project to a broader goal. While making the short film about the mask-making project, we became additionally cognizant of the critical need for improved access to mental health. There is an extraordinary need for greater mental health support in our islands, and even more so in the aftermath of disasters. A few months ago, in March 2019, VI Gov. Albert Bryan Jr. declared a mental healthcare emergency in the U.S. Virgin Islands because of a  shortage of psychiatric physicians and behavioral health providers. We believe producing a feature length documentary film can help make the case for professional art-therapy programs in the USVI. Through the film we want to demonstrate the success of this project (plus another VI art-based therapeutic program) and additionally promote professional art-therapy and mental health programs in the USVI. We will interview mental health care providers in the USVI, art-therapy professionals with the American Art Therapy Association, and include more interviews with people involved in the mask-making project.The film will also be valuable for communities across the Caribbean who also face the need to heal and recover post-hurricanes, but also communities around the world who face all types of disasters. 
What We Need & What You Get
Your contribution is greatly appreciated! Monies received will be used in the ways listed below.
Book Funding1. We will spend $5000 to print a bulk order of Masks in the Aftermath to ensure a great price. We will then sell these books and 100% of the sale price will go to the St. John Arts & Cultural Emergency Fund (described above).  Documentary Film Funding1. Filming more interviews! We need $3000 to conduct 5 more key interviews for the film. Three interviews are on St. John, one on St. Thomas or St. Croix, and one stateside. The interviews on St. John are with (1) a high school student who made the mask that appeared on the cover of the recent NEA Arts Magazine (National Endowment for the Arts, 2019),  (2) a teacher who gave workshop for children at Julius Sprauve School, and (3) a St. Johnian artist who has provided an art-therapy oriented program previously in the USVI. The interview on St. Thomas or St. Croix will be with a mental health care provider who can speak to the need for art-therapy oriented support programs in the USVI. The interview stateside will be with a leading scholar in the art-therapy profession. Money will also be spent on travel & accommodation expenses to St. Thomas/St. Croix and stateside, and paying our camera operator to work with our Director to film the interviews (in USVI).
2. Sponsoring and Filming an Art-Therapy Information Workshop in USVI! We need $2500 to sponsor this workshop open to the public, and conduct two additional interviews with the practicing art-therapists who travel to USVI to present a informational workshop about the practice of art-therapy. The interviews and material from the workshop will be included in the film. Money will be spent on travel & accommodations for the two art-therapists to get to USVI.
3. Making Music! $6000 is needed to hire musician and composer Victor Provost and a team working with him to create an original soundtrack for the film. A professional audio mix moves a film from good to amazing. This is one of the most expensive aspects of film (thankfully we have supportive musicians giving us a great price).
4. Editing & Graphics! Editing & graphic design is an expensive part of film production as it takes a considerable amount of time. We need $6500 to cover the final editing and graphics for the film. This rate is discounted as we are donating much of our time to finish the film.General Funding 1. Rewards! It costs money to create the perks. We estimate we will need $1000 to cover these costs (any perks created and not sold as part of this campaign will be sold at Bajo El Sol Gallery and 100% of sales will be donated to the St. John Arts & Cultural Emergency Fund).
2. Paying Indiegogo! Without IndieGogo we wouldn't be able to run this campaign and connect with you! We need an additional $960 to cover these costs (that is 4% of our goal of $24,000).Funding GoalThe total amount we need then is $24,960. Rounding up just a small amount for convenience - our funding goal is $25,000. Please help us reach the goal!

story:
The Story of Two Medicine Silver

Hello! My name is Kara, the maker behind Two Medicine Silver. I am a self-taught silversmith, writer, and mother  working and living near the beautiful Rocky Mountains of Montana. I starting silversmithing full-time almost one year ago, after months of  building up my tool and knowledge repertoire completely on my own. Throughout this last year, I have grown and learned so much as an artist and entrepreneur, but now it’s time to take a huge step. 

I have run out of room. My studio, aka the back room/storage room/freezer room/entryway, has started to limit my ability to create and grow. I have made the most out of every inch, but the space has reached it’s maximum capacity. 

 That’s where the dream arose.  

An external studio: built by our own hands from logs gathered and milled by my husband and I, powered by solar energy, made with reclaimed materials, and enough square footage  to create  and share that power of creation with the community! 

This studio build is something that will be the future of my business. It will allow me the space to grow my skills and offer higher-quality, more diverse silver jewelry to my customers. Beyond that, the  more I am able to grow, the more I am able to share. I believe in the power of art and of creativity. With this space, I hope to offer community classes to teach other the art of silversmithing. 

 

Here’s the Plan

There’s an “aim for the moon, and hope you land among the stars” sort of situation going on here— I am aiming high for funding, but it’s very important to me to remain as economical as possible while still building a beautiful, creative space. 

The majority of the funding will go towards the building itself. We plan to log and mill the wood we will use, and utilize our local ReStore for doors, windows, and any other necessary bits and pieces we can find. I want to limit the consumption of new building materials as much as is possible. Reduce, reuse, recycle is the name of the game. 

The next step will be adding a sustainable energy and heating  source. Once the building is completed, funding will go toward solar power installation.

If by chance I am lucky to have enough left over, all remaining funds will go towards upgrading my safety systems (fume and particulate extraction) and  growing my tool arsenal.  Things such as adding casting equipment and a rolling mill to eliminate my silver waste, purchasing more advanced shaping and cutting tools, and adding multiples of the basic to be able to offer classes to the community will be where any remaining funds will be spent. 

 

The Impact

My biggest hope is for this to impact my community.  Augusta is a small, rurual town and I would love to offer another opportunity for space of creation for the residents here. Augusta also relies quite heavily on tourism in the summer, so to add another viable stop that could produce more revenue in our town would be fantastic. 

Beyond that, the  impact building this studio would have on my success in growing this business and creating life-long pieces of quality silver  jewelry is immeasurable. Having space to house all the tools necessary to create  pieces of work that are of heirloom-quality— something that will last a family for generations— is the goal. Having a space to be successful and a female, a mother, and an entrepreneur is the goal. 

Of Course this Won’t be Easy...

Nothing about creating this business has been. Between balancing work and family, squeezing every bit budget as far as it can go, learning an art form from scratch, and becoming an entrepreneur with no real educational background in business theory or marketing, I think it’s safe to say hard work doesn’t scare me.

And nothing about building this studio will be easy work. But it’s important work. To create a sustainable business space with community  ties is something I must do. Whether it takes me a few months or a few years to raise enough, save enough, and learn enough, I will never stop working for it. 

Other Ways You Can Help

 Even if it’s just a dollar or two, any little bit helps, but I am the first to understand contributing money is not always an option. 

If you are unable to contribute in that way, SHARING can be just as important and just as appreciated!

Beyond that, the  impact building this studio would have on my success in growing this business and creating life-long pieces of quality silver  jewelry is immeasurable. Having space to house all the tools necessary to create  pieces of work that are of heirloom-quality— something that will last a family for generations— is the goal. Having a space to be successful and a female, a mother, and an entrepreneur is the goal. 

Of Course this Won’t be Easy...
Nothing about creating this business has been. Between balancing work and family, squeezing every bit budget as far as it can go, learning an art form from scratch, and becoming an entrepreneur with no real educational background in business theory or marketing, I think it’s safe to say hard work doesn’t scare me.
And nothing about building this studio will be easy work. But it’s important work. To create a sustainable business space with community  ties is something I must do. Whether it takes me a few months or a few years to raise enough, save enough, and learn enough, I will never stop working for it. 

Other Ways You Can Help
 Even if it’s just a dollar or two, any little bit helps, but I am the first to understand contributing money is not always an option. 
If you are unable to contribute in that way, SHARING can be just as important and just as appreciated!

story:
Hey there!

  • I'm John Hilmes, designer of Osmos. During last year's maiden playa voyage, we learned a lot about how Osmos performs in high winds and how folks like to use the space in the desert. The 21' tall pavilion proved a relaxing place to meditate, do yoga, stare up at the cosmos, hang with friends, take a nap, and "get the led out". Now we're building on the successes of last year by adding a soft, custom inflatable floor, turning Osmos into a bounce house with many uses on playa and beyond.
  • For 2019, we're looking to raise $6800 to cover the fabrication of a set of two, heavy-duty, drop-stitch inflatables. 

The design is composed of two parts.

  • The outer ring is 23' in diameter and 20cm thick, and fits snugly inside the base of Osmos itself. The 7'-8" width of the outer ring  is more than enough space for an individual to lay down and stretch out. After it leaves the Burn, it will make for an excellent floating dance floor or yoga platform for aquatic gatherings (see you soon Ephemerisle and Priceless?)
  • The 7'-8" diameter center disc fits perfectly into the center of the outer ring to complete a solid, 23' diameter surface. On land, the center disc can be removed to create space for a performer with AV equipment, or a conversation/pillow pit. The center disc can also be placed on top of the outer ring to make an elevated platform / impromptu stage for an instructor or performer.
  • Seven D-rings will be stitched evenly along the perimeter of both shapes, securing them to each other and the main structure. Both shapes can securely be bolted into the playa outside of the structure, serving as camp lounge furniture as the day's programming requires.
  • This project brought together not only our camp, but ALL citizens of Black Rock City, as Osmos was positioned on the corner of our lot, and served as an excellent landmark for sunrise bike rides home, while providing a peaceful and shady oasis for those looking to just chill out.
  • If you can't donate, PLEASE share this campaign with those who might be interested in supporting us...and don't forget to use the Indiegogo share tools! Thx!
story_txt:
Hey there!
I'm John Hilmes, designer of Osmos. During last year's maiden playa voyage, we learned a lot about how Osmos performs in high winds and how folks like to use the space in the desert. The 21' tall pavilion proved a relaxing place to meditate, do yoga, stare up at the cosmos, hang with friends, take a nap, and "get the led out". Now we're building on the successes of last year by adding a soft, custom inflatable floor, turning Osmos into a bounce house with many uses on playa and beyond.

For 2019, we're looking to raise $6800 to cover the fabrication of a set of two, heavy-duty, drop-stitch inflatables. 
The design is composed of two parts.

The outer ring is 23' in diameter and 20cm thick, and fits snugly inside the base of Osmos itself. The 7'-8" width of the outer ring  is more than enough space for an individual to lay down and stretch out. After it leaves the Burn, it will make for an excellent floating dance floor or yoga platform for aquatic gatherings (see you soon Ephemerisle and Priceless?)
The 7'-8" diameter center disc fits perfectly into the center of the outer ring to complete a solid, 23' diameter surface. On land, the center disc can be removed to create space for a performer with AV equipment, or a conversation/pillow pit. The center disc can also be placed on top of the outer ring to make an elevated platform / impromptu stage for an instructor or performer.
Seven D-rings will be stitched evenly along the perimeter of both shapes, securing them to each other and the main structure. Both shapes can securely be bolted into the playa outside of the structure, serving as camp lounge furniture as the day's programming requires.
This project brought together not only our camp, but ALL citizens of Black Rock City, as Osmos was positioned on the corner of our lot, and served as an excellent landmark for sunrise bike rides home, while providing a peaceful and shady oasis for those looking to just chill out.
If you can't donate, PLEASE share this campaign with those who might be interested in supporting us...and don't forget to use the Indiegogo share tools! Thx!

story:
I built an art installation at Burning Man 2019 called "WE. the people" and now it is time to spread the story into the world. 

On March 5th, 2020 my tour departed Reno for a 7-week journey.  This adventure will include art, beauty, and play to return voice to America.

Eleven Humanoid life-sized canvases are engaging with people and places across the country. Each holds a theme painted on its chest. People gather and contribute to create beautiful, dynamic graffiti-like stories that are shaping our world.

Six Humanoids: FORGIVE, AWE, SAFE, FREE, INCLUSION, and the D"INNER CHILD"REN are the escorts for 5 that will begin as blank. These new Humanoids are MONEY, POWER, RACE, RELIGION, and GENDER.

Now more than ever we need to feel beautiful, safe, and believe in ourselves.  We need to courageously use our voices to connect and create positive change.  We need to have fun, make things, and play. 

Art is a universal language, the Humanoids are our translators. With pen in hand, we collaborate and innovate with empathy and compassion as foundations for future design.

The Humanoids will speak for us in front of The White House, picnic on the lawn in front of the Washington Monument, and stand with Martin Luther King at his memorial.  We will vote on such things like who marries who at Niagara Falls.  They are the Art of Us, let's make a ruckus. 

Participate in The Tour

The Humanoids are on a human adventure and are asking for your support.  

You can join in several ways.  I am raising 27K to ensure that we fulfill the goals of the Tour -11  Humanoids, 2 humans traveling 7,000 miles over 7 weeks in an RV. 

  • RV expense and maintenance
  • Gas 
  • Food
  • Art materials and fabrication
  • Technology
  • Printing

Any and all support is gratefully received and appreciated, there is no limit to what we will create together!

story:
Short Summary

As part of the main Granton on Sea project we are looking to place 2 shipping containers on the site of our future LIDO. These will form a cafe and drop-in centre where the project can be explained to the public and what are the community benefits that will come with the project.

WHO IS BEHIND THE PROJECT

Following new discussions with BIG Lottery Growing Community Assets fund it was agreed that the existing partnership would form a   new local society and so The Granton Improvement Society was formed. The Granton Improvement Society with a strong   community membership and management committee of Trustees,   Vice-chair and secretary both being local residents in the area are   the   main driving force, currently a membership of almost 100 of both local residents and Interested person from within Edinburgh   and much   further afield. A full spectrum of professional advisers are working with the society to achieve the hugely   ambitious proposals. The   society is currently awaiting charity status.

PROJECT DESCRIPTIONS

  THE INTERNATIONAL GARDEN FESTIVAL

The Granton Walled Garden site provides the setting for a world-renowned garden festival showcasing artist and gardener/horticulturalist and designers from all disciplines to form collaborations collaborations. A similar festival held on council land has been successfully running in Chaumont-sur-Loire in France for 18 years, attracting up to150,000 visitors http://www.domaine-chaumont.fr/en_general_accueil

  The Festival’s five core objectives are:

·  The restoration, preservation and conservation of Granton’s historic site

·  The exhibition and promotion of cutting-edge design for outdoor spaces to contribute on a local, national and international level to greater awareness of   the art of the garden

·  To strengthen Granton’s economy by creating a high public profile event that attracts visitors from a wide catchment area and represent value-for-money

·  Community empowerment and ownership of major asset with it being open to local residents all year round

·  Education, training and full-time and part-time jobs for local residents.

 

  THE ARTISANS VILLAGE

  On the hillside overlooking the Firth of Forth, the project will build a “village” of sea containers converted with toilets, sinks and french   windows to provide up to 100 workspaces for artists and artisans- a new creative community. The containers will be insulated   internally   and, on their roofs, turf will enhance their thermal performance and the landscape in which they are set.

  Photovoltaic panels and one or two wind turbines will provide energy for the whole development.

  THE LIDO

  On the waterfront, on land currently used for fly tipping, the project will create the Granton Lido, with a pool, changing rooms, and   café/bar restaurant made from sea containers. By heating the water through the use of a heat exchanger in the Firth of Forth, energy   costs will be minimised. The scheme would seek to install an insulated textile cover to the pool to allow for year round use.

What We Need & What You Get

We need £10,000 to buy and convert the 2 shipping containers for a 5 year period. The money will enable a training exercise to take place that will help in the future of the conversion of the 100 artisan spaces.

Funders will be able to come and use the small facility wholly free and in the future get a concessionary entry to the future Garden Festival, Lido.

Should we not reach our target for this project the funds raised will go to the society to continue to convince the City of Edinburgh of the merits of this "giving" project and to allow us to purchase the land required.


The Impact

This larger project will bring upto 150 full and part time jobs to an area of Edinburgh that has one of the highest rates of family deprivation in Scotland. It will bring approximately 150,000 visitors over the year to the Garden Festival and that will contribute enormously to the local economy and create more jobs outside of the project.

This is a project that only gives and after its initial funding will provide £400-500K every year for good causes in the North Edinburgh area.


Risks & Challenges

The small shipping container project depends upon a temporary planning permission being granted.

We have excellent architects involved and we do not envisage a problem with this risk.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are unable to contribute financially we would ask that you share this campaign as far and wide as possible. Use the Indiegogo share tools.

We also need the membership of the Granton Improvement Society to be increased and you can become a member at, https://grantonimprovementsociety.wordpress.com/

story:
Asexual Outreach is in a position to spearhead the ace movement and you can join us on our journey. Spreading awareness and education is not a simple task, so with your help, we can go further faster and achieve our goals. From the North American Asexuality Conference to resource kits in schools and beyond can all be made possible with the support of people like you! Join the effort and help make ace history!




Prior to the recent onset of the asexual movement, almost all aces lived their entire lives feeling broken, alone, and unsure of where they fit in the world. Since David Jay started the ace movement in 2001, we have seen a strong community develop out of this 1% of the population that has finally discovered that many others are like them. The movement has since grown to a point where more than 100,000 people have joined various online platforms, yet when estimates show that there are more than 5 million aces in North America alone, there is clearly work still to be done.


Today, both mainstream society and LGBTQ+ spaces still widely erase, ignore, and discriminate against ace identities, leaving many aces feeling isolated and ostracized. This is where Asexual Outreach comes in!

As the first and only national registered ace non-profit organization in the world, we plan to provide essential services to the ace community and to our allies. Founded in 2014 after two of our directors were instrumental in the hosting of an international asexuality conference for about 250 attendees, Asexual Outreach has quickly grown to become Canada’s leading ace organization, and an internationally recognized support and advocacy group. Given these accomplishments, we are uniquely suited to spearhead the next major growth of the ace movement, and we certainly have the resources to do so. With both an extensive network of contacts and a dedicated, innovative team, we have built the infrastructure needed to succeed, and are ready to do so.





Since Asexual Outreach is an organization staffed 100% by volunteers, the entirety of your contribution goes toward ace efforts and projects. We've got plenty of ideas and plans in the works to substantially benefit the ace community, including our annual North American Asexuality Conference, our high school outreach programs, our online intersectional community engagements, our comprehensive community event finder, an activist network as well as collaborative projects such as a book of works by ace authors.  


Given our flexible conference ticket fee, we are not entirely sure how many funds will be raised through tickets, and so we may need to spend less of our campaign funds than expected on conference items; however, given our estimates, the first $10,000 - or our campaign goal - will be spent as follows:



At least 90% of all stretch goal funds will go directly toward each goal's indicated program.





By supporting our campaign, you are directly contributing to the betterment of aces across North America. Not only are your donations directly supporting our nearby projects, you’re helping us to create a large funding base which we will be able to grow and draw from for years to come.




We want to reciprocate the generosity you're showing to us, so we've created some fabulous perks to reward your kindness!





Our base $10,000 goal will allow us to ensure the success of the North American Asexuality Conference, will allow us financial stability for the next year, and will allow us to develop our high school resource kits, event finder, our weekly ace intersectionality articles and community engagements, and our formal activist network. With every stretch goal past that, however, we will be either expanding on one of our existing programs, or introducing an entirely new program to further the movement.






We have reached a point in our organizational process where we can absolutely guarantee our North American Asexuality Conference will occur in 2015. In addition, we are entirely confident that we will be able to fully develop all of our online resources and programs. However, should we fail to reach our funding goals, we may not have the financial means to adequately develop and distribute our high school resource kits and other informational materials, which would inhibit the potential growth of the ace movement.





Even if you don’t have the financial means to support our campaign, chances are, you know someone who does. Because the ace movement is still not at the forefront of discussion, we rely on our supporters sharing and spreading the word about our campaigns and projects. Even if you just share our campaign on Facebook, Twitter, or Tumblr, you’re still making an enormous impact, and for that we are incredibly grateful.




Q: What will the High School Resource Kits include?

A: Our resource kits will include a comprehensive, spiral bound book containing guides on how to make an LGBTQ+ club safe and inclusive for aces, and how to make schools and classrooms inclusive spaces. Additionally, this book will outline ace awareness activities and events that LGBTQ+ clubs can host, and ways to engage the school community in discussions around the ace spectrum. The book will feature distinct sections for student club leaders, for teachers, for guidance counsellors, and for administrators.

Additionally, these resource kits will include a large number of our Ace 101, Issues Aces Face, and Ace Intersectionality leaflets that can be distributed to students. Other materials such as an ace-positive poster may also be included.

We will be spending about $20 on the printing and shipping of each booklet so that we can ensure schools have ample resources needed to make ace-inclusive spaces.


Q: Where can I register for the North American Asexuality Conference?

A: You can find more information about and register for the North American Asexuality Conference, hosted in Toronto on June 20 and 21, on our website at http://asexualoutreach.org/2015/06/20/2015-north-american-asexuality-conference/.


Q: How will the event finder work?

A: There will be an interactive map on the “Find an Event” page on our website, where upcoming events will be pinned. These pins will have information on each event’s date and time, description, hosting group, etc. Through this application, you will be able to sort by location, by event type, and by date to discover local meetups, workshops, conferences, and other ace activities. We are currently in discussions with many different local community groups across North America to ensure that they will be able to easily list their events, and so that our event finder works for the community as best as it can.


Q: How will you be engaging with the community in an intersectional way?

A: Starting on June 20th, Asexual Outreach will be posting weekly articles around intersectionality and the ace spectrum on its website. We will be hosting discussions around each of these articles and their topics, and will be encouraging ace activists and others who are interested in social justice to join us in these discussions. Because there is not really a place yet for the community to come together and have these essential discussions around including all marginalized identities in our community and activism, these articles and discussions will help to fill that void.


Q: What payment methods do you accept?

A: This campaign accepts PayPal and all major credit cards.


Q: How can my company/corporation sponsor Asexual Outreach and/or its events?

A: To find out more information about sponsoring Asexual Outreach and its conferences and events, please contact Brian Langevin (brian@asexualoutreach.org).


Q: Who can I contact with media requests?

A: If you are interested in featuring Asexual Outreach or this campaign on your media/news outlet, or are looking to interview one of Asexual Outreach’s directors, you can contact us through our Media and Press contact form on our website: http://asexualoutreach.org/contact-us/media-press/.
