The video above was created by Maria one of my DT Members. It shows you how to you can use the stamps.

story:
It's true, Rock Paper Scissors Collective (RPSC) has been the anchor of the uptown art community on 23rd and Telegraph for over 10 years-- providing opportunities for emerging artists and makers, working with Oakland's youth, and staying open to the changing Bay Area community. Our awesome programs include a Gallery, ArtsLab, Zine Library, On and Off-Site Youth Workshops, Community Events, Youth and Arts Advocacy, Internship Programs, a Handmade Boutique, Adult Classes, and soooo much more.


On a typical Thursday at the Rock Paper Scissors Collective, the first question you'll certainly have is, "what the heck is this place?"

As a visitor to RPSC, you might witness a group of eager students, ready to learn how to insert a zipper into a pouch in a low cost beginner sewing class; one deaf student comes in with her interpreter and everyone sits at RPSC's public sewing machines, ready to create. Next up, it's an LGBTQ letter writing campaign to incarcerated LGBTQ community. Stamps and letters written, the group cleans up and tucks the chairs into the movable gallery wall that turned into a class and events space. A bustle with youth interns from Oakland Public High Schools, RPSC is a community space that prioritizes offering underprivileged youth the opportunity to cultivate creative skills, to use their hands, and to develop a radical community. Upon entering the space, you’ll see a handful of kids working on self-initiated creative projects: making handmade cards on a typewriter, checking out the DIY zine library, or working on a sewing project. With the help of volunteers from colleges such as CCA and UC Berkeley, RPS is able to develop comprehensive programs and creative workshops that are available to youth and to all of our community members to learn in a supportive hands-on environment.

When this class cleans up, all happy students leave with their creations and the next group rolls into the space; Still you may ask, "what the heck is this place?" It's a bastion of creativity and acceptance. RPSC does not limit its services based on identity or skill level. RPSC is a safe space for youth, and an intricate part of Oakland’s diverse distinctive creative culture, a volunteer organization where everyone is welcome to come in, get hands on, and support one another, a center for skill share, exhibition, and exploration of creative expression.

We're a plethora of things who forge collaborations with everyone: Oakland Unified School District, First Place for Youth, Oakland Public Library, Oakland Museum of California, Endless Canvass, Food Not Bombs, Walk Oakland Bike Oakland, Berkeley City College, Phat Beats, Estria Foundation, CIty of Oakland, Farmer's Markets, Books Not Bombs, Youth Spirit Artworks, SF Zinefest, Maker Faire, Berkeley Art Museum, Yerba Buena Center for the Arts, and way too many to list!

We've heard from lots of folks that they love the non profit RPSC. This love is often coupled with an assumption that we will simply be here forever.

WE WON'T.

NOT WITHOUT YOUR HELP.

We’ve been given so many recognitions and awards for the groundbreaking work that we’ve done over the past decade, but those plaques, banners, radio, news and ribbons don’t pay our bills.

WE NEED YOU TO BE the BONES OF THE CREATIVE CULTURE:

First and foremost, we are asking for your help in raising the funds to make sure we can pay our rent and keep the lights on next month. But that will only get us through next month, and it is really hard to program classes, events, internships, youth and community projects 3-6 months out when volunteers aren't sure we'll be here next month.

So, what we are really asking for is your help in raising the bare bones minimum to operate in 2015.  We might as well ask big and trust that the community of Oakland thrives in creative programming open to all.

Every dollar will help. If everyone on our email list gave $10, we'd be halfway there.

With the security of knowing our rent will be paid and our lights will be on, we can focus on creating, staffing and running the programming that we are known for. We hope to have a full semester of classes, a full season of 12 group exhibitions in the gallery, and a great year of working with the community to produce murals, zines, events, art events and more.

WHY YOU SHOULD CARE:

Well in addition to all the things we've mentioned above....Did you know that RPSC is the sole remaining founder of the Oakland Art Murmur and First Friday? What an explosion of cultural and creative capital! This event is a major part of what put Oakland on the international Art Map.It all started from this little organization that could, it started from a group of volunteers dedicated to building community, and collaboration, through Arts.

Rock Paper Scissors Collective provides an essential platform for expression that is available to all Oakland residents and is a welcoming and friendly space for supportive creativity. We have served tens of thousands of artists and arts supporters. Can you imagine not being able to use your voice for creativity, not having the tools or knowledge to create and express your inner self? Rock Paper Scissors Collective is that essential brick and mortar for these expressive activities. We need to continue to provide the tools, opportunity, space, and sharing of ideas to ensure that all of Oakland can have an opportunity to express themselves.


HOW YOU CAN HELP:

DONATE!  donate any amount you can, we will send you mad love in return. Check out our perks.

SHARE!  Please share this with your friends, family, fellow artists and Bay Area Communities.  Support truly local and grassroots arts.

JOIN! Beyond this monetary goal, we are looking for more volunteers for a more robust organization.  Teach a class! Take a shift! Come to a volunteer party! Make a Zine! Have an Event! Write a Grant? Come hang out!

We need everyone to dedicate to keep a vital space in our community open for all to have access to continue this creative culture where Oakland can thrive in a healthy way.

THANKS SO MUCH-Y'ALL ARE AWESOME!

story:
ExpoComer 2015, March 11-15, Round 1 Fundraising ended, January 16, 2015

Thanks to everyone who contributed to our project in round 1  fundraising for the ExpoComer 2015, March 11-15 trade show.  Your contribution helped us secure space to showcase Soar Couture's products on an international platform.  We are still in need of additional funds to finance the project. 

Help Continue Angie's Legacy, Round 2 Fundraising until February 26, 2015

Jori A Lacy's Story   I am the daughter of Angela Shaw (founder) of Soar Couture.  I was 10 years old when my mom transition to heaven.  She was diagnosed with Leukemia on September 26, 2012 and I would never forget that day she received the word on my birthday from her physician.

Jori Lacy (2002 #throwback)

It was the most shocking news to receive that my mother was ill, yet I did not quite understand her illness. My mother was looking just amazing, and then I was told that my birthday party had to be delayed. At the moment, I realized something was wrong. Within 3 months of finding out that my mom had cancer, she perished. As time passes by, I do believe my mother was chosen by our Heavenly Father.  "He who has ears to hear, let him hear." Matthew 11:15. I am so blessed to have realized my faith in Christ at an early age, being taught by my mom to look to Christ for my salvation and to Him alone. New Faith Baptist church in Matteson, IL is where I attend worship service.

I am also the CEO of Soar Couture founded by my mother. I PRAY is our on-line retail store, a division of Soar Couture Limited distinctly and divinely designed to offer you fashion and faith...in perfect harmony. We are committed to "elevate the spirit" and commission to spread the Gospel of our Lord and King, Jesus Christ through our dynamic fashion collection and gift accessories. My father (Otha Lacy) whom I love dearly, have given me the insight to stay focus with my deepest admiration. He teaches me not to just start something, but to finish it too. My mom started this business and I am going to try my best to keep her business up and running.

When I was a little girl, around six I had my own plan to start a business too. It was me, my granny, my auntie, and my mom. My mom was explaining her business to my aunt and granny when I interrupted and said “Hey, I have a business too.” My mom thinks I’m just saying whatever, but my aunt said “Hold on. I think she’s on to something here."

So I explain my business plan. I told them that I was going to sell batteries. I would buy them from the dollar store for $1 and resell them for a higher price. My aunt asked “Why batteries?" And I said, "because little kids need batteries for their toys.” My aunt, interested in my plan asked, Who is going to work for you though? Well, my mommy is going to have a baby and when my little sister grows up she’s going to work for me. My mom replied, with a smile “that’s my baby. I am so proud of you.” So that was my little plan. I had it all figured out. But now I want to invest in other things. I would like to carry on my mom’s dream but would also like to be a lawyer or a writer. (Read more) http://www.iprayjc.com/About-Us

A Special Invitation! Expocomer 2015 Panama City, Panama

I am so grateful to have received an invitation from Mrs. Melida Harris-Barrow, the Universal Peace Ambassador of Panama (CERCLE) and President & Chief Executive Officer of Panama World Trade & Investment Foundation (PWTIF) to showcase my mom's artwork and gift collections.  The event will be held at the Expocomer in Panama City, Panama on March 11-15, 2015. 

We've a February 26, 2015  deadline to help with all planning arrangements. However, we need additional funds to attend the event.  Your contribution can make this happen!  

Soar Couture Needs Your Help! 

Check out the perks and gallery page of my mom’s artwork.  Or visit our websitewww.iprayjc.com to purchase any products which the proceeds would help me continue my mother's legacy and promote Soar Couture internationally, the vision my mom had for the company.

Get the Word Out!

Thank you for your contribution to help me continue my mother, Angela Shaw's legacy!  http://articles.chicagotribune.com/2005-12-11/n...

Please share your comments or email iprayjc@gmail.com.

~ Jori Lacy, CEO Soar Couture

 "His mercy goes on from generation to generation, to all who fear him." Luke 1:50NLT

story:
My name is Lea Gray and I am the creator of Lea Gray Design, a professional art making business. I have been working with my own passion in art for almost four years. In my most recent year, I started designing paper flower bouquets! Each flower is hand-cut and arranged to make gorgeous, outstanding floral arrangements. 

..I would love to expand this concept into a flourishing business. One that would some day become the standard of what people choose from when selecting bouquets for special occasions! 

In order to gain momentum, my plan is to make a collection of uniquely designed flower arrangements and single flowers that can be sent in the mail. I will be distributing the arrangements around local businesses that have already agreed to display them for consignment. I also would like to photograph them for my online stores to represent a list of choices for interested clients. This will not only increase my exposure, but give people the easy option to purchase a beautifully handmade, lasting bouquet online.

                           

A list of Things Needed to Help PaperBlooms Grow:

  • Professional Laser Cutting Services via Laser Cutting Shapes
  • Living Expenses up to 2 Months for Completing Goals
  • Large Supplement of Imported and Fine Local Papers
  • Various Tools such as New Scissors, Crimping Tools, Pliers, and Paper Punches
  • Ribbons, Twine and Tags
  • Customized Rubber Stamp for Branding and Packaging Material
  • Business Cards, Promotional Flyers and Mailing Postcards 
  • Dried Moss (to fill bottoms of Terrariums) 
  • New Camera Lens, Tripod and Lighting Equipment 
  • Subscription to Website Domain and Hosting
  • Organizational Equipment for In Stock Materials 
  • Gift Bags, Tissue Paper, Postage and Boxes of Various Sizes for Shipment
  • Glass Terrariums, Bubble Bowls and Vases

The Benefits of a Paper Bouquets 

I believe that paper bouquets enhance the quality of life for individuals. Many people question the idea of a fresh flower bouquet because it may not be meaningful enough or the fact that it will only last a week. There are also many hospitals that need color and beauty to lighten up the environment, but can only take in silk floral displays because of allergies and germs. Brides are always looking for ways to make there wedding day special and unique. My bouquets have a "real" look to them and can be customized to specific wedding colors. Once the ceremony is over, the bouquets turn into memorable, lasting gifts for the bride and bridesmaids. 

Success Stories and How PaperBlooms Developed as a Concept

Since I started making paper flowers in June of last year, I have already completed three weddings that included all wedding floral adornments. I have also sold over 15 large and small bouquets, a very large customized flower arrangement and over 20 Hanging Floral terrarium bulbs! People enjoy the idea that they could order a customized bouquet for their loved ones and have re-ordered since! This was all through exposure through social media networks. I would love to see what happens when the flowers are out in the community to be touched and seen. 

I really appreciate you taking the time to read through my campaign and your consideration of supporting me in any way. Please pass this information to as many people as possible. Below is listing of perks that you could choose from per donation amount. All donors will be listed on my newest PaperBlooms website as part of my gratitude list. Stay tuned for more!

                                  

                                      

                                    Thanks again ~ Lea Gray Design

Please check out my website for more! http://www.leagraydesign.com

story:
Who is The Insomniac Propagandist?

The Insomniac Propagandist is a restless figure that spends its nights laying in a paradoxical, dreamlike state, connecting to pure emotion and raw experience. Eternally hunting the vile, elusive being that is “sleep”, TIP arms itself with human works of power, vulnerability, insight, and honesty that emerge from whatever strange medium or form expression demands. It uses this ever-changing arsenal to challenge existing power structures and systems, to dissolve boundaries between visceral and cerebral, to open souls and free imprisoned thought and to illuminate truth in contradiction.

TIP works to take great, weird, powerful art that wouldn't otherwise be published, and share it with the world. By contributing to our campaign you'll help publish brilliant writers and artists in a way that's accessible.

What We Need & What You Get

We are trying to raise $600 to cover the cost of publishing Vol. II as well as purchasing an ISBN number and bar core which will allow us to sell TIP through major retailers.

Our perks are pretty cool, if we say so ourselves. They range from a thank you on our website, to having your piece edited by our Editor-in-Chief and brilliant wordsmith Allison Fabian.

If we don't reach our goal, we will still put the funds received towards publishing Vol. II.

The Impact

Donating to TIP is taking a stand not only for art, but for growth in art. There is always pushback to evolution and change, and TIP is swimming upstream, trying to bring talented artists and brilliant work to light. You can be a part of taking special, unique, risk-taking art that wouldn't normally be published, read, or seen, and making it available for others to connect with and learn from. This is how we all grow as artists, and people. Expand someone's worldview, help us share the unique work featured in TIP.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't afford to donate but want to help TIP out, consider sharing this page, sharing our website and following us on social media. 

Thanks friends.

story:
What is the project? The project is called “Hostage”. I am examining the situations, ideas, customs and expectations of life modern women have communicated to me that bind them or hold them back in figurative, tangible, artistic photographic depictions.

Who are you? I am a professional photographer specializing in intimate photography for women. My mission is to empower women to see their own value and beauty & to liberate them to live life to the fullest. I achieve this through my brand “Freedom Boudoir” which is a personal development experience for women using intimate but tasteful photography. I also empower women through personal mentoring, community involvement such as women’s groups and through my art.

What is the funding for?

Your donations will help fund:

  • Rental or fees for shoot venues

  • Materials such as art supplies and props

  • Photography lab fees

  • Model and shooting assistant costs

  • Gallery show costs such as prints for display, advertising and venue rental


What do I receive?

There are some great rewards to choose from including:

  • A high res screensaver and thank you postcard

  • Original artist signed prints

  • VIP attendance to the gallery show

  • Original artist signed book

  • A Full Day of Sexy Boudoir experience with Freedom Boudoir

  • Headshot photography session with digital files

  • Full size artist signed gallery canvas of a project piece

  • Sponsorship of the gallery show for you or your business

  • Member’s only access to project updates


Why is this project important? 1 in every 4 women will experience domestic violence in her lifetime. But, in my world the odds are much higher. I meet and speak to women who are either in domestic abuse situations, are trying to heal from one or have been the victim of a violent crime. Since making my mission public, women I’ve known for years have come forward to tell me about their past abuse. This project calls attention to the plight of the woman, regardless of her history, and visually depicts the fears, attitudes, customs and situations holding the modern woman hostage literally and in her own mind.

As a survivor I feel passionate about empowering women to see themselves as valuable individuals. As an intimate photographer I encourage women to move out of their comfort zones and achieve emotional freedom through photography. The “Hostage” project takes this one step further by allowing women to anonymously communicate their fears and what they feel bound by that prevents them from thriving and stifles their self perception of value.

The goal of Hostage is for each image to elicit a strong emotion and to call attention to the physical, verbal, and emotional abuse women are subjected to. I am exploring the societal and self imposed ideas responsible for women’s literal and physical bondage in modern times.The visibility of this project will encourage women to break out of their bonds.

Additionally, I wish for the project to affect every person involved; the model(s), assistant(s), donors and gallery attendees.  I encourage each individual to examine what holds them back from prosperity and to overcome it. This project is about putting broken people back together.

10% of your net donations to Hostage (goal met or not) & 15% of all prints, books or cards sold will be donated to Northwest Arkansas Women’s Shelter. The shelter provides free emergency shelter, food, and clothing to victims of domestic violence and/or sexual assault. They also provide a free 24-hour crisis phone line.

How can I get involved? By donating, not only do you help women in immediate need, but you will give a voice to all women bound by abuse or simply their own limited thinking. You will also receive some great rewards and be involved in the project.

If you cannot donate, you can still help! Spread the word and share the campaign on Facebook, Twitter, your Blog or Website, Instagram, Google+ and with family and friends. Please especially share with those who have a heart for women’s empowerment.

Enjoy, share and donate! Thank you for taking time to understand my mission. Thank you for your help and support.

Check back often for updates on the project.

My mission is to empower women to see their own value and beauty & to liberate them to live life to the fullest. story:
Summary

Every young person deserves access to arts and a safe space which is what we provide at Donda’s House. Donda’s House, Inc. launched in 2013, provides access to high quality arts instruction to youth. The instruction is not only in the arts though as Donda's House helps to transform a young person's life.  After our program, those who have dropped out are ready to re-enroll in school, they have a blueprint for their personal and professional future and they belong to a community of peers and mentors who make themselves available to be there during their challenges and to celebrate their successes. To date we have served 120 artists between the ages of 14 - 24 years old in Chicago.  

Our efforts to provide this opportunity for young people are currently under threat.  On Tuesday, January 27th, we had an Orientation for our Spring Programming. Then, on Thursday, January 28th, the State of Illinois sent an e-mail to over 18 agencies stating that “effective immediately”, funding for Spring Out of School (OST) Funding & Youth Employment Programs had been cut. On Friday, January 29th, we had to make the critical decision to either cancel our Spring Programming OR raise the funds. On Monday, February 2nd, we opened applications for our Spring 2015 Program, where we received a huge pool of applicants. 

Your contribution will send a resounding signal to our State Capital, and to the 60 youth we are enrolling in our Spring Program that art matters and it is the pulse of any healthy community.

What We Need & What You Get

We need $100,000 to pay for our Spring, Summer and Fall “Got Bars” Programs. This will support a total of 180 young artists. Your contribution will allow us to hire :

  • a Creative Writing Instructor - to teach the students poetic devices and writing techniques.

  • a Studio Recording Instructor - to teach the students studio etiquette and to produce and engineer the student’s original songs.

  • The students also learn how to monetize their music by learning about ASCAP, BMI and music publishing.

  • Additionally, we will take the students on a field trip each semester to go to the Southside Community Arts Center where they get out of their neighborhood and connect to the rich history of Chicago.

If we don’t reach our goal, we will use whatever we raise to support programming for the students.  

We have some exclusive perks - thanks to people like you who understand the value of the arts:

  • Angela C. Styles - Celebrity Stylist, Salon Owner and personality on the reality show L.A. Hair is offering a consultation.

  • Britany Rickett who manages media strategy for brands like Allstate and Kellog’s Frosted Flakes & Fruitloops is offering a consultation to help build the business of your brand.

  • Our Grammy-Award Winning, Golden Globe Winning, Oscar Nominated Creative Director Che “Rhymefest” Smith will create a personalized voicemail greeting for you!

  • We also have t-shirts, music from the students in our program and a host of other perks!

The Impact

Youth who study the arts have more positive life outcomes. In an external evaluation conducted by the Alternative Education Research Institute (AERI), we learned that Donda’s House  “serves as a positive element in the lives of those faced with many adversities…” Beyond the artistic benefits, our youth have an “increased ability to effectively communicate verbally and in writing” and an increase in their “ability to work positively within group and professional settings.” We believe that Chicago doesn’t have a violence problem, it has a heART problem - because the youth who need the most support are not receiving that support. If we can replace the guns on the street with microphones, the street corners with rap cyphers and the sense of hopelessness with the promise of opportunity - we will not only reduce the crime, drop-out rate and incarceration rate - we’ll have a model to to do the same in other cities with similar challenges.

One great example of the promise of Donda's House is the story of sixteen year old Tomas “Skoolie” Arjonas. Skoolie enrolled in “Got Bars” in the Spring of 2014 as a high school drop-out. When we met him, he faced many obstacles. He couldn’t even ride public transportation due to fear of gun-violence and gang-activity in his neighborhood. At Dona's House, one of the things we cultivate in our youth is goal-setting, and during class, Skoolie talked about his desire to go to college one day. After being kicked out of three Chicago public high schools, Donda’s House helped him enroll in military school where he finished with his diploma in December of 2014. He is now enrolled in a Community College and is well on his way to reaching his dreams.

Donda's House was featured in a Facebook Documentary where our students shared their feelings about our program in their own words. We’ve partnered with Amnesty International on their annual Write 4 Rights Campaign, and we’re planning collaborations with the Chicago Public Library to scale our impact. We are committed to seeking other partnerships that will further transform the lives of Chicago’s youth.

Risks & Challenges

Chicago’s Youth face many challenges, but under the leadership of our Executive Director, Donnie Smith and our Creative Director, Che “Rhymefest” Smith, we are well equipped to handle any challenge. Donnie Smith taught High School for over 10 years. She ensures that the learning activities are curriculum based, and that we can measure the transferable skills the students learn in our program. 

Che “Rhymefest” Smith serves as one of our Creative Writing Instructors - committing 2 hours per each semester to work directly with the artists. He ensures that the program is engaging and that students actually learn the "business" of music. He's secured guest speakers like No ID, the Vice President of Def Jam Records, and a trip to Philadelphia for 15 students to work behind the scenes at Jay-Z's Made in America Festival. 

Both Donnie and Che credit the arts with "saving their lives" and are committed to helping the next generation of young artists realize their full potential. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Any amount helps. In addition to donating, we ask that you share this with people you know who understand that heART matters:
  • Share this on Twitter, Facebook, Instagram and via e-mail.
  • Secure a Corporate Matching gift from your employer
  • Ask your co-workers to donate. 
  • Sign our Change.org petition that will be sent to Governor Rauner and other elected officials: http://bit.ly/funds4youth
We don’t have time to wait for the State to restore the funding or to play politics. Applications are rolling in every day and we want to be ready on March 16th to start classes! Thank you for your support and contribution!

story:
FROM ZERO TO THE ULTIMATE SUCCESS

Mongolia’s debut to take the first appearance of Mongolian contemporary art at the 56th International Art Exhibition at La Biennale di Venezia was initiated and organized by Mongolian Contemporary Art Support Association (MCASA), chaired by Gantuya Badamgarav. The team structure and participants include B. Gantuya, Commissioner; Ts.Uranchimeg, Curator; Ch. Boldbaatar and David Ross as advisers and Scientific Committee members.

While Mongolian economy and business possibilities present as promising potential for foreign investment especially in mining sector, Mongolian art and culture remains almost unknown. Gantuya, who holds MA in Economics from Williams College, and has a solid background in business executive leadership, international project management, and nonprofit organizations, took a pioneering step to make a critical change. The change that is important not only for Mongolia but more so for the Western public in the opening of the world in the globalization era--after all, that is the main goal for international exhibitions with Venice taking the lead.

Gantuya took tremendous, if not impossible, courage in initiating and organizing a project with zero budget during the time of Mongolia’s economic downfall, unexpected change of the government in November 2014, and subsequent internal politics.

With the little support from the government and businesses at the time, MCASA first time launched online crowd-sourcing campaign that aided the project with $820, which in the given situation was “better something than nothing.” The Indiegogo fundraiser, however, brought more than something: international awareness of the project, and its impossibly ambitious and pioneering goals. But this is the beauty in all pioneering endeavors, and the case of the success of Mongolia Pavilion by MCASA is another proof how courage and unbroken management leads from zero to the ultimate success. The fundraising success was secured by MCASA in last February aided by Mr. Bat-Uul, Mayor of Ulaanbaatar capital city and local private funders, and the final decision for the venue was made in discussion with the supporting international institutions and new partners, including the Dutch Global Art Affairs Foundation.

The project is also solidly backed up by former Whitney Museum director David A. Ross and the winner of the Golden Lion at the 2004 Venice Biennale, artist and musician Yoko Ono.

Currently, Mongolia Pavilion is planned to show two Mongolian artists--UnenEnkh and T.Enkhbold-- at European Cultural Center at Palazzo Mora. Mongolia Pavilion also ventures to present a new performance art of its Nomadic Pavilion component as its additional feature in designated public spaces in the city of Venice.

Text by Curator Ch.Uranchimeg


Credits:

Gantuya Badamgarav, Commissioner of Mongolia Pavilion, Founder of MCASA

Uranchimeg Tsultem, Curator of Mongolia Pavilion

David A Ross, Adviser

Enkhbold Togmidshiirev, Artist

Dorjderem Davaa, Video Editor

Gantulga Jargalnasan, Graphic Designer, Camera Operator

Tsolmon Naidandorj, Camera Operator 

Davaa Tsaschiher, Composer

Emma Ellis, Media

Vanessa Soetanto, Media

story:
Find new ways to orgasm!

Use this book to explore different techniques to achieve an orgasm. Each recipe is broken down into specific steps with illustrations.  

___________________________________________________________

Why write a cookbook for orgasms

A year ago, I was searching for a break-up project and decided to write this book. After years of being chronically single, I had learned a few tricks to get myself to climax.  With my new found singleness, I decided to share these lessons with the world. 

In talking with other women, there are many who have never had an orgasm or can only do so with a toy.  The goal is to give women and their partners some fresh ideas.  This campaign is to recover some of the costs of creating the book.  In doing so, I can keep the price low, when selling the book and thus reach more women.  

What We Need & What You Get

The majority of the funds raised will go towards editing, typesetting and creating illustrations.  I have hired professionals for these tasks and they will bring extra clarity to the book.  

The Impact

The funds will allow me to create a professional looking book and to keep the price low, for many to enjoy.  

Progress

I have a draft of the book, as well as a draft of the illustrations.  Next steps are to get the wording edited, the images professionally done and to typeset the book.  

Sample of the Book

"An orgasm is like a beautiful symphonic performance. Each section works together harmoniously to create wonderful music that builds into a climax and resolves to an end. Much like a good musician practices her instrument, these techniques must be practiced until they are second nature.

Broadly speaking, each orgasm is broken down into four major parts or steps. Each of these parts happen simultaneously in order to produce an amplification of sensation in each specific area."

Recipe 2: The Clitorgasm

Introduction

The second recipe is the Clitorgasm. Once you’ve mastered the Clitorgasm, you can reach it very quickly. ………………….

Description of the Orgasm

The Clitorgasm climax sends intense waves out from the vulva and that travel through the body in a quick burst……………..

The Recipe

Step One:  Mental mindset: For this orgasm, you want to have ………………………

Step Two:  External stimulation: The stimulation for this orgasm is located at the clitoris. Start with two fingers ……………………….

Step Three:  Muscle contractions: The muscle contractions for this recipe ………………………….

Step Four:  Breathing: Breathe through your nose, but only the top half of the passageway……………………..

Draft of the tea towels

story:
CLEMENTINA

A project of an exhibition and a reading room

Between visual art and literature, Clementina is a collaborative project born one year ago after the acquaintance of Eva Marathaki and Giulia Casartelli in Athens.

Eva is an artist.

Giulia is a writer.

Eva’s drawings were for Giulia the trigger for a new short story, Clementina, now enshrined in a manuscript created by Eva.

Portrait ΙII, Simone de Beauvoir, 2014, pencil on paper


In November 2015, the manuscript of Clementina will be exhibited at the Yeni Djami of Thessaloniki, the last mosque built in the city in 1902, alongside with a number of selected works and new productions by Eva.

http://www.thessaloniki.travel/index.php/en/component/content/article?id=32

Manuscripts are by nature fragile, they can be exposed and read by a limited audience; a manuscript is the outcome of dedication, a secret shared with few. The manuscript, like the character of Clementina, carries the weight and the fragility of a secret, echoed in the space and history of the Yeni Djami.

In the manuscript the story is presented in Italian and Greek and will be read by Giulia and Eva in both languages, during the opening of the exhibition on November 3rd 2015.

                                                   

Fall or reign of the middle class, 2013, pencil on paper


In the context of the exhibition, a reading room will be open to give to the audience the possibility of experience an intimate and cosy environment to approach the story.


The Emperor (a throne with its prestige undermined), 2012, pencil on paper


WHO ARE WE?

Giulia Casartelli (b. 1986 in Lecco, Italy) worked in art galleries and non-governmental organizations in Milan, New Delhi and Cape Town. She has been the associate coordinator of the Pavilion of the Republic of Armenia at the 56. Biennale of Venice (2015), awarded with the Golden Lion for the Best National Participation. She holds a BS in Management for Arts and Culture (Università Bocconi, Milan) and a MS in Anthropology and Ethnological Science (Università Bicocca, Milan). She carried out her field research in Istanbul. She is currently based in Athens.
 

Eva Marathaki (b. 1977 in Athens, Greece) graduated in 2001 from the University of North London (BA French/Spanish & Latin American Studies) and continued her studies at the Athens School of Fine Art. Her work has been shown in Greece and abroad and can be found in private and public collections. She has worked as a set and costume designer for the theater. She is a founding member of SKOUZE3 artist run space and a member of the ATONAλ Theater Company. She is currently based in Athens. A presentation of her work can be found at www.evamarathaki.com

WHY WE NEED YOUR SUPPORT?

Clementina is an independent project.

So far we have benefited from the generosity of supporters in Greece and abroad that are offering their help, hospitality and expertise to sustain our creativity. We want to thank for their help the Municipality of Thessaloniki, the Italian Cultural Institute of Athens, Hotel Olympia (Thessaloniki) and CRITERION I The Furnishing Approach (Thessaloniki).

Step by step, all together we are making this exhibition possible.

What we need now is your contribution to have with us a team of local technicians to create a new art installation that will enrich the dome of the Yeni Djami and the presentation of the manuscript of Clementina. You will be able to see the documentation of the mounting of the show on the website we will create for the project and see the team at work.

We are aiming to raise 8’000 euros. Ambitious indeed, but with your help we can do it!

This amount will enable us to support the following:

-  making of the installation in Athens with tailors and engineers 

-  shipping of the artwork from Athens to Thessaloniki

-  technicians’ honorarium for the mounting and dismounting of the installation

HOW TO SUPPORT

You can support the campaign in two different ways: 

·  choosing one of the 'perks' and their different benefits

· clicking on the CONTRIBUTE NOW button and choosing the amount of your contribution from €1 to...no limit!

Thank you everybody!

OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP

If you are unable to make a donation, but you like the project and you would still like to support us, there are other ways in which you can do it.

First of all you can do so by sharing this campaign with everyone you know, via social media, emails, mails…

And you can also send us your ideas, advices, comments to make this project happen.

We are grateful for any support you can give us!  

------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

                                                            CLEMENTINA

                                    Un progetto di mostra e sala di lettura

Clementina è un progetto tra arte visiva e letteratura, nato un anno fa, dopo l’incontro tra Eva Marathaki e Giulia Casartelli ad Atene.

Eva è un’artista.

Giulia è una scrittrice.

I disegni di Eva hanno ispirato Giulia nella scrittura di un nuovo racconto, Clementina, ora custodito in un manoscritto creato da Eva. 

          Safe in their alabaster room, 2010, matita su carta, carta da parati, legno

Il prossimo novembre, il manoscritto di Clementina sarà esibito alla Yeni Djami di Salonicco, l’ultima moschea costruita nella città nel 1902, con una serie di opere selezionate e nuove produzioni realizzate da Eva.

http://www.thessaloniki.travel/index.php/en/component/content/article?id=32

I manoscritti sono per natura fragili, possono essere esibiti e letti da un pubblico circoscritto; un manoscritto è il risultato di dedizione, un segreto condiviso tra pochi. Il manoscritto, come il personaggio di Clementina, porta il peso e la fragilità di un segreto, a cui fanno eco la storia e lo spazio stesso della Yeni Djami.

Nel manoscritto il racconto sarà presentato in italiano e in greco e sarà letto da Giulia ed Eva in entrambe le lingue il giorno dell’inaugurazione della mostra, il 3 novembre prossimo. 

Nell’ambito della mostra, sarà aperta una sala di lettura che darà al pubblico la possibilità di avvicinarsi al racconto in uno spazio intimo e accogliente. 


                                          You an I II, 2013, pencil on paper, 29,2x29,2 cm

CHI SIAMO?

Giulia Casartelli è nata a Lecco nel 1986. Ha lavorato in gallerie d’arte e organizzazioni non governative a Milano, Nuova Delhi e Città del Capo. È stata coordinatrice associata del Padiglione armeno alla 56. Biennale di Venezia (2015), premiato con il Leone d’Oro per la Miglior Partecipazione Nazionale. Ha conseguito la laurea triennale in Economia per l’arte, la cultura e la comunicazione (Università Bocconi, Milano) e successivamente la specialistica in Scienze antropologiche ed etnologiche (Università  Bicocca, Milano), svolgendo le sue ricerche a Istanbul. Attualmente vive ad Atene. 

Eva Marathaki è nata ad Atene nel 1977. Si è laureata nel 2001  all’University of North London in  francese/spagnolo e studi latino americani. Ha proseguito i suoi studi all’Accademia di Belle Arti di Atene. Il suo lavoro è stato esposto in Grecia e all’estero e si trova in collezioni pubbliche e private. Ha lavorato come scenografa e costumista per il teatro ed è un membro fondatore dello spazio indipendente SKOUZE3 e della compagnia teatrale ATONAλ. Attualmente vive ad Atene. Una presentazione del suo lavoro è presente nel sito www.evamarathaki.com

PERCHÉ CI SERVE IL VOSTRO AIUTO?

Clementina è un progetto indipendente.

Fino ad ora abbiamo beneficiato della generosità di sostenitori in Grecia e all’estero che hanno offerto suggerimenti, ospitalità e abilità per sostenere Clementina. In particolare vogliamo ringraziare la Municipalità di Salonicco, l'Istituto Italiano di Cultura di Atene, l'Hotel Olympia (Salonicco) e CRITERION I The Furnishing Approach (Salonicco).

Passo dopo passo, tutti insieme stiamo rendendo questa mostra possibile.

Quello che ora ci serve è il vostro contributo per avere con noi un team di tecnici per creare una nuova installazione che arricchirà la cupola della moschea, impreziosendo la presentazione del manoscritto di Clementina.

Sarà possibile accedere alla documentazione del montaggio della mostra sul sito che creeremo per il progetto e vedere così il team all’opera.

Puntiamo a raccogliere 8’000 euro. Sì, ambizioso, ma con il vostro aiuto possiamo farcela!

Con questa somma saremo in grado di sostenere le spese per:

-  la realizzazione dell'installazione a Atene con sarte e ingegneri 

-  il trasporto dell’opera da Atene a Salonicco

-  la parcella dei tecnici per il montaggio e lo smontaggio dell'opera


COME CONTRIBUIRE

Potete contribuire alla campagna in due modi differenti:

·  scegliendo uno dei perk e i loro corrispondenti benefit

·  cliccando su CONTRIBUTE NOW e scegliendo l’ammontare della vostra donazione da €1 fino a... non c’è limite!

Grazie mille a tutti!

ALTRI CONTRIBUTI

Se non vi è possibile fare una donazione, ma vi piace il progetto e volete comunque dare il vostro contributo ecco qui altri modi in cui potete essere partecipi.

Anzitutto spargendo la voce riguardo al progetto attraverso social media, email, lettere…E potete anche inviarci commenti, idee, consigli per rendere questo progetto possibile.

Vi siamo grate per il supporto!

PERK

10 EUROS – Friend  

§  Menzione come sponsor sul sito della mostra (opzionale)

50 EURO - Supporter

§ Menzione come sponsor sul sito della mostra (opzionale)

§  Invito alla mostra in edizione limitata disegnato da G Design Studio (Atene)

200 EURO - Patron 

§  Menzione come sponsor sul sito della mostra (opzionale)

§  Invito alla mostra in edizione limitata disegnato da G Design Studio (Atene)

§  Libro a stampa in edizione limitata di “Clementina” disegnato da G Design Studio (Atene). Il libro è trilinge: italiano, greco e inglese. 

500 EURO - Sponsor

§ Menzione di sponsor sul sito della mostra (opzionale)

§ Invito alla mostra in edizione limitata disegnato da G Design Studio (Atene)

§  Disegno unico di Eva Marathaki ispirato a Clementina (22 x 30 cm)

CLEMENTINA
A
project of an exhibition and a reading room

Between visual art and literature, Clementina is a collaborative project born
one year ago after the acquaintance of Eva Marathaki and Giulia Casartelli in
Athens. 
Eva is an artist.
Giulia is a writer.
Eva’s drawings were for Giulia the trigger for a
new short story, Clementina, now enshrined
in a manuscript created by Eva.



Portrait ΙII, Simone de Beauvoir, 2014, pencil on
paper

In November 2015, the manuscript of Clementina will be exhibited at the Yeni
Djami of Thessaloniki, the last mosque built in the city in 1902, alongside with a number of selected
works and new productions by Eva. 
http://www.thessaloniki.travel/index.php/en/component/content/article?id=32

Manuscripts
are by nature fragile, they can be exposed and read by a limited audience; a
manuscript is the outcome of dedication, a secret shared with few. The
manuscript, like the character of Clementina, carries the weight and the
fragility of a secret, echoed in the space and history of the Yeni Djami. 
In
the manuscript the story is presented in Italian and Greek and will be read by
Giulia and Eva in both languages, during the opening of the exhibition on
November 3rd 2015.

                                                   



Fall or reign of the middle class, 2013, pencil on paper

In the
context of the exhibition, a reading room will be open to give to the audience the possibility of experience an intimate and cosy
environment to approach the story.





The
Emperor (a throne with its prestige undermined), 2012, pencil on paper

Casartelli (b. 1986 in Lecco, Italy) worked in art galleries and
non-governmental organizations in Milan, New Delhi and Cape Town. She has been

Participation. She holds a BS in
Management for Arts and Culture (Università Bocconi, Milan) and a MS in
Anthropology and Ethnological Science (Università Bicocca, Milan). She carried
out her field research in Istanbul. She
is currently based in Athens.

 
Eva Marathaki (b. 1977 in
Athens, Greece) graduated in 2001 from the University of North London (BA

by step, all together we are making this exhibition possible.

we need now is your contribution to have with us a team of local technicians to
create a new art installation that will enrich the dome of the Yeni Djami and
the presentation of the manuscript of Clementina.
You will be able to see the documentation of the mounting of the show on the
website we will create for the project and see the team at work.
We
are aiming to raise 8’000 euros. Ambitious indeed, but with your help we can do
it!
This
amount will enable us to support the following:
-  making of the installation in Athens with tailors and engineers 
- 
shipping
of the artwork from Athens to Thessaloniki
- 
technicians’
honorarium for the mounting and dismounting of the installation
HOW TO SUPPORT
You
can support the campaign in two different ways: 
· 
choosing
one of the 'perks' and their different benefits
· clicking
on the CONTRIBUTE NOW button and choosing the amount of your contribution from
€1 to...no limit!
Thank
you everybody!

OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP

If you are unable to make a donation,
but you like the project and you would still like to support us, there are
other ways in which you can do it. 
First of all you can do so by sharing this
campaign with everyone you know, via social media, emails, mails…
And you can also send us your ideas,
advices, comments to make this project happen.
We are grateful for any support you can
give us!

story:
Short Summary

Spaces of popular imagery for themselves attract curiosity. The success of their survival over time is based on the fact that they always in the background evoke normality. The study of this subject requires fieldwork, talking to local inhabitants of a place, collecting stories, indexing, analysis and interpretation. Interpretations provide further existence of folk tales in which the miraculous and the supernatural intertwined with the real.

Our goal

The aim is to preserve the original cultural and traditional values of supernatural creatures from Croatian folklore, which, so far, are mostly based on oral, the so-called "from generation to generation" stories.

Humanity is clearly inclined to believe that we share this world with supernatural creatures, good and evil spirits, because fear and curiosity mix with imagination, and the principles of good and evil act on it.

We are here to keep it alive, to tell you what happens with supernatural creatures while you are asleep. 




Stories and illustrations

Night butterfly


Mrna & Dobra witches


Sea Lady from small town of Zaton

story:
"And if the body were not the soul, what is the soul?" Walt Whitman "I Sing The Body Electric." 

It's been written that Whitman's poem "…catalogues the glories of the body, moving from head to toe and from outer surfaces to inner organs and processes." Whitman writes about the beauty of every body, not just an ideal. The heart & soul, as well as oxygen, gives our body life…every one of us. Regardless of our physical differences we all have beauty in us and we should feel that beauty as well as see it.

The mission of this phase of this project is to photograph seven individuals from the physically disabled community, in water, to create three images (each) that show the beauty and uniqueness of the physically disabled body, from a disabled perspective, in 21 photographs in a self-published Limited Collector's Edition Book of beauty.  

Being photographed underwater allows every body to be free of mechanical assistive devices (but allowing human assistance) and to experience a weightlessness that contributes to the body's own flowing movement. 

Your contribution will enable us to: 

  1. Reserve 12 hours at a pool to photograph underwater. 
  2. Reserve underwater housing for the photo gear, 
  3. Cover Transportation for seven models to participate,
  4. Document the process on Video.
  5. Print a self-published Limited Collector's Edition Book of positive, artistic images to contribute to changing the ableist view of the physically disabled body as "incomplete," "deficient," “deformed” or "grotesque," to one of beauty being what we are. 
After we have our costs covered for this project I will be donating all remaining funds to Creative Growth Art Center (in the Bay area) that "serves adult artists with developmental, mental and physical disabilities, providing a professional studio environment for artistic development, gallery exhibition and representation and a social atmosphere among peers." 

Working collaboratively with the individual models throughout this process (including choosing the photo images for the final edit) will result in images showing the heart and soul of the disabled individuals in 21 photographs in a Limited Collector's Edition Book. However, this is just the beginning of a project that I hope will eventually be picked up by a small publisher and reprinted allowing it to continue to grow and inspire. 

Project Origins & Bio:

In 2002, I lost my right leg above the knee due to a blood clot. My left leg was also affected and I've suffered nerve damage as well as an infection in my right arm. Thirteen years later I have chronic pain in my left foot, left leg, right arm and in my residual limb. My (dominant) right hand also has a tremor, which has had a serious impact on my art. However, there are many things that I can do, just differently, which requires a different perspective from before.

‪As a person with multiple physical handicaps, I have struggled with the limitations of my body and accepting my body as beautiful. As a Visual Artist, I have studied photography, Disability Theory and the ableist ideas of beauty. As a Photographer/Artist for 20+ years, I have a love of film and the beauty and uniqueness of the process that can be produced with a directness, and individual manipulation, to create a one of a kind work of art in each print. 

‬In the past 13 years, utilizing social media, I have become aware of the larger physically disabled community online (worldwide). There are many difficult things experienced daily by a physically disabled person socially, culturally, in addition to having to physically navigate through the day. What I have found is that what most of us have in common, in addition to a disability, is that most of us have struggled with a poor self-image, and/or the ableist idea of what makes a body beautiful. Please help us get this started and make this a thing of beauty at the grassroots level and from there it will take off with a life of its own. You are also the heart & soul  of this project!

Thank you, from the models and myself!

Lu Hanna, Photographer/Artist

Lu Hanna Website

Lucy Hanna Wikipedia

story:
The Art of Governance is a work of art. This work brings together a paid team of seven young people in Jackson, MS - one from each City Council ward.

As a team they set their own budgets, research local issues, and imagine paths forward for Jackson. Along the way, they will meet with their City Council counterparts and the Mayor to reflect their thoughts and receive feedback.

Having decided on paths forward, daniel johnson will facilitate the team to create an art work to raise awareness and inspire action.

The aim of this campaign is to finance a documentary project to run alongside The Art of Governance. Being able to track the progress of the student team through monthly videos will help to bring along the citizens of Jackson - inviting them into the story to offer feedback and to physically participate.The videos and forums will be hosted on the project website www.theartofgovernance.us. 

At the conclusion of the project in May 2016, the footage will be brought together into a short documentary which will be an important tool for the young people to carry forward their momentum and message past the end of the initial production.

The application period is open until October 9th so if you would like to participate as a team member, download the application at www.theartofgovernance.us. Our team will be announced November 1st. 

daniel johnson is a creator and explorer working in the fields of relational aesthetics and social practice. johnson engages communities in explorations of collective identity and narrative formation through projects which emerge from facilitated dialog and take form in the visual and performance mediums best suited to the task.

johnson has organized an array of public policy, health, artist, and social communities over the past 12 years both professionally and simply as an engaged citizen of Jackson, MS. Some of his past projects have included the Jackson Arts Collective, the Mississippi Improvisation Alliance, the Volunteer Market, Jackson State of the Arts public dialogs, Outreach Coordinator and Board Member for the Rainbow Natural Grocery Cooperative, project facilitator for the FIGMENT Interactive Arts Festival, and co-founder of Mississippi Happening, an all-arts blog and podcast exploring the myriad creative threads weaving throughout Mississippi.

In 2012, johnson organized and implemented a Creative Hub initiative in the Midtown neighborhood bringing together resident, artist, association and institutional partners around a $150,000 Our Town initiative with the National Endowment for the Arts. His more game-oriented public art works can be viewed at www.danieljohnsonmakesart.com, the most notable of which are The Westinghouse Refrigerator Project, Mr. Muddle and the Council of Suggestion, and Core Sample, a work of Significant Developments, LLC.

daniel johnson is currently the Director of Engagement and Learning at the Mississippi Museum of Art, a Board Member for Purple Word Book and Paper Arts Center and the Business Association of Midtown, a father and husband and a proud member of Alternate ROOTS.

Kevin Perez is a local videographer/producer from Miami, FL and currently residing in Jackson, MS. A recent graduate of Jackson State University, he now works at a local news station as a field photographer (cameraman) and is also involved in commercial film productions throughout the metro area with RedSquared Productions, LLC. A highlight of his work with Jackson youth has been as a producer mentor with Mississippi Public Broadcasting's “Can I Kick It?”: Youth Movement Through Media Institute, a summer program for local high school students that encourages leadership development through digital literacy and the creation of a script and short film. http://goodnewskevin87.wix.com/kperez

Bridget Townsend is the Director of Youth Initiatives with the City of Jackson. In her role as director, Townsend manages youth and educational programs within the city, developing collaborative relationships with other governmental agencies, non-profits and faith-based agencies. The Jackson, Mississippi native has also worked as a recruiter for the Department of Homeland Security (TSA) and program manager for Junior Achievement. Townsend received her bachelor’s degree from Mississippi College and Master's degree from Troy State University. One of her most significant professional accomplishments is coordinating Jackson's Annual Back to School event, which serves over 5,000 Jackson Public Schools students. A board member of the Boys and Girls Club and Alignment Jackson, Townsend also serves on the high school committee, career fair planning committee and often volunteers on special projects within the city. She is very proud to be part of the development of Mayor Yarber’s “I Need You To Make It” Youth Initiative platform. The Initiative offers comprehensive programming for the mind, body, and soul. The INYTMI is a collaboration in partnership with city departments, Jackson Public Schools, Alignment Jackson and other community and private organizations in support of youth in the City of Jackson

Alternate ROOTS supports the creation and presentation of original art that is rooted in communities of place, tradition or spirit. We are a group of artists and cultural organizers based in the South creating a better world together. As Alternate ROOTS, we call for social and economic justice and are working to dismantle all forms of oppression- everywhere. www.alternateroots.org 

Mayor Tony Yarber's "I Need You To Make It" Youth Initiative

Mayor Tony T. Yarber desires to create a holistic approach to the development and progression of our city’s youth and young adults by implementing the “I Need You To Make it” (INYTMI) initiative. The general purpose of the initiative is to foster a comprehensive method that effectively addresses key areas in which our young people need guidance and support. The INYTMI initiative is comprised of three components. Each component represents a key area of focus for the overall initiative. Those three components/key areas are:

Mind-The Education Component

Body-The Health Component

Soul-The Character Building Component

This is “Our Moment, Our Time” and we are excited to research and develop new programs that will support our young peoples success.—Bridget Townsend, Director, Mayor's Youth Initiative

story:
The Hip-Hop Cosmic Circle Palestine is composed by Nadim Al Ayaseh, stage name is MC Naz, a Palestinian refugee rapper, activist and writer ; Mohammed Ghanayem, also known as Hajj MC, a Palestinian refugee rapper originally from Haifa; Moises Lopez, a Hip-Hop Educator and activist in New York City, and Alice Le Diouron, a French researcher trainee and activist, and Elijah Gomez, filmmaker, photographer and activist from the Bronx, New York

The Hip-Hop Cosmic Circle- Palestine foresees creating and supporting a three day Hip-Hop conference in Bethlehem & Ramallah to make innovations glow in a country often presented through the Israeli-Palestinian conflict prism by bringing, together, people who have already been independently contributing to innovations.

One of the major goals of this conference is to help create the first Hip-Hop School of Palestine, a project that will embrace the arising creative-talented artists and will give them the support to continue their artistic march in what serves the humanitarian work.

Through film screenings, panel discussions, and collaborative music performances, The three day conference is intended to provide a space where participants will be able to interrogate the dynamics of power, hegemony, and popular culture in the Middle East. From this engagement will emerge a proactive framework for thinking through potential nonviolent alternatives to trauma, mourning, and loss.

Hip Hop is suggested to be a loudspeaker of the counter hegemonic discourse of Palestinians. We really need your help to make this historic event happen!!

story:
You can still donate!

Our IndieGoGo campaign has finished, but you can still help! Visit us at  transfamilyphotos.com to help us raise the remaining funds we need to fulfill our vision for a robust, traveling exhibit that will stand the test of multiple venues. You can also get up-to-date information there about our exhibit, contact us about bringing it to your location, and more!

The project

This exhibit is a collaboration between Matthew Clowney, artist and photography professor at the Rhode Island School of Design, and Margaret Middleton, exhibit designer. 

We're making an art exhibit for children, featuring photographs of a family with a transgender grandparent. These images will offer a window into the family life of Erica Tobias, her children, and grandchildren.

The exhibit will debut at the Provincetown Library on Cape Cod for Family Equality Council's Family Week in late July. After its run in P-town, the exhibit will re-open at Boston Children's Museum in October. We hope to travel the exhibit to other venues after that.

Contributing to the campaign

Your contributions will fund signage, a wall system, printing and framing for the photographs, exhibit furniture, exhibit fabrication, possible expansion of the project.

Perks

  • Contributors at all levels receive a free download of "Pink Explosion", our original campaign song by Tracie Potochnik.
  • Contributors at the $25 level and higher will get their name on a donor recognition panel that will hang in the exhibit.
  • $1000 contributors will get their very own family portrait by Matthew Clowney
  • ...and we're working on adding additional perks throughout this fundraiser! 

About the exhibit

The pictures, mostly done reportage style, are candid captures of Erica Tobias and her family, focusing on their relationships with one another. The centerpiece of the work will be a complete family portrait done in Matthew’s signature digital-composite technique. Accompanying signage in English and Spanish will be written to inspire dialogue between family members. 

Book Nook 

Cozy seating and a basket full of child-appropriate fiction and non-fiction books about family diversity and gender expression.

Sharing Station 

A table and chairs with paper and color pencils and a display space where visitors can respond to prompts like, What does family mean to you? How has your family changed over time? What makes your family special? This is an opportunity for visitors to reflect on their own families’ unique qualities and share with others. 

An art exhibit for grown-ups vs. an art exhibit for children.

Why it's important

Opinion polls show that people who know someone who is gay or lesbian are more likely to support equal rights for all gay and lesbian people. Anecdotal evidence also suggests that the same is true for people who know someone who is bisexual or transgender.
Human Rights Campaign

  • It's estimated that only 9% of Americans know someone who is transgender. We hope that visitors who see this exhibit will feel like they've gotten to know Erica and her family.
  • We also hope that some visitors will recognize themselves or their families in these images. It's so important for people, especially children, to see representations of who Laverne Cox calls "Possibility Models".

What if...

  • If we don't reach our entire goal we'll do what we can. This might mean printing signage on paper, using easels instead of a wall system, or foregoing framing or furniture. Of course, we'd love to realize our full vision of the complete exhibit, sturdy and robust so it can travel and live on through multiple venues.
  • HOWEVER if we exceed our goal, we have plans for a family photo booth that we'd like to add to the exhibit. Depending on if and when that funding comes in, we could have the photo booth ready for our installation in October.
  • If we wildly exceed our goal, we would like to extend this project to other cities not just by traveling these photographs, but also by finding more families to work with in order to create more exhibitions, and once all those things are paid for, if we can afford to, we'll give Matthew a modest artist's honorarium.

Other ways to help

  • Share this page with all your friends! Facebook, Twitter, email...
  • Donate a service or product that we can use as a perk. Get in touch if you have an idea for an incentive.
  • Buy books! Help us stock the exhibit's Book Nook by making purchases from our Amazon Wish List.

story:
Short Summary

Why is the Don’t Turn Your Back on AIDS™ (DTYBOA) High School HIV Awareness Art Program important?

HIV/AIDS is not over. Surely, those who become infected with the disease today are no longer doomed to only weeks and months to live longer, but it is a chronic disease. It is a disease filled with isolation and alienation for so many. It is a disease, still, filled with too much societal fear, stigma, and ignorance.

Young people today, and even some a generation or two from before, know nothing about the scary images the public experienced in the 80’s and early 90’s when the disease reached its epidemic height. Few parents and guardians feel comfortable sharing these past horror stories with their teens knowing full well they are exploring their sexuality and taking active risks.

At Flowers Community Initiatives, we take the education and the nurturing of our youth seriously. We provide a public service to young people and their communities with compassion, dedication, and consistency. We consider our track record a critical and important role that can still change the trajectory of a single youth and keep one more teen from becoming infected with HIV disease.

According to the Centers for Disease Control,  people under 25 are estimated to make up HALF of all new HIV infections in the U.S. Sixty (60%) percent of new HIV/AIDS cases reported each year are teenage girls aged 13-19.

  • Fact: Many young people do not know the basic facts about HIV risk and prevention. 
  • Fact: A large number of young people participate in unprotected, multiple partnered, unsafe sexual activity, and lack critical information regarding the spread of HIV.

What We Need

We need to reach our monetary campaign goal as quickly as possible in order begin implementation of our 2015-2016 DTYBOA program.

After 9 consecutive years of educating and helping prevent HIV infection among high school students through art education, we need your help.

We lost our funding. Next year is our 10th Anniversary of producing DTYBOA in Bay Area High Schools.

We promote the program via DVD on HIV education to high schools. Teachers build their curriculum around the art contest and use the program as a vehicle for both inspiring creativity, learning art technique, and raising awareness on this sensitive subject. Students are encouraged to create art works such as sculptures, paintings, drawings, textile works and photographs around the theme “Don’t Turn Your Back on AIDS”.

We offer underserved communities new opportunities. We level the playing field by offering art supplies and materials, so that low income, predominantly minority communities can participate.

Since it takes money to make money, we accept all non-monetary donations that will enable us to offer “perks” in exchange to fund donors. Non-monetary donations include the following: caps and t-shirts, art and ceramics, time-shares and vacations, gift certificates for upscale tangible goods, restaurants, etc.

After 9 consecutive years of educating and helping prevent HIV infection among high school students through art education, we need your help.

We lost our funding. Next year is our 10th Anniversary of producing DTYBOA in Bay Area High Schools.

We promote the program via DVD on HIV education to high schools. Teachers build their curriculum around the art contest and use the program as a vehicle for both inspiring creativity, learning art technique, and raising awareness on this sensitive subject. Students are encouraged to create art works such as sculptures, paintings, drawings, textile works and photographs around the theme “Don’t Turn Your Back on AIDS”.

We offer underserved communities new opportunities. We level the playing field by offering art supplies and materials, so that low income, predominantly minority communities can participate.

Since it takes money to make money, we accept all non-monetary donations that will enable us to offer “perks” in exchange to fund donors. Non-monetary donations include the following: caps and t-shirts, art and ceramics, time-shares and vacations, gift certificates for upscale tangible goods, restaurants, etc.

The Impact

Over the years, students, parents, teachers, and community leaders have a high regard for our public service contributions and value our work. They acknowledge our novel and unique approach to a sensitive and too often too personal issue. They give us feedback and tell us stories about the personal growth and development they witness in their young people who have been a part of our DTYBOA program.

On the surface, we address HIV infection and empower artistic expression and understanding about a global and social health dilemma. However, we have learned that teens deal with and gain insight into so many other aspects of their personal lives while working on their art pieces. They open up, they mature, and they meet their true selves from the inside out for the first time.

To document the community response, we asked an outsider to gauge our program’s achievements and successes.

According to a 2011 independent and objective evaluation:

  • Eighty one percent (81%) of participating students increased their knowledge about HIV awareness and learned how to educate others about HIV prevention.
  • Eighty six percent (86%) of participating students reported having talked to their peers about HIV/AIDS; the same percentage of students (86%) report that DTYBOA has prompted them to encourage their friends to practice safe sex. 
  • One hundred percent (100%) of responding teachers reported participating in or witnessing a conversation on safer sex among their students about HIV/AIDS.

Risks & Challenges

We’ve all been teenagers before. Some of use listened and some didn’t. Today, we the increase distractions of social media, expanded networks, and immediate at-your-fingertips peer approval or disapproval, young people face a lot more risk and challenges.

In 2010, 13 and 24 year olds accounted for about 26% of all new HIV infections, but almost 60% of youths with HIV in the U.S. don't know they are infected.

  • In a MAC AIDS Foundation study, the majority of teens between 12 and 17 did not think they were at risk for HIV and their awareness of HIV and how to prevent it is low. Only two-thirds of American teens know that HIV is a sexually transmitted disease.
  • Health educators, teachers, and policy makers must dramatically readjust their approach and take young people’s perceptions and perspectives into account.

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Tell folks about this site and our need and ask them to donate.
  • Forward this site link to your list-serves to friends, family, and others.
  • Contact us with new and fresh ideas for raising funds for our cause

According to a 2011 independent and
objective evaluation:

Eighty one percent (81%) of participating students
     increased their knowledge about HIV awareness and learned how to educate
     others about HIV prevention.


Eighty six percent (86%) of participating students
     reported having talked to their peers about HIV/AIDS; the same percentage
     of students (86%) report that DTYBOA has prompted them to encourage their
     friends to practice safe sex.  


One hundred percent (100%) of responding teachers
     reported participating in or witnessing a conversation on safer sex among
     their students about HIV/AIDS.

Risks
& Challenges
We’ve all been teenagers before.
Some of use listened and some didn’t. Today, we the increase distractions of
social media, expanded networks, and immediate at-your-fingertips peer approval
or disapproval, young people face a lot more risk and challenges.
In 2010, 13 and 24 year olds
accounted for about 26% of all new HIV infections, but almost 60% of
youths with HIV in the U.S. don't know they are infected.

In a
     MAC AIDS Foundation study, the majority of teens between 12 and 17 did
     not think they were at risk for HIV and their awareness of HIV and
     how to prevent it is low. Only two-thirds of American teens know that HIV
     is a sexually transmitted disease.
Health
     educators, teachers, and policy makers must dramatically readjust their
     approach and take young people’s perceptions and perspectives into
     account.

Other Ways You Can Help

Tell
     folks about this site and our need and ask them to donate.
Forward
     this site link to your list-serves to friends, family, and others.
Contact
     us with new and fresh ideas for raising funds for our cause

story:
Hello. My name is Jack Busby. I was born in Tucson Arizona in 1949. I've been an artist most of my life and I've been involved in retail for over 30 years.

My campaign is to raise capital to have my Lil Fish dish project to move forward. This project has been in the works for 5 years. I created a five piece place setting of dinnerware, shown in the video above, using my fish designs. I have a contact at the Dallas Mart who sells to the major upscale department stores. She has remarked that the setting I'm putting together is really nice and very marketable.

With your contributions, I can get legal representation and have a full line of prototypes made by a local ceramic artisan for both the factory and the showroom in Dallas. This is a huge opportunity for me and the people on my team. It will allow uw to realize this application and several more of the 38 other applications for my fish designs.

To see my fine art website: http://jackbusbyartist.com/faq.html

To see my Facebook page: https://www.facebook.com/jackbusbyartist?fref=ts

Thank you.

story:
We are raising money for our Scholarship Fund in order to assist graduating high school seniors to go on to pursue their passion in the arts.  This includes all art forms including music, drama, painting, sculpture, design, ceramics, culinary, photography and anything else that is considered "the Arts".  



Background: Robert graduated from Otis Art Institute where he received his Master's degree in Fine Arts. He has been making high fire ceramics for over 50 years.  He and his wife, Patricia, created a scholarship fund 13 years ago to encourage art students to go on to college.  The fund has awarded 63 scholarships to date.  All the profit from the sales of Robert's porcelain and photography is awarded to graduating high school art students.


Purpose: By taking an expedition to Mount Everest, this campaign will promote awareness of our fund and give these young artists the recognition they deserve.  Robert strongly feels we need to acknowledge these emerging artists.

Goal: Our funding campaign will allow us to give more scholarships to other schools in Sonoma County.  ALL funds raised here will go directly to graduating high school students.  


What We Need & What You Get

  • We are looking to raise $15,000, all of which will go to graduating art students.  The cost of the trip itself will be funded by Robert.
  • Help us reach our goal.  All shapes, sizes and colors will vary, every piece will be handmade, signed and numbered by Robert. 
  • Here is what we offer:


For a $35 donation, you will receive a SMALL hand-thrown tumbler finished with Robert's special crystalline glaze.  All pieces will be numbered and signed.


For a $55 donation, you will receive a larger hand-thrown tumbler finished with Robert's special crystalline glaze.  All pieces will be numbered and signed.


For a $75 donation, you will receive two larger hand-thrown tumblers finished with Robert's special crystalline glaze.  All pieces will be numbered and signed.


For a $100 donation, you will receive a limited edition piece that will be hand-thrown at the highest altitude that Robert reaches on Mount Everest.  He will start throwing at about 12,000 feet and will continue to throw at every plateau in an effort to reach the ultimate goal of over 17,000 feet.  The piece that is thrown at the highest altitude will be reproduced by casting and will be hand-signed, numbered and glazed in one of Robert's crystalline glazes. These will be limited to 200 pieces at which time the mold will be destroyed.


For a $500 donation, you will receive:
  • One set of 4 crystalline-glazed mugs
  • One limited edition piece (see the $100 item)
  • A One-Hour Demonstration for You and Your Friends

For ALL Contributions:
  • You have a choice to come to Robert's studio to meet him and pick up your pieces or they will be shipped at no cost.
  • Whether the goal is reached or not, all funds go to graduating art students to assist them in pursuing their future in the arts. 
*Please note:
  • A tumbler is without a handle, as opposed to mugs that have a handle.
  • Colors, shapes, and sizes vary.

The Impact

  • Our funding will allow us to expand to other schools which will allow us to give more scholarships in Sonoma County. 
  • We will be bringing attention to the need for more art in our schools
  • In the last 13 years 63 scholarships have been awarded.
  • The evidence is in..."The arts create critical thinking".  We need more young folks developing this skill.

Risks & Challenges

There are many risks in climbing to the Mount Everest North base camp.  High altitude sickness and frostbite while Robert treks to altitude and works on the wheel are our main concerns.  The reason for throwing at different altitudes on the way up is to make sure that Robert is able to throw at least one piece on the mountain.

  • In order to assure success, Robert has been practicing by kneading clay in a deep freeze at about 3ºF.  A portable wheel (donated by Speedball Corp, thank you, thank you!) arrived last week. Robert took the wheel into our friend Stem's walk-in freezer to continue to practice at low temperatures. It was a challenge but he was able to make a nice vase in about 12 minutes, no frost bite!
  • Robert recently went to Mammoth Mountain and journeyed between 9,000 and 11,200 feet to test how his body reacted at those altitudes and had no issues. Over 17,000 feet will be a further challenge.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you aren't able to financially contribute at this time, we appreciate your interest and invite you to let your friends know about this expedition and our scholarship fund.

  • Support our campaign by following us on Facebook @RobertWeissCeramics
  • Use Indiegogo's share tools to help us get the word out!

Robert took the wheel into our friend Stem's walk-in freezer to continue to practice at low temperatures. It was a challenge but he was able to make a nice vase in about 12 minutes, no frost bite!
Robert recently went to Mammoth Mountain and journeyed between 9,000 and 11,200 feet to test how his body reacted at those altitudes and had no issues. Over 17,000 feet will be a further challenge.
