story:
Short Summary

Contributors fund ideas they can be passionate about and to people they trust. Here are some things about what we are doing in 2016:

  • My name is Chris, I'm a fine artist from Torrance, California.
  • This campaign has been the center of my life since 2011.
  • You will help me introduce a new aesthetic to the art world to inspire more people to prioritize their passion.
  • You will create jobs in art production and sales opportunities, giving more aspiring entrepreneurs the chance to liberate themselves from 9-5 jobs and be in charge of the time and work-style.

We are in the digital era, this entrepreneurial work-style is more sustainable than it was in the industrial era or agricultural era before that. My vision is an autonomous workforce where people are working from laptops, making a passive income and traveling in style wearing the fashion. The "entrepreneur" is no longer a career choice for the 1% who opt out of corporate culture. It is a way of life that can be embraced in and out of one's professional life. It is a lifestyle and it is cooler than it ever has been before . We are just making the back-end of business attractive on the front end too.

What We Need & What You Get

To break it down for folks in more detail:

  • We need $30,000 to be in production. To bee transparent and specific, We need $1,500 for the printing equipment, $200 a month for three years for the software that helps clients customize their fashion, and $1,000 a month in working capital to pay two production employees and one administrative employee, while our sales force works on 100% commission.
  • The unique perks are, free gear, free invites to art shows, an instant opportunity to make money based on referral!
  • If we don't reach our entire goal, the funds will go to producing minimum-order merchandise through a sub-contractor and the store will be opened and marketed online.
  • We want to bring production in house to scale faster to feed off of quality, work culture, and throw a huge opening reception art gallery party to invite people who helped us out to. 

The Impact

Let's explain more about our campaign to let people know the difference their contribution will make:

  • Our project is truly valuable to the contributor and to the world because our guests get to participate in introducing the entrepreneurial lifestyle to the masses. This is great for the world at large because it will bring attention to the entrepreneurs who need funding or support in making an impact on society. Look back and remember what skateboarding lifestyle brands did for skateboarders. What Ralph Lauren did for Polo as a sport and what Banana Republic did for the safari lifestyle and culture. The CHRISTOPHER JAMES HUGHES is a lifestyle brand built to amplify the lifestyle of entrepreneurs around the world and offer an additional income stream for entrepreneurs.
  • I've had multiple clothing, each with a concept and ethos. I owned a screen-printing and design company for ten years and it paid for my lifestyle and college. I saw this opportunity to do it better than it has ever been done before by putting the ready-to-wear fashion on the front line and offer a division of fashion that is bespoke and set for customization.
  • This business model worked for me and it can work for many others. I have so much faith in this idea, I was willing to donate $40,000 worth of screen-printing equipment to a trade school in L.A. while retaining my long-term clientele and the brand I operated from, which is my birth name, CHRISTOPHER JAMES HUGHES. I could have sold the equipment, but who know what would become of it only a year later. I wanted more students to learn and keep the legacy alive. I now teach the art-form independently for my city because I care about keeping the trade alive. This demonstrates that I know the state of the decorative apparel industry and when I see a need in the marketplace, I do whatever it takes to position myself in a way to fulfill it and maximize on any opportunity to down-size or scale-up. What matters most is the value generated and the return value captured.

Risks & Challenges

People value transparency. The risks and obstacles we may face on the way to achieving our goal are that the fashion may be unpopular.

  • I know the state of the decorative apparel industry and with the technology only recently available, I will be able to capture a market in the fashion industry that want's customization fashion in record time. I'll be capable of fulfilling that need.
  • I plan to solve these challenges by intensive outreach and campaigning. I want to educate a world that the fashion company on the runway can also be the production company your team hires to make your T-shirts, sweatshirts or tank tops for an event.

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand that some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean you can't help:

  • Please get the word out and make some noise about our campaign.
  • Remember to use the Indiegogo share tools!

And that's all there is to it.
story_txt:
Short Summary Contributors fund ideas they can be passionate about and to people they trust. Here are some things about what we are doing in 2016:  My name is Chris, I'm a fine artist from Torrance, California. This campaign has been the center of my life since 2011. You will help me introduce a new aesthetic to the art world to inspire more people to prioritize their passion.
You will create jobs in art production and sales opportunities, giving more aspiring entrepreneurs the chance to liberate themselves from 9-5 jobs and be in charge of the time and work-style.  We are in the digital era, this entrepreneurial work-style is more sustainable than it was in the industrial era or agricultural era before that. My vision is an autonomous workforce where people are working from laptops, making a passive income and traveling in style wearing the fashion. The "entrepreneur" is no longer a career choice for the 1% who opt out of corporate culture. It is a way of life that can be embraced in and out of one's professional life. It is a lifestyle and it is cooler than it ever has been before . We are just making the back-end of business attractive on the front end too.   What We Need & What You Get To break it down for folks in more detail:  We need $30,000 to be in production. To bee transparent and specific, We need $1,500 for the printing equipment, $200 a month for three years for the software that helps clients customize their fashion, and $1,000 a month in working capital to pay two production employees and one administrative employee, while our sales force works on 100% commission. The unique perks are, free gear, free invites to art shows, an instant opportunity to make money based on referral! If we don't reach our entire goal, the funds will go to producing minimum-order merchandise through a sub-contractor and the store will be opened and marketed online.
We want to bring production in house to scale faster to feed off of quality, work culture, and throw a huge opening reception art gallery party to invite people who helped us out to.     The Impact Let's explain more about our campaign to let people know the difference their contribution will make:  Our project is truly valuable to the contributor and to the world because our guests get to participate in introducing the entrepreneurial lifestyle to the masses. I know the state of the decorative apparel industry and with the technology only recently available, I will be able to capture a market in the fashion industry that want's customization fashion in record time. Remember to use the Indiegogo share tools!   And that's all there is to it.

story:
Short Summary

El Corazón y la Muerte is the most important exhibition of contemporary dark surrealist artists from Mexico to be organized in Europe for the past few years.

Curated by cult artist Kikyz1313, this exhibition showcases the talent of 12 among the most talented young artists active in Mexico today:

  • Alejandro Barrón
  • Rodrigo Cifuentes
  • Mario Cinquemani
  • Ricardo Fernandez
  • Victor Hugo Jácome
  • José Luis López Galván
  • Patrick Mallow
  • Román Miranda
  • Rafael Rodríguez
  • Rolando Sosa
  • Talía Yañez
  • and Kikyz1313

The show has been organized and planned since 2015 together with Giovanni Giusti, founder of GalleryX Dublin.

GalleryX is the only gallery in Ireland, and one of the very few in Europe, devoted to dark, surrealist and alternative art. Since its inception in late 2014, it is quickly gathering an enthusiastic following in Ireland and abroad.

The exhibition will be presented in Dublin from 28 October to 26 November 2016. However, the caliber of the work is such that it deserves to be seen by a wider audience. We want to bring the exhibition to a number of European capitals in the first half of 2017.

Your help will allow us to fund this European tour, which may include Rome, Zurich, Berlin, Stockholm... and we are open to suggestions!

At the end of the European tour the exhibition will return to Mexico, for a final showing in the Museo de la Ciudad of Querétaro.

The funds collected will also help us produce a high quality printed catalog for the exhibition – which is also one of the perks.

What We Need & What You Get

Our basic campaign goal of €5000 will help pay for:

  • the production of a high-quality printed catalog for the exhibition
  • transport costs for the exhibition to travel among European cities
  • live costs of the host galleries in other European cities

Any receipts in excess of the goal will be used to advertise the exhibition and for bringing the curators to Europe.

In exchange for your help, you will have the possibility of receiving an exclusive signed and numbered giclée print of one of the works in the exhibition. These prints will be produced only for backers and will never be made available to the general public. There are only 50 of these available.

Other perks include copies of the catalog signed by the artists, the possibility of adding your name on the printed catalog itself, and special deals on the original works!

Should we not reach our funding goal, the organizers will in any case print the catalog, if necessary covering the shortfall.

The Impact

El Corazón y la Muerte is the first exhibition of this kind to reach Europe. At GalleryX, we are very excited to be able to showcase such amazing works and such talented artists.

In the words of Kikyz1313:

“There is something hidden and even attractive in death: a curious call that keep us trying to solve the eternal mystery of our purpose in this world. This is especially true in Mexican culture, in which mystery and mourning are almost transformed into a glorification of life, where the two extremes of existence find a balance. Because, rather than fleeing or denying their destinies, Mexicans have a deep respect for the eventualities of life.”

It would be a pity if this exhibition were only to be shown in Dublin. Ireland is a small country and it’s not at the center of the European art scene, both geographically and historically. The impact of the exhibition would be much greater if it were able to tour many other countries before returning to Mexico for a final show and being dispersed among the collectors.

Your contribution will make this exhibition an even greater success than we are expecting it to be.

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you can’t help financially, you can still share your passion for these amazing artists by sharing and inviting your friends to participate using the Indiegogo tools.

Also, check out our Facebook page fb.com/galleryxdublin and share news of the exhibition far and wide!

story:
"Finally, an online resource for real working artists in all stages of their career. Ann Landi brings us sage advice through smart writing, lively podcasts, in-depth artist interviews, "Under The Radar," and more. It is long overdue, and working artists, like me, cannot help but be inspired and encouraged by this wealth of information. Bravo!" Jeannie Motherwell

"Vasari21 really fills a void. Before I found the site, any professional questions I had were answered or not by luck of Google. Often I couldn't find the complete information I was looking for. Finally there is a resource that does have answers for working artists with great articles that are refreshingly focuses on the craft and difficulty we face in choosing this life." James Austin Murray

 

It’s been more than a year since I first reached out to you for your support for Vasari21, and nearly a year since the site launched.  I had two primary goals—to spotlight artists who deserve more attention than they get from online or print venues, and to give useful information members can apply to their careers and their lives. The kind of “service” stories you won’t find elsewhere. Such as how to do a studio visit, what do curators look for, how do critics think, what are a dealer’s obligations to his or her artists, how do artists handle “post-show blues,” how to bring your website up to speed, how to negotiate a contract with a gallery, smart ways artists use social media, and some common scams and shams in the art world.

Each week, in “Under the Radar,” I’ve profiled the many terrific artists who aren’t getting the attention of the mainstream or art press—like those mentioned in the video—but also including August Muth, a master of holography; Kate Petley, a painter of smart and seductive abstractions; installation artist Brian McCutcheon; Marc Baseman, maestro of a manic miniature universe; the wildly inventive sculptor and trapeze artist Jamie Hamilton; Martha Russo and Lorrie Fredette, who expand the boundaries of ceramics; and a special homage to mon amie Parisienne, Anne Ferrer (one of whose installations made from parachute fabric is below). They are artists of different backgrounds and all ages, and their stories are often inspiring tales of determination and true grit.

In “Ripe for Rediscovery,” I’ve brought some half-forgotten but wonderful talents to your attention—like Francis Picabia, Dorothy Hood, and Lee Lozano. There are also artist essays on the site, personal reminiscences, and some categories that have languished a bit—like “Did You Know”—because I discovered, as a staff of one, that I can only produce so much copy a week. In essence, what I’m producing each month is the equivalent of a magazine.

And in Vasari21 Radio, I’ve brought you podcasts from some of the leading figures in the field: artists Ursula von Rydingsvard, Eric Fischl, and Ellen Harvey (below); dealers Hal Bromm and Francis Nauman; critics Peter Plagens and Christopher Knight; curators Tricia Paik, Dan Cameron, and René Barilleaux. The half-hour interviews are tailored to bring you not only the stories of their lives but advice for artists in pursuing their careers.

I’ve recently introduced a spotlight on collectors, and hope to present more of these, so that my audience can understand their passions and prefererences.

This is not a “blog,” as I made clear in an editor’s note. If there’s one thing I’ve learned in a 30-year career in journalism, it’s how to be a reporter and how to present material in readable prose (no “artspeak” allowed here). And, if I do say so myself, the visuals are far superior to what you generally get from an online site.

The rewards have been incredible. My 500 members have proved to be a great resource for information about the art world and have provided suggestions for stories they’d like to see. I labeled Vasari21 “interactive” when I first launched, hoping at that point to introduce a members’ forum, like Facebook, but this turned out to be expensive and impractical. Instead the site became interactive in ways I could not have predicted—through social media and Vasari21, I’ve been able to help a photographer land a spot in a group show (Carol Rose Brown, whose evocative digital print, Song of Experience, is shown below); another member piqued the interest of a curator on the West Coast; and when artists travel, I’m able to connect them with other members. Every weekday, I post on Facebook and Instagram a Vasari21 “Pic of the Day”—and those seem to be generating interest and valuable connections. Best of all are the friendships I've made with artists, which I hope will grow for many years to come.

 

Oh, and there’s also a weekly newsletter to let 1000-plus interested subscribers know about members’ shows and awards and see the work of newcomers to the site; give a shout-out for new editorial on Vasari21; and solicit information for reports on the site. (Peter Roux, whose landscape Suspension (east sky) is below, among others, has been a huge help for stories on artists’ relationships with art advisers and dealers.)

 

Some of the issues I’d like to tackle in the future include the value of advertising and of public relations firms, how to keep your collector base happy, what are some grants and retreats you may not know about, what are some unexpected health benefits of making art, how do artists use crowd funding to finance new projects (or just stay afloat), and how do husband-and-wife artists interact and maintain the state of the union.

When I first launched, I hoped to use a subscription model (one-year, two-years, lifetime, and so on). This also proved a thorny job for me and my webmeisters. So now I’m operating more along the lines of NPR and PBS, with an eye to doing subscriptions down the road. Your contributions and your support keep Vasari21 alive and kicking, and allow me to continue to bring you the kind of quality editorial you’ve come to expect.

Perks are rather modest this time around, but for donors of $100 or more I'm offering the trusty, stain-resistant (but probably not immune to paint) Vasari21 apron again. For those who chip in $500 or more, I'll throw in a copy of Patti Smith's Just Kids, maybe the best coming-of-age-as-an artist memoir ever. 

My heartfelt thanks for your continuing support.

 

More from Vasari21 members:

"Vasari21 is exactly the sort of e-zine you would expect from  a veteran art journalist, someone who has seen it all and written about it all and wanted a place where she could express her vision of what art reporting should be for those who make art, those who love art, and those who collect art." Leslie Parke

"A site like no other, Vasari21 is an important resource for working artists of all levels, providing lively podcasts by leading members of the artistic community and insightful writing that covers the many issues artists face today, including practical advice, historical perspectives, and most interestingly, regular profiles on artists that we would otherwise never get to see."  Leslie Wayne

"Vasari21 is intelligent substance beautifully presented. Free from art jargon, hype, and fad, Ann’s focus is illuminating and incisive. The community that has formed around Vasari21 is reflective of its timely dedicated voice to capturing artists working now. As an artist, the connections that I have made through Vasari 21 have been life changing. As a pro bono contributing writer to Vasari 21, working for Ann as an editor and publisher, has been a privilege."  Millicent Young

"Were Giorgio Vasari alive today, the chief biographer of 16th-century Italian artists would no doubt be running a website like Vasari21.  Through thoughtful essays and lively podcasts, Landi has created an invaluable platform for information-sharing among artists and those who love contemporary art.  Amazingly comprehensive in scope, Vasari21 is one of the best resources on the web for discovering new artists, looking at new work, and learning about practical matters, critical opinions, or frequently asked questions about today's art and those who make it." David Rubin, independent curator

"Finally, an intelligent and comprehensive site for practicing studio artists that focuses on the  pertinent issues and challenges  of this most difficult profession.  Ann’s brilliant writing, sprinkled with just the right touch of her wickedly delightful sense of humor, is highly informative, underscores her knowledge of the craft, and always keeps me wanting to read more!" Karen Jilly

 

The "campaign card" image is Elisabeth Condon's Fear of Life Can Be A Subtle Thing (2015), Ink, acrylic and other mediums on linen, 59  by 59 inches.
"

story:
WHAT ?
 

A Blacklight Dome of 2,5 meters high / 5 meters width – built out of PVC material, covered out of 1 or more layers of flame retardant cloth. (see picture)
Inside : A Blacklight is facing a large white Canvas, covered with Glow-in-the-dark paint.
People stand behind the Canvas and interact with each other, thus creating graceful, shiny silhouettes (see picture).
Interaction is the main ingredient, Harmony is the only challenge, no predefined theme or discipline is imposed. You can come as a group and team up to share an emotion, an idea, a concept, a vibe with the audience... Or take a leap of faith and add to / create a spontaneous act with a complete stranger !
Not feeling like being in the spot(black)lights ? No problem! People are also invited to express themselves by modulating the angle/intensity of the Blacklight, as well as painting/playing with the Glow-in-the-dark paint.
We hope to immortalize this unique gathering of free souls with videos, pictures, live sketching... Get in touch with us if you would like to help with documenting the performances.
 


HOW ?
 

All material will be bought prior to the festival and brought to the venue by car.

The Dome Theater will be built on site then covered with flame retardant cloth.
The cloth will then be painted while the Canvas will be hung up inside of the dome and painted with Glow-in-the-dark paint.
Finally, the Blacklight will be installed and set up....
And we're all ready to go !
 

 


WHERE ?

At the Dutch Edition of Burning Man Festival! A beautiful, spacious, relaxing countryside location in the Veluwe region of The Netherlands (Approximately an hour drive from Amsterdam).
The event sold out in a record time and is expected to become a one of a kind yearly European gathering of people sharing same interests and concerns for creativity, self expression, freedom, tolerance, sustainability, social participation, civic responsibility and experimentation. Don't expect to find a crowd of spectators here, each and everyone is encouraged to participate, to gift the whole community with his/her personal and immediate interpretation of his/her surroundings. In this egalitarian, kind of settings, people have as much to learn from another as to teach another. Each individual thought/questioning, when shared, blossom into as many bridges to reach to, bound with and understand ''the other''.
This virtuous circle is what makes this event so special : more than a festival, a full immersive experience into the absolute necessity of (re)creating as a mean for human progress.

 

 

WHEN ?
 

The last weekend of July. More precisely : on Saturday 30st and Sunday 31st July 2016.

So, exactly 1 month to go !!! ;)
 

 

WHAT DO WE NEED ?
Your support, your ideas, your smiles, your hugs...
And as you probably have guessed, financial help :P
 

We need money for the materials :
PVC, cloth, canvas, glow-in-the-dark paint (which is quite pricey), brushes, paper, etc...
Blacklight
Petrol for the car
Various tools, ladders, ...

Signs

Speakers/possibly a sound system...

 

So if you like our idea, please show us some LOVE! Every donation counts :)

In case there's money leftover, we will donate it to fund other Burning Man projects.
 

 

Thanks !

Bedankt !

Merci !


Hugs,

Marie, Vanessa and Sander

(Text by Marie, Pics by Sander)
story_txt: WHAT ? A Blacklight Dome of 2,5 meters high / 5 meters width – built out of PVC material, covered out of 1 or more layers of flame retardant cloth. (see picture)Inside : A Blacklight is facing a large white Canvas, covered with Glow-in-the-dark paint.People stand behind the Canvas and interact with each other, thus creating graceful, shiny silhouettes (see picture).Interaction is the main ingredient, Harmony is the only challenge, no predefined theme or discipline is imposed. You can come as a group and team up to share an emotion, an idea, a concept, a vibe with the audience... Or take a leap of faith and add to / create a spontaneous act with a complete stranger !Not feeling like being in the spot(black)lights ? No problem! People are also invited to express themselves by modulating the angle/intensity of the Blacklight, as well as painting/playing with the Glow-in-the-dark paint.We hope to immortalize this unique gathering of free souls with videos, pictures, live sketching... Get in touch with us if you would like to help with documenting the performances. HOW ? All material will be bought prior to the festival and brought to the venue by car.The Dome Theater will be built on site then covered with flame retardant cloth.The cloth will then be painted while the Canvas will be hung up inside of the dome and painted with Glow-in-the-dark paint.Finally, the Blacklight will be installed and set up....And we're all ready to go !  WHERE ?At the Dutch Edition of Burning Man Festival! A beautiful, spacious, relaxing countryside location in the Veluwe region of The Netherlands (Approximately an hour drive from Amsterdam).The event sold out in a record time and is expected to become a one of a kind yearly European gathering of people sharing same interests and concerns for creativity, self expression, freedom, tolerance, sustainability, social participation, civic responsibility and experimentation. Don't expect to find a crowd of spectators here, each and everyone is encouraged to participate, to gift the whole community with his/her personal and immediate interpretation of his/her surroundings. In this egalitarian, kind of settings, people have as much to learn from another as to teach another. Each individual thought/questioning, when shared, blossom into as many bridges to reach to, bound with and understand ''the other''.This virtuous circle is what makes this event so special : more than a festival, a full immersive experience into the absolute necessity of (re)creating as a mean for human progress.  WHEN ? The last weekend of July. More precisely : on Saturday 30st and Sunday 31st July 2016.So, exactly 1 month to go !!! ;)  WHAT DO WE NEED ?Your support, your ideas, your smiles, your hugs...And as you probably have guessed, financial help :P We need money for the materials :PVC, cloth, canvas, glow-in-the-dark paint (which is quite pricey), brushes, paper, etc...BlacklightPetrol for the carVarious tools, ladders, ...SignsSpeakers/possibly a sound system... So if you like our idea, please show us some LOVE! Every donation counts :)In case there's money leftover, we will donate it to fund other Burning Man projects.  Thanks !Bedankt !Merci !Hugs,Marie, Vanessa and Sander(Text by Marie, Pics by Sander)

story:
Founder of Webb International

Hello, my name is Thomas Webb, I grew up in Indiana, but I now live in the Bay Area in northern California.  It has been a long road, and a very interesting life.  I served in the Marine Corps as a machine gunner for 4 years, locations served in include: Afghanistan, Australia, Japan, and the Philippines.  I have traveled to many other countries, and through my travels I discovered that even in different cultures people share a common set of values.  These values that connect us all is shown in much of the artwork, which I discovered along my journey.  It is my pleasure to share this amazing artwork with all of you. 

For more artwork please check out our website:  www.webbinternational.org


How Webb International began

Now, I love to travel, it is my passion, and during my travels, I have found amazing and exotic artwork. Artwork, which has never be seen in America, until now! We have begun importing artwork from around the world, but in order to provide even more artwork and create both sustainable domestic and foreign jobs, we need your help to fund our first few initial shipments.  Our goal is to import from many different cultures from all over the world.  As promised in the video, for every tree cut down to make our products.  We will plant 10 trees in their place.  Now that is sustainability!!!

Why we need your help

The biggest issue we have is funding, we need $10,000 for travel and shipping expenses, and $20,000 to buy products from different countries all over the world, and I have personally invested $15,000 of my own money (this is not a one sided funding campaign).  Webb International always take care of those who help our cause, so your rewards are at the top of our priority list, you will likely receive your rewards sooner than the listed dates.  

Giving back

Each year, Webb International will give 10% of your net profits to help worthy causes.  Webb International believes in the greater good for all!!!  We are all in this together, welcome to Webb International.

story:
What is Heart Works 
  • We're a small group of philanthropic entrepreneurs who want to bring the Heart back into giving. On our site you can buy original art pieces and select charities for your money to go toward all at once. Donate to great causes easily and often while filling your home with amazing products from talented individuals.
  • By contributing to the campaign you will help us support great charities, great artists and get us one step closer to our goals including supporting great charity organizations and helping the Millions of people facing hunger, poverty, disease. 
Heart Works is an innovative way to buy things that you love for a cause; give back to charities that you choose at checkout with each purchase. 

How it Works

Step 1: Artists list their work on our site and set the terms of their selling with us. When you buy their products from us through our website and live events, you provide them the opportunity to continue being creative and artistic.

Step 2: The net proceeds from your purchases are then split two ways. Fifty percent is provided to the artist who created the original piece/product. The other fifty percent is directed to a U.S. based charitable organization chosen by the you at checkout!  The impact of your purchase not only affects the artists, your communities, and millions of people in the U.S.

Charities we'll support (& more)

Why we've started this Campaign

Let us Break it Down:

We have a great website and team, but we've hit a financial hurdle and need to raise money to secure the following:

  • Warehouse space, to store and manage inventory from talented artists. This will allow us to ship your orders quickly and efficiently.
  • Promotion: advertising Heart Works will allow us to recruit talented artists and work with them. 
  • Order fulfillment for our first 3 months of operation including packaging & shipping inventory
If we do not reach our entire goal  funds will go toward promoting Heart works in an effort to recruit as many artists as possible.
More Specifically
Warehouse Space: 1 month rental agreement $1,500
Order fulfillment: first 3 months $5,000 (shipping & packaging inventory)
Promotion: $3,500 (flyers, website ads, commercial shorts etc.)

The Impact

The Need (in the U.S):

  • As of 2015 564,708 people faced homelessness 
  • At this very moment 1 in 6 people are facing hunger 
  • 1 in 3 women are victims of domestic violence
  • Over 20 million people have been diagnosed with Cancer
  • More than 250,000 children enter the foster system each year
These statistics are from the U.S alone. And the list goes on of ways billions of people are suffering each day. 
There are Amazing charities & organizations in place that work tirelessly to combat these issues and more. At Heart Works we want to support those initiatives. 
Heart Works is an innovative way to buy things that you love for a cause; give back to charities that you choose at checkout with each purchase. 

Risks & Challenges

We're a new company and the hurdles inevitable. Finding the right warehouse space, hiring new staff and finding artists to work with are just some of the challenges we'll face. 

  • We are a small team of dedicated, innovative and creative professionals, so we're sure to find the best way to get past these challenges. With your contribution we can meet some of the major start up costs such as managing and shipping inventory. 
  • Contributions from this campaign will strictly go toward securing warehouse space, packaging and shipping the first few months worth of order & promoting Heart Works (in order to recruit talented artist) 

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you can't contribute, here are other ways to help:

  • Help us get the word out and make some noise about our campaign!
  • Suggest Artists you think would we should reach out to
  • Send us a list of your favorite charities you want us to contribute to 

Thank you for your support! 

We are so grateful for you taking the time to check out our campaign!  

Please visit our website and don't hesitate to contact us (theheartworkscharity@gmail.com) with any suggestions or feedback you may have!

Also find us on:

Facebook, Twitter, Instagram, & YouTube

story:
Sometimes through sublime silence, or perhaps from an inner roar of cosmic proportions, it is always amazing how the Universe delivers its guidance to us. But no matter the mode of delivery, the omniscient message that is conveyed is undoubtedly the true wonder and gift. And when we receive such divine guidance, and are moved to action, prosperity of all sorts follows.

We were moved most inexplicably and humbly to create the Samadhi Oracle Deck and it is Our Wish that the Universal wisdom, truths and love contained within it help to serve as a life's compass whenever needed and to create an abundant flow of good things in Your life, dear one.

The insights conveyed through the deck are garnered from the ancient, beautiful and transcendental religion of India, Hinduism,  and have been lovingly selected to further strengthen Your innate connection to the Divine, with the hope and prayer of one day achieving the highest state of meditative consciousness, Samadhi.

The Universe brought us together over a decade ago to create a beautiful family and life and now we've used our Divine gift of togetherness to co-create the Samadhi Oracle Deck:) Though we're both devout Hindus, we have a deep respect for all religions, cultures and belief systems.

Sahil is a successful business owner and creates intuitive and moving poetry in his spare time. Jess is a work-at-home mom who loves to illustrate all things weird and wonderful.


Each Samadhi Oracle Deck contains:
  • 44 fully illustrated tarot-sized cards  (they're categorized as Deities, Sages, Symbols, Elements, Chakras and Mythological Creatures)
  • a beautifully written companion book, and
  • a sturdy magnetic flap box to house the book and cards
We're also offering select 11x16 inch prints of the most popular cards:

And 10 hand strung Chakra Meditation Malas:

If there's something special You'd like arranged please let us know and we'll try our very best to make it happen:)



We are eternally grateful to You, dear one, for supporting this vision and would appreciate Your help in spreading the word so that we can spread the love together.  

We've opted for flexible funding and set our goal at $8000 which essentially covers the cost of printing 200 complete decks. It's really important to us that we hit our goal (and even beyond that) so that we can reward each backer with freebies

If You'd like to chat to us directly about the deck or are interested in ordering it in bulk please do drop us an email: samadhioracledeck@gmail.com


*** PLEASE NOTE ***
The prices you see for each perk do not include shipping - these rates will be displayed once you've selected your perk and country of residence. Any questions... send us an email:)

story:
"Hearts tied to the past. Uncertain of the future. A rugged journey into the west, from the eyes of 6 brazen women and the men brave enough to love them."

The Story!.!

Peace Among Black Hills is a story of love, loss, and overcoming treacherous hardship and discrimination during the war with the Plains Indians of the North West.
One Star and Jacob were born on opposite sides of the same coin, as “half breeds”. An early act of compassion brings them together as children, but the war raging around them tears them apart. In order to be together, they will have to overcome miles, and years of separation when One Star is taken to the Carlisle Institute in Pennsylvania. After years at the Institute, One Star and her best friend, Melody escape the Institute and return to the ranch of her love, Jacob, only to find him gone.  One Star and Melody decide to explore their world and leave love behind them when Jacob does not return to his childhood home. They experience the hardships of the land, and collect a band of other Misfit girls along the way.
After realizing that none of them fit in with the civilization the world deems “Proper”, the girls make their way to a better life raising cattle in Montana. Along the way they encounter a series of unfortunate mishaps, the worst of which is the accidental death of the Silver City Sheriffs father in New Mexico, which One Star is blamed for.
The girls begin a hasty escape north to San Francisco, where they meet up with an equally transient bunch of young men that agree to help them drive the cattle, and low and behold, one of the young men is the long lost love, Jacob. But the Silver City Sheriff is hot on their trail.
Now that the group is complete, they must begin the treacherous journey north, through Oregon and Idaho, encountering every possible challenge the west has to offer along the way. They must try to reach Montana without being shot, trampled, captured by the Sheriff, or caught up by winter with 300 head of cattle in tow.
Its “Young Guns” meets “Dances with Wolves” with the perfect mix of true history and make believe, shining light on the amazing and gritty history of the Pacific Northwest.

We are Planted Roots!:

We often get caught up in the belief that local or independent films cant be as high quality or moving as big mainstream films.. Fortunately, this isn't true..
Why are independent films so important? Because they aren't just a story, they are art! They are a stepping stone for up-and-coming talent! They bring revenue to locations like our small town of Sandpoint, ID! They create a job source! They teach a new generation about film! There are so many reasons why independent films are important!

Filmmakers do not have a moral obligation to create socially conscious, empathy-inducing films, but films have the ability to to shine light on social issues, help comfort personal struggles, and help motivate great love and compassion for humanity.

Planted Roots Productions was founded by two small town sisters, Sarah and Hailey Hines in August 2015, with a goal of bringing artful, motivating movies back to the film community.

Our crew is dedicated to bringing high quality short and feature films that touch their audience, and we want to do it locally! We want to bring business to our beautiful town, while telling amazing stories.. Where do the sponsors funds go? Costumes, props, set dressing, location fee's, film permits, gas, equipment, and food..
Do you want to help sponsor an amazing local film, with talented local cast and crew? And get onscreen film credit for it? Here's your chance!

Why is this campaign important?
Because our story is important! Yes, its an action packed, gritty, scenic western film. But it is also a love story that uplifts and empowers the audience and shines light on major historic events that are often downplayed or forgotten. Oh and not to mention, the butt kicking is done by a group of girls!

Why choose our project over so many others?
 Well that is completely up to you! But if it was me, I would back this project... We have already funded $2,000 of this project ourselves, because we are passionate about it and believe so strongly in its success! Everyone needs a good western in their lives, right? But its not just our amazing story that your supporting, its our amazing cast and crew who are all donating their time and energy to this project because they believe in it, too! If so many people are willing to volunteer their time to making this happen, it couldn't be that bad, right?

Where will your donation go?
Your donation goes to paying for Equipment Fee's, Location Fee's, Gasoline, Lodging, Costumes, and Food. We have the amazing people, now we just need help funding the other key parts of making a great film. Every little bit helps!


So there you have it! Please Like, Share, Send Happy Vibes, Donate, anything you can do is appreciated more than you know!

story:
As a transgender activist and filmmaker I've always been searching for representations in the media of people like me and so I realized maybe I should do something about that myself. So I wrote a script for a short film and came up with this crazy idea that everyone on screen would be trans-identified. I figured, how many movies have I seen in my life with an all cisgender (non-trans) cast...why not try something a little different? Why not show everyone who views this film the multiplicity of ways in which trans people can look, talk, and move about in the world? 

Since there is no one singular trans experience why would I pigeonhole myself by creating a short film that fits neatly into an 'LGBT genre?' The LGBTQ experience is as vast and diverse as any other community and why can't we mesh different genres in unexpected ways to create something new and exciting? 

So I'm asking you to help us produce a short film with an all transgender cast and create visible representations of a community that is as diverse as it is beautiful.

We are currently in pre-production. That means tons of preparation. If you know any trans actors interested in working on a film like this please direct them to the casting call below.

Location Scouting:

Here's where your contributions will help our film come to life! West New York, NJ, a square-mile town with the most incredible vibes and views of New York City. 



Casting Call for Short Film “Spot”

**IMPORTANT**

All actors interested, please be trans-identified. We will not police anyone’s gender presentation, just working on the honor system here. But this film is supposed to highlight the multiplicity of ways in which trans people can look, talk and move about in the world. All actors on screen must be trans-identified in some capacity. Gender-queer, agender, non-binary, etc. folks are welcome. No need to have been through medical/physical transition to be considered trans, as long as you self-identify as such. Acting experience strongly preferred but not absolutely essential to audition.

Contact Director & Writer, Jamie DiNicola, for audition information.

Email: jamiedinicola@gmail.com

Website: Jamiedinicola.com


About Our Crew

Writer and Director Jamie DiNicola 

Jamie is really excited about bringing this passion project to life with the help of your generous donations. Jamie studied women's and gender studies and filmmaking at Rutgers University and is currently a law student at Rutgers Law School. He hopes to combine his passions of activism and visual storytelling as a way to become a better artist and better activist. Watch below to learn a little more about where Jamie's passions come from. 



Cinematographer Jamie Deradorian-Delia

Jamie Deradorian-Delia is a New Jersey based Cinematographer who has a passion for creating impactful pieces. Jamie’s interest in cinema goes beyond just creating a “pretty picture” in order to find the truth in the frame. She most recently has worked as lead cinematographer on “I am the T’s”latest project Finding Cedar. She also was the lead cinematographer on “To Queer Things” web-series.

She has a B.A. in English with a minor in Cinema Studies from Rutgers University and a Documentary filmmaking certificate from Mason Gross School of the Arts. 


Producer Russell Dolan 

Russell is a New Jersey native who refuses to leave the Garden State. He works for the online skateboard magazine Jenkem Mag and helps out on comedy MNN public access show, "The Special Without Brett Davis." He suggests you quickly become fans of both.
story_txt: As a transgender activist and filmmaker I've always been searching for representations in the media of people like me and so I realized maybe I should do something about that myself. So I wrote a script for a short film and came up with this crazy idea that everyone on screen would be trans-identified. I figured, how many movies have I seen in my life with an all cisgender (non-trans) cast...why not try something a little different? Why not show everyone who views this film the multiplicity of ways in which trans people can look, talk, and move about in the world? Since there is no one singular trans experience why would I pigeonhole myself by creating a short film that fits neatly into an 'LGBT genre?' The LGBTQ experience is as vast and diverse as any other community and why can't we mesh different genres in unexpected ways to create something new and exciting? So I'm asking you to help us produce a short film with an all transgender cast and create visible representations of a community that is as diverse as it is beautiful.We are currently in pre-production. That means tons of preparation. If you know any trans actors interested in working on a film like this please direct them to the casting call below.Location Scouting:Here's where your contributions will help our film come to life! West New York, NJ, a square-mile town with the most incredible vibes and views of New York City. Casting Call for Short Film “Spot”**IMPORTANT**All actors interested, please be trans-identified. We will not police anyone’s gender presentation, just working on the honor system here. But this film is supposed to highlight the multiplicity of ways in which trans people can look, talk and move about in the world. All actors on screen must be trans-identified in some capacity. Gender-queer, agender, non-binary, etc. folks are welcome. No need to have been through medical/physical transition to be considered trans, as long as you self-identify as such. Acting experience strongly preferred but not absolutely essential to audition.Contact Director & Writer, Jamie DiNicola, for audition information.Email: jamiedinicola@gmail.comWebsite: Jamiedinicola.comAbout Our CrewWriter and Director Jamie DiNicola Jamie is really excited about bringing this passion project to life with the help of your generous donations. Jamie studied women's and gender studies and filmmaking at Rutgers University and is currently a law student at Rutgers Law School. He hopes to combine his passions of activism and visual storytelling as a way to become a better artist and better activist. Watch below to learn a little more about where Jamie's passions come from. Cinematographer Jamie Deradorian-DeliaJamie Deradorian-Delia is a New Jersey based Cinematographer who has a passion for creating impactful pieces. Jamie’s interest in cinema goes beyond just creating a “pretty picture” in order to find the truth in the frame. He works for the online skateboard magazine Jenkem Mag and helps out on comedy MNN public access show, "The Special Without Brett Davis." He suggests you quickly become fans of both.

story:
The Cause:

I'm Tony Hayton from Ottawa, Canada. My initial foray into crowd funding, so I'm happy that you dropped by! I'd love you to join in my cause and passion. For over 15 years now I have been involved with working to raise the prominence of a group of 1950s era African-American landscape artists known as the Florida Highwaymen. These 26 Artists (25 men and 1 woman) are critically and culturally acclaimed in Florida, but sadly unknown elsewhere. Their creativity has lasted up to the present day, with over 250,000 paintings created. The Florida Highwaymen began painting during a time of racial intolerance, segregation and prejudice. They not only created stunningly vibrant landscape art, but they also forged their own Civil Rights story. Their art was their vehicle to express their rights, freedoms and self-esteem. Please help to support or attend a Black History Month Exhibit celebrating the story, the era and the works of the Florida Highwaymen. The only "Highwaywoman" artist, Mary Ann Carroll, 77, will be in attendance. The Florida Highwaymen Art Exhibit in Toronto is the 4th and last in a series of highly acclaimed Highwaymen Exhibits in Canada. Please lend your support to make this important event happen! Thank you.

The History and Importance of the Florida Highwaymen:

African Americans Who Created Vibrant Landscape Art and a Poignant Civil Rights Story

“Art has an ability to soften difficult exchanges… exchanges in social, political and human difference. It fills the gaps between us and allows us to travel, work and coexist in the world harmoniously. As a whole we have great power for change and forward movement.”

—Nick Cave, artist (Chicago, USA), in response to this exhibition.

 

“Beauty is in the eye of the beholder. I guess there’s a lot of beholders”. – Mary Ann Carroll, Florida Highwaymen Artist.

 

“FORT PIERCE, Fla. — Wind-bent palm trees, sand, surf, billowing clouds and vivid sunsets were the essentials of Florida landscape painting that emerged following World War II. Occasionally moss-draped cypress trees in the still water of a marsh presented a more contemplative view, while a royal poinciana in full, flaming red bloom or a storm-tossed shore provided dramatic relief”. – The New York Times, 2001.

 

The Florida Highwaymen are a group of 26 African-American landscape painters that formed during the 1950s in Fort Pierce, Florida. Their careers took shape during a time and in a place where pursuing a career as an artist presented an alternative to working in citrus groves and labour camps. Denied access to private galleries due to segregation, the Highwaymen made a living selling their work door to door and from their cars along Florida’s eastern coastal roads A1A and US 1. Collectively, their work stands at the crossroads of innovation, entrepreneurship and personal-political resilience.

"History shall say that they fought for their freedom, using paints and brushes  in their arsenal to  challenge societies' unwritten laws, stereotypes and conventions. Their Civil Rights Story is  singularly unique. They did not march to demonstrate, instead they created vibrant, bold and majestic art to find freedom and self determination. In so doing they became a living example of the American Dream and gifted America with an incredible collection of breathtaking dreamlike landscapes depicting a lost primordial paradise that was Florida before the shovels and the concrete of development  that would change it forever. They are the Florida Highwaymen, African American Landscape artists from the 50s, and their untold American Saga of beauty and freedom. "

The Highwaymen first began painting Florida Landscapes in 1954. America was struggling to put a rocket into space, the national highway system was still two years away and Florida was a very young and undeveloped state. Racism, prejudice and harsh Jim Crow segregationist laws meant that African Americans were treated as second class citizens. Opportunities were few, and higher education and advancement were denied to most. Life offered hard menial work in hot agriculture fields. African Americans were  subjected to hatred, racism, segregation and violence. That year, the Civil Rights Movement in the south was just beginning.

Emerging against this backdrop, in the small east coast town of Fort Pierce, was a group of young African American landscape artists. Several of them had had some formal art training in High School, but most were self taught. They mentored each other and honed their skills. They developed ingenious "fast" painting techniques to increase productivity. Improvising to save costs, they used construction materials, "upson" wallboard for their "canvas" and window casing for frames.

Racism and prejudice closed the doors of art galleries as none would represent African American artists, that was the domain of white artists only. So they improvised to make their sales. They visited businesses, offices and homes to sell their art door to door and out of the trunks of their vehicles. Often these works were freshly painted and still wet. They took to the roads and the highways. In 1995, white art historian Jim Fitch began to research stories of a group of African American artists painting landscapes in the Fort Pierce area. He named the group, branding them the "Highwaymen." Astonishingly, it took 40 years after they had begun painting for them to become recognized as an art group! 

In 2004, the State of Florida inducted all 26 Highwaymen painters into the Florida Artists Hall of Fame, along with the likes of Ernest Hemingway, Ray Charles and Tennessee Williams. Estimates are that they created 250,000 to 400,000 works of art! Many of the surviving artists are still painting for a living.  Two generations of Highwaymen offspring and countless others now paint “in their style”. They continue to defy categorization and time. Respect is slow to come, yet with such a huge body of work over more than half a century of time they meet all the criteria of an art movement. In fact, it has been said that the Florida Highwaymen are the most significant American Art Movement of the last half of the 20th Century. Yet sadly, these artists have not yet been fully recognized for who they are or what they did.  Few outside the state of Florida have heard of them. Only recently has their epic saga been recognized as a unique but untold Civil Rights Story.

Their legacy is a massive body of work that captures a dreamlike primordial Florida landscape dominated by pristine wetlands, fecund forests and splendorous skies. It is a Florida that no longer exists, lost to development, tourism, and concrete. However, their artwork stands through time as a statement of environmental protection, self determination and human rights.

The Passion:

My adventures began with the Florida Highwaymen in 2001, while searching for some iconic Florida art, I found a painting online that reached out to me, it was a sun-drenched sandy beach, with crashing surf, tall billowing clouds, wafting palms and soaring  birds. I thought, that’s exactly what I was looking for. It said “Florida Highwaymen” so I began to research the painting's history and became "instantly hooked" on the story of this group of African American painters from Fort Pierce, Fla., who had defied social convention to sell their art as an alternative to working in Florida's citrus groves. I thought "This is like the Group of Seven in Canada but instead of seven white guys mentoring each other and painting the wilds of Canada, this is 26 black artists mentoring each other and painting the wilds of Florida. I was hooked!

The commonality to the Group of 7 intrigued me, and the art was fascinating. The story was romantic, poignant and inspiring,  Over time I ended up with a significant collection of Highwaymen paintings. But I needed to ask myself  what was I, as a Canadian, doing with all of this American art? I had lent it to many exhibits in Florida but I was living in Canada and had no intention of bringing the art north. I considered it an important part of American History and Culture. It really made no sense to have this collection sitting in storage. That to me was wrong, the art and the story needed to be shared. It needed to be on exhibit. I felt that underlying this  was also an untold Civil Rights. The story that needed to be told outside of Florida. The artists were getting older and dying off. I felt their story needed to be told by the artists while they were still alive. I took up the cause to get involved and share the art and help get these artists known and appreciated outside of Florida.

I chose to move my collection to Washington, I felt that was as a good as place as any to raise the group’s awareness. There I found an ally at Florida House, an embassy on Capital Hill, for a state instead of a country. They agreed to showcase my Highwaymen artwork. Since then I have spent the last decade trying to exhibit the  collection in the United States. Being out of the country has not helped. I had limited success in spreading the word. As an "unconnected" Canadian living north of the border I was having a difficult and challenging time "shedding light on this part of American History and Culture".


 I had  just about given up on my quest, and then one day last year the U.S. Embassy in Canada became aware of my collection and my efforts, and agreed to bring the paintings to Canada. In 2016, under the auspices of Vicki Heyman,  the wife of Bruce Heyman, the U.S. ambassador to Canada, the art crossed the border north into Canada. Mrs. Heyman, was a keen supporter of the arts and facilitated cross-border artistic exchanges while she was in Canada. She says "the Highwaymen's story addresses issues such as social justice, race, environment and identity." She believes the paintings constitute an art movement, although "not the kind of art movement the art society would necessarily accept." The U.S, Embassy helped to mount 3  exhibits in Ottawa, Montreal and Windsor, which all received rave reviews and critical acclaim.

The Highwaymen art in this exhibit will be departing Canada this year as it heads back to the U.S. It had arrived in Canada as part of a cultural mission for the U.S. Embassy in Ottawa, and the Montreal U.S. Consulate. The Windsor exhibit and now the upcoming Toronto exhibit have been self funded. The upcoming Toronto Black History Month exhibit will be important, being that it is in Canada's cultural centre, but also extra special, as famed Highwaywoman artist Mary Ann Carroll will be present for the exhibit's opening night events. She will be flying in specially from Florida to attend the festivities, share her stories and meet with exhibit attendees. The exhibit will be at Daniels Spectrum at 585 Dundas Street East in the Regent Park neighbourhood.

What is Needed:

The campaign to fund the exhibit has set a monetary goal of $3,500 CDN. The actual estimate to mount the exhibit is $5000 to $6000, so we are looking to fund just over half of that amount through INDIEGOGO. The big thanks go to all of you for helping  and with thanks to all of you.

Major costs include: Start up costs, advertising, printing and media outreach. Shipping the art to Toronto from Ottawa. Installing the art. Signage for the art. Opening night Vernissage , space, food, drinks. Return flight from Florida for Mary Ann Carroll (77) who needs to be accompanied by her daughter, as her health is not the best. Hotel, transport, food etc. for Mary Ann Carrol and her daughter while in Toronto.

I have attempted to allow for as many levels of support as is possible. A shared experience enhances the exhibit and speaks to the soul of the art and sharing not only it but also the story with as many people as possible.  The sense being that the more we can have involvement the greater the team. In the end the Exhibit and your support is about acknowledging the art and the fascinating efforts and the history of an extremely important, but unknown group of artists that did amazing things during a dark period of American History.

Great Perks For You!:

It's crowd funding and it's for art, I believe it's all about sharing. I'm trying to share this great art and this great story, I'd like you to share a little $ to  help me be able to do that. With that in mind there are a number of Kool Perks for you, after all The Florida Highwaymen is a very cool story and their art is also superb. Please join the team and partake in an important social event and help make this exhibit happen!

The $2 Team Perk, which is our ask to you to get involved at minimal cost. If we get 1000 people involved, at just a little money, this exhibit gets well on its' way to happening and I send you a Big Thanks!

There's also a $5 Perk which is My True Thanks & A Big Hug!

Next is a $5 Highwaymen Poster from the Windsor Highwaymen Exhibit.

For $10 You Have an invite to the Opening Night Reception of the Exhibit at Daniels Spectrum  in Toronto on February 09/2017.

story:
About this project

Hi, my name is Bill Czappa and I am an artist working with found objects. I have been making sculptures since the '60s. The project I want to finish is this piece I call “Abstract Erectorism.”  I started this piece some 20 years ago and want to use this platform to finish it. I need some $1795.00 to finish it up. My small business used to support my work but it is not doing so well these days so I really need your help to finish it. This is not the largest Erector set piece ever made but possibly one of the most interesting.  Seeing this piece in operation takes people back to their childhood and some holiday morning. So this piece needs to be completed and gotten out for the public to see and enjoy.

The piece itself is made from Erector set pieces. Erector sets are still made but the older ones are the best. You can build just about anything with this toy. In fact, it was designed to be an educational toy. I purchased 13 kits from an antique store that was moving and that was the impetus to make this piece. Since then I have had to purchase even more parts and motors from  Ebay. There are 8 different motors that move 8 different functions, each containing numerous moving parts. There will be lights in various places and in the little house you can peek in the window and see me in my studio building this very piece.

What needs to be done? All of the various elements have to be removed and re-installed on a new plywood backing. Some of the pieces will need to be sent out to be re-tinned.  I need to have a rack fabricated so it can be mounted on a wall, much like a mount for a flat screen TV. However, it will have to be made of aluminum in order to keep the weight down. Once that is made the various elements have to be re-installed and they have to be rewired and all the lights hooked up.

Then the complicated frame has to be made from several different pieces of moulding and it has to be made to attach to the piece after it is mounted on the wall, again in order to keep the weight down. 

So with your help I can finally finish it. I am offering some interesting rewards from a video of the piece being taken apart and re-built to a personal-guided tour of my studio followed by a burger, chili and kraut dog meal including beverage.

My budget is at the end of this.  If I get more then the amount requested I can miss some days at work and finish it even sooner.

Thanks for having a look, and to find out more about me have a look at my website and some documentary shorts that have been made about me and my work, including one on Vimeo featuring this very piece.

Web site: Czappa.com

Vimeo: CZAPPA: A Conversation on Art and TV Repair:https://vimeo.com/130500607

You Tube:

Older and wiser:  https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=yWW4j99yphU

City of lost parts: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8uetvFlpC_U


 

Just showing this Spruce goose ll piece as an example of a recent complicated piece which took 500 hours to build. It actually operates and sounds like a real airplane. You can see it operate here https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=IAkkMXBEvDM

This is the control panel for Spruce Goose. The "Abstract Erectorism" piece I am rebuilding is even more complicated.


The book "Tech Techniques" reward.


The "Holidaze" book reward.

This is the Starbucks pencil holder reward.


This is the tractor reward.


This is the pump car reward.


This is the "Suspense" reward.


Erector Oil Well 

This is the operating oil well reward. 


This is the "Metalphor" reward.


This is the Plywood Toaster reward.


This is Duck Tape reward.


This is the Waxing Poetic reward.


This is the operating Ferris Wheel reward.


This is the Round Go Round award.

Erector project of your choice on this page or similar one of equal complexity. Includes the Erector house.


This is the "Monument to the End of Time" reward.


Project budget.

3- 4’X8’ ¾” oak plywood veneer (49.99 each)    147.00

2- Saw blades     45.00

Stain     10.00

½  gallon polymer resin    45.00

Aluminum L channel   125.00

Welding labor        130.00

More erector parts for rewards      125.00

Ducks for reward (45.00 each)   180.00

Duck tape        8.00

5”x 1” moulding  65.00

4”x 1” molding       55.00

1 - ½" radius moulding    65.00

Hardwood for bases of rewards  125.00

Misc. hardware      75.00

D/C power supplies    25.00

Re-tinning some of the parts      125.00

Varnish & paint  85.00

Food and drinks for studio visits      145.00

 Help for studio visit      125.00

Kickstarter charge   90.00

Total       1795.00

Risks and challenges

Some of the obstacles that could come up is finishing it in the allotted time. Although the plans have already been drawn up, there is no way to accurately tell how long it might take given having to make some of the rewards as well. I have to work and only have half day Saturdays and all day Sundays to work on the piece and a few days after work. But once I get rolling on a piece I have a track record of getting them done as can be seen on some other major works I have made such as "The Spruce Goose ll" that took some 500 hours to build. 
The other problem could be summer heat as my studio is not air-conditioned.
story_txt:
About this project

Hi, my name is Bill Czappa and I am an artist working with found objects. I have been making sculptures since the '60s. The project I want to finish is this piece I call “Abstract Erectorism.”  I started this piece some 20 years ago and want to use this platform to finish it. I need some $1795.00 to finish it up. My small business used to support my work but it is not doing so well these days so I really need your help to finish it. This is not the largest Erector set piece ever made but possibly one of the most interesting.  Seeing this piece in operation takes people back to their childhood and some holiday morning. So this piece needs to be completed and gotten out for the public to see and enjoy.
The piece itself is made from Erector set pieces. Erector sets are still made but the older ones are the best. You can build just about anything with this toy. In fact, it was designed to be an educational toy. I purchased 13 kits from an antique store that was moving and that was the impetus to make this piece. Since then I have had to purchase even more parts and motors from  Ebay. There are 8 different motors that move 8 different functions, each containing numerous moving parts. There will be lights in various places and in the little house you can peek in the window and see me in my studio building this very piece.
What needs to be done? All of the various elements have to be removed and re-installed on a new plywood backing. Some of the pieces will need to be sent out to be re-tinned.  I need to have a rack fabricated so it can be mounted on a wall, much like a mount for a flat screen TV. However, it will have to be made of aluminum in order to keep the weight down. Once that is made the various elements have to be re-installed and they have to be rewired and all the lights hooked up.
Then the complicated frame has to be made from several different pieces of moulding and it has to be made to attach to the piece after it is mounted on the wall, again in order to keep the weight down. 
So with your help I can finally finish it. I am offering some interesting rewards from a video of the piece being taken apart and re-built to a personal-guided tour of my studio followed by a burger, chili and kraut dog meal including beverage.
My budget is at the end of this.  If I get more then the amount requested I can miss some days at work and finish it even sooner.
Thanks for having a look, and to find out more about me have a look at my website and some documentary shorts that have been made about me and my work, including one on Vimeo featuring this very piece.
Web site: Czappa.com
Vimeo: CZAPPA: A Conversation on Art and TV Repair:https://vimeo.com/130500607
You Tube:
Older and wiser:  https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=yWW4j99yphU
City of lost parts: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8uetvFlpC_U

Close up of "Abstract Erectorism"

Close up of crane on "Abstract Erectorism" 
Just showing this Spruce goose ll piece as an example of a recent complicated piece which took 500 hours to build. It actually operates and sounds like a real airplane. You can see it operate here https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=IAkkMXBEvDM

The Spruce Goose ll

Back of control panelThis is the control panel for Spruce Goose. The "Abstract Erectorism" piece I am rebuilding is even more complicated.

Ferris WheelThis is the operating Ferris Wheel reward.


Erector set LampThis is the Erector Set Lamp with operating crane and 4 position touch dimmer switch.

Erector project choicesErector project of your choice on this page or similar one of equal complexity. Includes the Erector house.

I have to work and only have half day Saturdays and all day Sundays to work on the piece and a few days after work. story:
Jaime Ruiz Otis Background //// Antecedentes

  • My name is Jaime Ruiz Otis. I am a visual artist form Baja California currently based in Los Angeles. Over the last twenty years, my artwork is based on upcycling industrial waste from the border maquiladoras. //// Mi nombre es Jaime Ruiz Otis. Soy artista visual originario de Baja California y actualmente vivo en Los Ángeles. Desde hace veinte años desarrollo trabajo artístico a partir de la apropiación y reciclaje de desechos industriales de las maquiladoras fronterizas.
  • Swatch Art Peace Hotel has awarded me an art residency from January to April 2020.  The residency covers my round fare trip and lodging costs. //// Swatch Art Peace Hotel me ha galardonado como artista residente de enero a abril de 2020. Esta residencia cubre mi viaje redondo y alojamiento.
  • The investigation I am proposing to develop as an artist-in-residence entails expeditions to industrial parks in peripheral Shanghai and the appropriation of found materials that I will integrate to artworks. //// La investigación que propongo como artista-en-residencia requiere la realización de expediciones a los parques industriales ubicados en el área conurbada de Shanghai para recolectar materiales que integraré en mis piezas.
  •  Your contributions will allow me to cover my field trips, art materials, and living expenses in Shanghai. This residency represents a major opportunity and a milestone in my career. All contributions will impact this artistic endeavor. //// Sus contribuciones me permitirán cubrir los gastos de transportación local, otros materiales artísticos y alimentación en Shanghai. Esta residencia representa una gran oportunidad y un parteaguas en mi carrera. Cualquier contribución impactará en la realización de mi proyecto.

​

The Goal and Purpose of this Fundraiser //// La meta y objetivo de esta campaña

  • This drive seeks to raise 4,000 USD that will pay for my local trips, food, and some materials in Shanghai. //// Esta campaña de recaudación de fondos busca reunir 4,000 USD con los que cubriré mi transporatción local, alimentación y materiales adicionales en Shanghai.
  • Contributions between 100-2000 USD will receive rewards that include original artworks and limited editions of prints, as well as artworks produced as part of this residency. //// Las contribuciones entre 100 y 2000 USD recibirán recompensas que incluyen obras de arte originales y ediciones gráficas, además de piezas producidas durante la residencia.
  • Any contribution is too small to impact my project and stay in Shanghai. //// Cualquier contribución por pequeña que sea impactará el desarrollo de mi proyecto y estancia en Shanghai.

​

The Significance of Your Contributions //// La importancia de sus contribuciones

  • The opportunity to do the Swatch Art Peace Hotel Residency means a major next step in my career. //// La oportunidad de participar en la Residencia del Swatch Art Peace Hotel representa un gran y muy importante paso en mi carrera.
  • The support of collectors, friends, and art enthusiasts interested in my work will be determinant in the development of a new body of work. //// El apoyo de coleccionistas, amigos y apasionados del arte interesados en mi obra será determinante en el desarrollo de este nuevo cuerpo de trabajo.

Please share this link with anyone you think might be interested in supporting this drive! Thanks! //// Por favor comparte esta liga con quien pueda interesarse en apoyar esta campaña. ¡Gracias!
