story:
About Me:

My name is Christian Stavrakis, and I'm a sculptor. I'm also the Chief Creative Officer of Cryptic Pictures, an independent film production & distribution company based in Pittsburgh and Maryland. My love of film - and eventually other forms of artistic expression - is an outgrowth of my youthful obsession with the works of one man: George A. Romero.

George is the reason I wanted to make films in the first place. He's the reason I live in Pittsburgh today. He was my inspiration to CREATE.

My brother Taso worked on some of George's films, and I was lucky enough to have visited the sets of Knightriders and Day of the Dead during their production. On both occasions I saw an incredible thing at work: I saw a group of unknown, non-Hollywood filmmakers working very hard to fulfill the vision of a man they obviously loved...a big, gentle Teddy bear of a man who clearly loved them too. You could feel it, like an invisible web of happiness binding these people together as they made these films off the map and under the radar.

The world lost a great creative soul on July 16th, 2017...and it's time this man was honored in Pittsburgh with a proper, respectful memorial to his zeal, humor, and independent spirit. Pittsburgh now has a bustling film community, but it all started with George and his band of merry men at the Latent Image (and later, Laurel Tape and Film).

This year marks the 40th anniversary of the production of Dawn of the Dead at the Monroeville Mall in Monroeville, PA (about 14 miles east of downtown Pittsburgh). The Mall has long been a destination for fans of George's work from all over the world, and now - with the blessing of the Mall's management - a permanent memorial to George may be installed, in the form of a bronze portrait bust sculpted by myself and sponsored by Cryptic Pictures, a company which wouldn't exist without his inspiration.

What We Need & What You Get:

We need to raise $18,000 to make this happen. This goes towards the creation and production of the bust itself (both in materials and sculpture), the purchase of supplies for same (as well as supplies for the various incentive products we'll be crafting in the weeks to come), a proper pedestal and accompanying bronze plaque for the memorial display, shipping of the incentive goods, reimbursement for work done and materials purchased, and various and sundry other expenses as yet unforeseen.

The incentives will include exclusive t-shirts, commemorative posters and postcards, a 1/3 scale version of the George bust, reproductions of the famous ashtray prop from Creepshow, DVDs of our own film Mortal Remains (which features many alumni from George's films), and a few other fun things.

George's Legacy:

Why install a bust of George at a shopping mall? If you have to ask...you didn't know George.

Dawn of the Dead was pooh-poohed at the time of its release by self-important critics who sniffed at its "thinly-veiled jab at consumerism." The cream always rises; as time has marched on, Dawn has come to be recognized as one of the most significant American films of the 20th century, genre trappings notwithstanding.

I've sculpted George as he appeared on Press Night in January, 1978. See the big grin on his face? That grin was the precursor to what I thought of as George's Tom Bombadil laugh, a great, hearty roar that seemed to emanate from the very ground beneath his feet.

Now imagine George's glee at being honored exactly where, 40 years ago, he staged a pie fight... (Here comes that big laugh...!)

Risks & Challenges:

The biggest challenge is that the clock is ticking. After I began sculpting in February, it occurred to me that the perfect event for the dedication of such a tribute was only a few months away. Our goal is to unveil and dedicate the bust and memorial at the Living Dead Weekend festival on the weekend of June 8th-10th. And it's already May...

The bust is under construction, but the rest needs to come together quickly! This 30-day campaign will end on June 6th, which is my 47th birthday. The dedication MUST take place that weekend.

Other Ways You Can Help:

SPREAD THE WORD! Even if you can't afford to contribute to the fund, please post, write, tweet, share photos! George deserves a lot more local recognition than our little project (a bridge named after him would be swell), but this is a start...it's the first public memorial to the man and his contributions to local history and the world of film.

And YOU can help make it happen!

story:
Welcome! 

Have a seat and get uncomfortable.

This is a fundraiser to grant me the opportunity to bring monsters to you, Toronto: an invitation for you to sit for a portrait as a monster.
“Wait, what?”
Okay, the back story: In 2013, I created 'I AM A MONSTER': a photo essay of a monster’s life, and his underlying humanity.  These six photos highlighted our similarities by exposing them as our assumption of difference.  They featured a “human-sized” monster, designed and created as part of my undergrad thesis at OCAD University. 

Wat, the name of this character, got to come out and play on a few occasions while I lived in Toronto, post graduation.  When I moved to Australia in 2015, he went into hibernation (tucked away in my childhood bedroom closet, of course).

This past September I was given the chance to build on this work as part of a show for Melbourne Fringe (TRANSTRAVAGANZA, Myriad Collective).  This time I wanted to design something for others to don.  This new monster was not a single character, but a “species” for anyone/everyone to belong to.  While this guise may cover the face, participants would still find themselves recognizable.  The portraits explored identity, individuality, and being different while belonging to a greater whole.  'I AM A MONSTER – and you can be, too' was the next chapter in my “monstrous body of work”. 

So now it’s your turn, Toronto!  Come and celebrate otherness and individuality, while finding yourself belonging to a greater whole: a whole new species of beautifully complex creatures. (Terrifying only in the power we may harness for our selves and others)

It’s time for you to become the monster you want to see in the world.

 

WHAT YOU ARE FUNDING:

I am setting myself a modest bare-minimum goal of $1000.  This will cover the costs of the printing & distribution of the portraits, as well as paying for location, equipment, and assistance for the photo shoot. 
The funding will also cover additional baggage costs for transporting my Obleng monster from Australia to Canada, as well and bringing the monsters I currently have in Canada back to Australia.

 

WHAT YOU ARE GETTING:

Those who are physically able to attend the photo portraits will receive a physical print of their portrait: one 5”x7” and five 2”x”3s.  You have the option to pose as the Obleng Monster (alone or with human friends) OR as an Obleng Monster with Wat.  You may donate/sign up for multiple portraits (one portrait per min. $25 donation; limit of 75 portraits total).

Additionally, for those who would like to participate in this monstrosity but are unable to physically attend, there are some physical perks to donating: a pack of 4”x6” prints of the original ‘I AM A MONSTER’ photo series (no quantity limit), a hand made one of a kind monster eye brooch/pin (limit of 50), and the “ultimate” perk of your very own custom monster plush (as well as aforementioned physical perks).

 

GOING BEYOND:

If, as I very much hope, I am able to raise more than my $1000 goal, this is what the additional money will enable me to do:

+$2000

will cover my regular living expenses (rent/bills) while I am off/out of work (away from Australia and in Canada for 6-8 weeks).  Additionally, it will enable me to apply for/attend the Toronto Makers Festival, which takes place the first weekend in July (the weekend before the photo shoots).  At the festival, I plan to have all of my monsters, as well as the prototypes I have built and tested while making them.  It would be an opportunity for me to share with the public how I make these creatures with accessible materials and tools.

+$3000

ADDITIONAL PHOTO SHOOT LOCATION: MONTREAL!  Getting to/above this amount will allow me to add an additional photo shoot opportunity, located in Montreal! 

This amount will also enable me to take additional narrative based photos of these monsters.  Ideas have already been brewing: you know, just casual daily life, like at the hair dresser’s and dog park.
 

+4000

I would be able to develop and print a monster “yearbook”: a collection of all the portraits I’ve taken (Melbourne, Toronto & Montreal), along with the narrative based photos of the monsters.
 

+5000

I’LL MAKE A WHOLE NEW MONSTER FOR YOU.
Yes, a whole new monster character to join the family, and for you to become.

 

Please donate what you can, and share it with anyone & everyone you think would want to participate.  I love doing this work, and sharing it with others, and I’m excited for this opportunity to continue to grow this family of monsters.


Follow the monstrous journey:
on Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/elijatude/
on Instagram: https://www.instagram.com/elijatude/

story:
The story

Hello! I'm Lorelai, a jewellery designer based in Reading. I currently offer all of my designs in custom colours as I love giving my customers the chance to be involved in the process and come up with their own combinations! I have been able to do that this past year because I became a member of a community run Hackspace which has a laser cutter amongst a variety of other tools and machines.

However, I will be relocating to Sheffield soon in search of a life filled with more art, music, culture and creative friends and in order to be able to continue to provide the bespoke service that my customers love, I will need to buy my own laser cutter.

That is where you come in! If you purchase a piece from this campaign, you will be helping me live my dream of spreading colour and joy around the world with my jewellery!

The laser cutter

I need a minimum of £5000 to be able to purchase a laser cutter; however the more I can raise, the better laser I can buy! I already have an entire rainbow of acrylic sheets in stock but I will need to purchase more in order to make all of your perks. I do have a some money in savings to out towards this.

I polled my customers to see if they would prefer the campaign perks to be exclusives or items that they would be able to purchase later on and it was a fifty fifty split! So there are a few designs which you can only buy in this campaign, such as the amazing glittery firework necklace and other such as the psychedelic flower earrings that will be made a permanent item in my shop. 

If I don't reach my goal, I will have to use some to get your perks made with a laser cutting service (Yeah Laser) and the rest will be squirreled away in savings until I can raise enough for the laser.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't afford to contribute, please help me spread the word by telling your friends and family about me and my business!

story:
WHO'S THE BEST FOOTBALLER IN THE WORLD? Is it ex-Manchester United and current Real Madrid goal-machine Cristiano Ronaldo? Or is it Barcelona’s talismanic ace Lionel Messi? The last 10 player of the year awards could not separate these 2 incredible athletes, but YOU can! YOU can decide which 1 of these 2 super-humans will go down in history as THE GREATEST OF ALL TIME!!

Our Indiegogo campaign allows you to contribute to creating a 20 FEET TALL BRONZE SCULPTURE of 1 of these 2 athletes. Every $ contributed will go towards determining who is the greatest ever footballer, and who we will immortalise in bronze! Funds generated through this campaign will not only be used to create the MASSIVE statue, but also be used towards transporting and exhibiting the winning statue at museums & events around the world!

Moreover, you can HAVE YOUR OWN FIRST AND LAST NAME ON THE STATUE for as little as $99! For contributing just $9 or more, YOUR FIRST AND LAST NAME WILL BE OFFICIALLY LISTED ON CR7vsLM10.com! You can see who is winning on CR7vsLM10.com! All odd pledges like $1, $5, $11, $47, $109 etc. will go towards backing a Ronaldo statue, and all even pledges like $2, $4, $10, $42, $110 etc. will go towards backing a Messi statue. Once the statue has been sculpted by December 2018, it will be transported to, and showcased at museums and events around the world - all while bearing your very own name on it!

IT'S TIME FOR THE BIGGEST RONALDO & MESSI FANS TO JOIN US IN CREATING HISTORY (literally), BY CONTRIBUTING TO THIS CAMPAIGN AND PUTTING THIS DEBATE TO REST, ONCE AND FOR ALL!

story:
Newark Print Shop

Newark Print Shop (NPS) is a 501(c)(3) organization dedicated to promoting the fine art of printmaking by providing a vibrant learning community and access to professional equipment and facilities. The shop incubates artistic expression through education, while simultaneously creating workspace opportunities for shop members and artists in our community. 

In 2012, artist and educator Lisa Conrad founded Newark Print Shop.  Her vision was to create a place where artists could work side by side, share and create together.  She turned her tiny downtown artist studio, which she paid a mere $187/mo, into a communal space, and invited artists to gather around her printing press and create together. Newark Print Shop was born!

6 years later, NPS continues to be a space for artists and has grown into a vibrant hub for community engagement and arts education for people of all ages and abilities to create, engaging with thousands of artists, entrepreneurs, students, and community members annually:

  • 1,603 K-12 STUDENTS: art education programs
  • 226 STUDENTS: adult education printmaking classes
  • 547 RECEPTION ATTENDEES: fine art print exhibitions
  • 1,600 PARTICIPANTS: live printing and public programs
  • 1,955 PARTICIPANTS: print club open studio access
  • 15 ARTISTS: teaching artists employed
  • 50 SCHOOLS: community partners engaging in our art ed programs

On January 5, 2019, our contract for our current space at Express Newark in Hahne & Co. expires, and sadly we do not have the option to renew and stay. While we are uncertain of our new address, it is exceedingly clear that there is a need for NPS to continue to serve the community and its artists whose desire is to create, educate, and showcase their craft.

What We Need & What You Get

We are looking to raise $30,000 to fund our transition and secure our new home. Our goal:  A PERMANENT BUILDING FOR NEWARK PRINT SHOP!

By raising $30,000 we accomplish the following:

  • Deposit/Down Payment for new space
  • Build-out funding to outfit a new space
  • If 1,000 people donate $30 each, we prove our wide community reach. People power has weight, join us in saying "Newark needs Print Club!"

As a token of our appreciation for your contribution, we have a few hand-printed perks that we are offering. Thank you!

The Impact

With your help, we can co-create a permanent facility for the community of printmakers in our city!

  • Permanent space for our programs and community of artists and printmakers
  • We have successfully opened up 3 printmaking facilities in the past 6 years, and have only expanded our impact & reach each time! Help us open our 4th space in a more sustainable, LONG-TERM space.
  • We have secured equipment donations from prestigious institutions including Metropolitan Museum of Art, Newark Museum, and Seton Hall University to name a few. It is tiring to move large, heavy antique presses every 2 years. Help us land in a long-term space!
  • Our reach is far! We have folks trekking from all parts of Newark, NJ, NYC, and even PA to join our weekly Print Club. Just imagine how far we can go with a permanent home!

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute financially, and that's ok! But that doesn't mean you can't help:

  • Share the link and spread the word!
  • Advocate for the Newark Print Shop!
  • Construction skills? Help us with the buildout!
  • Free time? Help us set up the new shop once the space is secured!

WE SINCERELY APPRECIATE EACH AND EVERY ONE OF YOU! Thank you so much for being a part of our community throughout these past six years. Our goal: to remain a vibrant community arts space for decades more and generations to come! Join us on this journey!
#newarkprintshoplovesyou

story:
The Journey

 The Raincoast journey began for me when I decided to combine my artwork with my interest in Tarot.

I'm not a company, I'm only one person, and I have gone from sketches to final production, with a great deal of encouragement along the way.

Without crowd funding, I would not achieved my goal. Start up money is essential.

It's very important to me that I deliver the best quality product that I can.

 What You Get

The Raincoast Tarot deck arrives in an attractive Tin. (No flimsy tuck boxes here.)

The cards are 2.75" x 3.75" in a durable medium stock with a satin finish. The colours are beautiful and bright, without being garish. Each deck comes with a signed and numbered COA.

The Impact

By supporting my Tarot deck you will become a very Valued Patron of the arts, and will be helping me to continue with the creative work that is so close to my heart.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Understandably some people can not afford a pledge, but you can be a great help by passing on

the campaign to anyone that you think may be interested. Please note that there are a number of Indiegogo share tools!

story:
While the juggernaut of technology and virtual reality are unstoppable and are leading us into a world of digital disconnect, our show, Actual Reality, at the Museum of Ventura County , June-mid-August 2019, is our attempt to honor the real in the here and now.

 Carlos Grasso’s luminous, vibrant hand-cut shreddings and multi-colored assemblages along with Peter Fox’s often humorously concocted found objects wish to engage the viewers with analog appreciation of what can be seen and touched in real time, not relying on coded 0s, 1s, and an electric screen. This is an unique opportunity to see these two artistic visions in one coherent show.

We are seeking to raise $8500 to make and promote this exhibit. Please consider helping us realize our vision by watching the video and clicking the link below. And we hope to see you at Actual Reality.

MEET THE ARTISTS

PETER FOX

After graduating from Harvard with a concentration in primate anthropology, I spent many years roaming the jungles of Los Angeles acting on stage and screen, producing, writing screenplays, and directing plays. After leaving Hollywood and moving to Ojai, I became restless. One day I looked around at the diverse oddities I had gathered over the years on movie locations, junk stores, and flea markets. These found objects all seemed to stare at me and say “Okay, you got us here. Now what?”

I started to see connections and put things together in what I came to learn was “assemblage”. I was suddenly in a realm where 2 + 2 equals many things other than 4.

Who inspires my brand of art? “Ballard Street” cartoonist Jerry Van Amerongen is an insightful, hilarious, and soulful navigator. Although I never knew of him previously, I found myself crawling into Cornellian boxes. Marcel Duchamp, I have to believe, was chuckling inside when he hung his urinal.  And Kris Kuksi, Gerard Cambon, Carlos Grasso, Ron Robertson, and Ted Gall all push me to go further.

Peter Fox Art Statement

Here’s what I’ve learned --

Art is everywhere, in everything. Believe it.What is the thread that led me to art?

“I’m here!”

Yet I know someday I won’t be. Most of my adult life has been spent creating projects that say “I’m here, if just for a short time.” Surely ego/vanity play their  mischievous parts, but discounting those two nuisances, there is a deeper universal need to create something that says “I was here and I had something to say.” As Lord Buckley put it, to “…stomp the terra!”

My particular mode of expression often involves humor. But it is humor I take seriously. In my work and titles, I strive to create and share a spark of recognition with my audience that says “Right. I get that.”

But what is “that”? For me, it is how we are all trying desperately to navigate the complex absurdity of quotidian existence…with mixed results.

Creating these pieces gives me great pleasure, and like all the other creative projects I’ve done in my life, they flow out of me on their own accord.

It’s child’s play. Remember that?

 

CARLOS GRASSO

Visionary Artist and Compulsive Visual Explorer
Carlos Grasso’s personal journey began in the cosmopolitan city of Buenos Aires, Argentina, where his parents encouraged his interest in the arts, particularly music. As a young adult, while studying figure drawing in workshops, he also studied both piano and flute at the National Conservatory of Music before moving to Paris, where he worked as a professional flautist for 15 years. During this period, he also trained and worked as a graphic designer. After moving to Southern California, it only took one class with master representational artist David Leffel for Carlos to discover a new passion: painting. Over the last 25 years, not only has he transitioned from music to making art full time, he’s also shifted from representational works to abstraction, mixed media and conceptual art. Throughout this period, he has participated in many gallery and group exhibitions, and received a number of awards for his work.

Carlos Grasso Art Statement

What might seem as nothing but a torn piece of canvas or a rusty sheet of metal to be discarded, I visualize as the perfect ingredient for my next piece of work. What might be viewed as worthless scraps of wood or slit fabric I envision as works of art. They speak to me just as much as my paints and brushes, sometimes asking and sometimes flat-out demanding to be included in my art. They are the blood and bones of my current creations.


Artists—in all branches and disciplines—are the preeminent voice of both the collective and the individual unconscious. Art brings to the surface, to our awareness, all the processes that run deep, embedded, and often silently ignored within. As the ancient philosopher once said, the unexamined life is not worth living.

 

The Museum of Ventura County

100 East Main Street • Ventura, CA 93001 - 11 am to 5 pm - Tues. through Sund.

Founded in 1913, The Museum of Ventura County celebrates, preserves and interprets the art, history and culture of Ventura County, the California Channel Islands and the surrounding region. Our collections, exhibitions, educational programs and research library are designed to be a gathering place for the community to inspire curiosity and conversations about the past and the stories of who we are and what makes us unique.

 

We hope to see you at the Actual Reality Show

at The Museum of Ventura County, June-August 2019

And THANK YOU for your support!

story:
We are no longer accepting book orders via IndieGoGo.

Please email NANO LEON STUDIO to place your order!

 

(Versión en español abajo)

Masks of New York will be a coffee table book that brings together more than 100 photographic portraits of New Yorkers (during the pandemic). Currently more than 200 participants have been photographed. The focus will be your protective masks, but the emotional focus will be your eyes.

In addition to being photographed, participants will have the opportunity to share their experience with the world of what their life is like in the times of COVID-19.

I am Nano León, a Colombian photographer. As a fashion photographer, I am always looking for the most beautiful way to tell a story. But now, fashion in New York City has been transformed. While wearing a mask is not ideal, New Yorkers have found a way to express themselves and show the world their creativity when it comes to wearing a mask and that gives me hope.

I decided to create MASKS OF NEW YORK to remind myself why I love New York and inspire the people in my foster home to feel joy and pride in wearing a mask.

My ultimate goal is to promote the wearing of masks, but also to capture a historic moment, from when the pandemic flourished in a fashion capital of the world. With your help and when it is safe to do so, I would like to be able to make an exhibition of photos and stories.

 

Where will your money go

With more than 12 years as a photographer, I am lucky to have all the photographic equipment I need, and a friend has lent me his high-speed bicycle (for now) to reach all the destinations where I will take the photos of the participants.

Doing the entire process from start to finish for each person: find participants, collect and organize their information, travel to and from their neighborhoods by bicycle, edit and retouch the photos, review the stories for typos and place them on the website : it will take between 3 to 5 hours per person.

 

Risks and challenges

The main financial risk is that while cycling around town, I have an accident and break my photographic equipment. Although I am taking all precautions and have no pre-existing conditions, I could potentially become ill and not be able to complete the project. Another risk is that participants do not complete their stories after I take their photos.

 

Other ways you can support

If you can't afford the book, there are other ways you can get involved!

1. Volunteer to be photographed and tell your story.

SIGN UP TO BE PHOTOGRAPHED

I will create a bike route and visit the volunteers one by one to take their portrait. I will take all photographs outside, keep at least six feet away from everyone, always wear a mask, and only ride my bike.

After taking your portrait, I will email you to get your personal story about your life during the pandemic. The final step is to match your portrait with your story on the project website.

2. Donate a few dollars to this campaign.

3. Get in touch with your most interesting friends to be part of the project.

4. Share the project and fundraising campaign (IndieGoGo) on social media. Follow the project and tag us at: @ Masks.ofNewYork and #masksofnewyork


 

Versión Español 

Masks of New York será un libro de mesa que reunirá más de 100 retratos fotográficos de neoyorquinos. Actualmente hemos fotografiado mas de 200 participantes. El enfoque serán sus máscaras protectoras, pero el enfoque emocional serán sus ojos. 

Además de ser fotografiados, los participantes tendrán la oportunidad de compartir su experiencia con el mundo de cómo es su vida en los tiempos del COVID-19.

Soy Nano León, un fotógrafo colombiano. Como fotógrafo de moda, siempre busco la forma más bella de contar una historia. Pero ahora, la moda en la ciudad de Nueva York se ha transformado. Si bien usar una máscara es no es lo ideal, los neoyorquinos han encontrado una manera de expresarse y mostrarle al mundo su creatividad a la hora de llevar una máscara y eso me da esperanza.

Decidí crear MÁSCARAS DE NUEVA YORK para recordarme por qué amo a Nueva York e inspirar a la gente de mi hogar adoptivo, a sentir alegría y orgullo de usar una máscara.

Mi objetivo final es promover el uso de máscaras, pero también capturar un momento histórico, de cuando la pandemia floreció en una capital mundial de la moda. Con la ayuda de ustedes y cuando sea seguro hacerlo, me gustaría poder hacer una exhibición de fotos e historias.

 

A dónde irá tu dinero

Con más de 12 años como fotógrafo, tengo la suerte de tener todo el equipo de fotográfico que necesito, y un amigo me ha prestado su bicicleta de alta velocidad (por ahora) para llegar a todos los destinos donde tomare las fotos de los participantes.

Hacer todo el proceso de principio a fin para cada persona: buscar participantes, recopilar y organizar su información, viajar hacia y desde sus vecindarios en bicicleta, editar y retocar las fotos, revisar las historias en busca de errores tipográficos y colocarlas en el sitio web: tomará entre 3 a 5 horas por persona.

 

Riesgos y desafíos

El principal riesgo financiero es que mientras voy en bicicleta por la ciudad, tengo un accidente y rompo el equipo de mi fotográfico. Aunque estoy tomando todas las precauciones y no tengo condiciones preexistentes, podría enfermarme potencialmente y no poder completar el proyecto. Otro riesgo es que los participantes no completen sus historias después de que yo tome sus fotos.

 

Otras formas en que puede apoyar

Si no puede pagar el libro, ¡hay otras formas en que puede participar!

1. Voluntario para ser fotografiado y contar tu historia. 

REGÍSTRESE PARA SER FOTOGRÁFIADO

Crearé una ruta en bicicleta y visitaré a los voluntarios uno por uno para tomar su retrato. Tomaré todas las fotografías afuera, me mantendré al menos a seis pies de distancia de todas las personas, siempre usaré una máscara y solo viajaré en bicicleta.

Después de tomar su retrato, le enviaré un correo electrónico para obtener su historia personal sobre su vida durante la pandemia. El paso final es unificar su retrato con su historia en el sitio web del proyecto.

2. Done unos pocos dólares a esta campaña.

3. Póngase en contacto con sus amigos más interesantes para ser parte del proyecto.

4. Comparta el proyecto y la campaña de recaudación de fondos (IndieGoGo) en las redes sociales. Siga el proyecto y etiquétenos en: @ Masks.ofNewYork y #masksofnewyork

Con la ayuda de ustedes y cuando sea seguro hacerlo, me gustaría poder hacer una exhibición de fotos e historias. A dónde irá tu dineroCon más de 12 años como fotógrafo, tengo la suerte de tener todo el equipo de fotográfico que necesito, y un amigo me ha prestado su bicicleta de alta velocidad (por ahora) para llegar a todos los destinos donde tomare las fotos de los participantes.Hacer todo el proceso de principio a fin para cada persona: buscar participantes, recopilar y organizar su información, viajar hacia y desde sus vecindarios en bicicleta, editar y retocar las fotos, revisar las historias en busca de errores tipográficos y colocarlas en el sitio web: tomará entre 3 a 5 horas por persona. Riesgos y desafíosEl principal riesgo financiero es que mientras voy en bicicleta por la ciudad, tengo un accidente y rompo el equipo de mi fotográfico. Aunque estoy tomando todas las precauciones y no tengo condiciones preexistentes, podría enfermarme potencialmente y no poder completar el proyecto. Otro riesgo es que los participantes no completen sus historias después de que yo tome sus fotos. Otras formas en que puede apoyarSi no puede pagar el libro, ¡hay otras formas en que puede participar!1. Voluntario para ser fotografiado y contar tu historia. REGÍSTRESE PARA SER FOTOGRÁFIADOCrearé una ruta en bicicleta y visitaré a los voluntarios uno por uno para tomar su retrato. Tomaré todas las fotografías afuera, me mantendré al menos a seis pies de distancia de todas las personas, siempre usaré una máscara y solo viajaré en bicicleta.Después de tomar su retrato, le enviaré un correo electrónico para obtener su historia personal sobre su vida durante la pandemia. El paso final es unificar su retrato con su historia en el sitio web del proyecto.2. Done unos pocos dólares a esta campaña.3. Póngase en contacto con sus amigos más interesantes para ser parte del proyecto.4. Comparta el proyecto y la campaña de recaudación de fondos (IndieGoGo) en las redes sociales. Siga el proyecto y etiquétenos en: @ Masks.ofNewYork y #masksofnewyork

story:
WE NEED YOUR HELP!

Earlier this year, we were awarded an art grant from YOUTopia, an arts & music festival that happens every year in San Diego. We were lucky enough to be one of only 2-3 projects that were awarded their largest art grant, and it gave us a strong foundation to start making things happen. However, it's only a portion of the funds we need and as artists, we're expected to raise the remaining funds and complete the project. We love this for a few reasons (mainly because it encourages us to engage with our communities in exciting ways), but it also presents some obvious challenges, as it takes us away from the very thing we were commissioned to do, which is to make art.

We're looking to raise $2,000 to cover the costs of purchasing materials, machine rentals/shop space, the time of some very skilled programmers and technicians as well as the costs of transporting ma8nanimous to YOUTopia.

YOUTopia is just the beginning! This is a project that will grow, change and take on all kinds of new dimensions as it travels to different festivals, public spaces and communities. Even if you can not attend YOUTopia, your donation helps us get ma8nanimous closer to you!

 

Where The Money Goes:

  • Purchasing remaining lumber
  • Welding climbable handles
  • Programming LEDs
  • Transporting ma8nanimous to YOUTopia

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Not everyone has money to give, but that doesn't mean you can't help! Help us get the word out by sharing with friends, family and anyone else who might enjoy ma8nanimous! If you're interested in volunteering, let us know - hit the "Ask A Question" button towards the top of a page and shoot us a message!

 

http://www.sdyoutopia.com
